While some features have been upgraded - the house is double glazed - David Beddoe, director of Auction Houses Bristol and Somerset North, believes the potential cost of renovations could put developers off.

He believes the house could make a perfect family home for those with a passion for antiques. The historic house will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo on Saturday after his parents dangled him over the edge. The boy suffered minor injuries and was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived on the scene. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the parents.

The boy's mother was holding him and another child when he slipped and fell between 10 to 12 feet into the pit. The boy's leg was injured in the fall, but he was not attacked by the animals.

Zoo officials said the cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents while in the pit. Zoo visitor Terra Lurie believes the boy was not approached by the fast feline because they were frightened.

The zoo has received a number of eyewitness accounts that indicate the "strong likelihood that the child was dangled over the railing," zoo executive director Dr. Christopher Kuhar said.

The exhibit was closed following the child's fall.

Dawn, a woman who has had seven miscarriages, was devastated when she discovered that her friend Jamie had stolen £207 from her. The money was set aside for a gravestone for her son Daniel James, who died shortly after birth. Dawn confronted Jamie, who denied stealing the money. However, a lie detector test revealed that Jamie was lying. Jamie later confessed to taking the money and blamed it on his girlfriend Carol. Dawn was left feeling betrayed and heartbroken. She said that she felt like she had been "thrown in the face" after trying to do a good deed for Jamie.

A working animal is an animal that is kept by humans and trained to perform tasks. They may be close members of the family, such as guide dogs or other assistance dogs, or they may be animals trained to provide tractive force, such as draft horses or logging elephants. They may also be used for milking or herding, jobs that require human training to encourage the animal to cooperate. On rare occasions, wild animals may be not only tamed, but trained to perform work, though often solely for novelty or entertainment purposes, as such animals tend to lack the traits of trustworthiness and mild temper that characterize the true domesticated working animal.

Working animals have been used by humans for centuries, and they play an important role in many cultures around the world. They provide transportation, labor, and companionship, and they can also be used for security and protection. Working animals are often considered to be members of the family, and they are treated with respect and care.

There are many different types of working animals, each with its own unique set of skills and abilities. Some of the most common working animals include horses, dogs, cattle, sheep, and pigs. These animals are used for a variety of purposes, including transportation, agriculture, and security.

Working animals are an important part of human society, and they play a vital role in many cultures around the world. They provide us with transportation, labor, and companionship, and they can also be used for security and protection. Working animals are often considered to be members of the family, and they are treated with respect and care.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, fell down a 70-foot cliff to his death after running from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. He had been out drinking with friends in Cardiff and caught a taxi home, but didn't have enough cash to pay for it. He ran from the taxi driver, who gave chase, and fell down the cliff in the dark. His body was found the next day.

The inquest heard that Phillips had grown up in Barry, South Wales, before studying accountancy at the University of Birmingham. He had returned to Wales for Christmas and had been staying with his mother in the upmarket Cowbridge area. Phillips had planned to stay at a friend's house but he and his friends didn't have enough money to complete the journey, so decided to trick the driver by "dodging" the fare.

Phillips ran off into the "pitch black" and fell down a cliff at the end of the disused Northern Promenade - also called The Dardanelles. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, told the inquest: "I stopped because I couldn't see where I was going. I had no idea how much danger he was in."

Coroner Andrew Barkley recorded a verdict of accidental death. He said: "It is likely that he became disorientated and there is no evidence that he knew where he was at the time. "There is no way he could have known the danger that lay in front of him. The following day with the benefit of light it was clear the danger he faced by the sheer drop off the cliff just yards beyond the fence."

A&E is an American cable and satellite television channel that serves as the flagship television property of A&E Networks, a joint venture between the Hearst Corporation and Disney–ABC Television Group subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company (both of which maintain a 50% ownership interest). The channel was launched on January 1, 1984, as the Arts & Entertainment Network. It was originally a joint venture between Hearst and ABC, but Disney acquired ABC in 1996 and became a partner in A&E.

A&E's programming includes a variety of documentaries, reality shows, and dramas. The channel has been home to some of the most popular reality shows on television, including "The First 48" and "Hoarders." A&E also produces a number of original documentaries, including "Biography" and "Investigation Discovery."

A&E is available in over 90 million homes in the United States. The channel is also available in a number of other countries around the world.

AMGTV is an American family-oriented television network that features a variety of programming, including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how-to, hunting and fishing, children's shows, and other features.

Aaron Burr was an American politician who served as the third Vice President of the United States from 1801 to 1805. He was born in Newark, New Jersey, in 1756, and studied law at Princeton University. After graduating, he moved to New York City and began practicing law.

Burr was elected to the New York State Assembly in 1784 and 1785. In 1789, he was appointed New York State Attorney General. He served in that position until 1791, when he was elected to the United States Senate. Burr served in the Senate until 1797.

In 1800, Burr was elected Vice President of the United States. He served under President Thomas Jefferson. Burr and Jefferson had a falling out, and Burr ran for President in 1804. He lost the election to Jefferson.

In 1804, Burr killed Alexander Hamilton in a duel. He was tried for murder, but was acquitted. Burr fled to Europe after the trial. He returned to the United States in 1812.

Burr died in 1836 in Staten Island, New York. He was 80 years old.

Harbro Group, an Aberdeenshire-based company that manufactures and supplies feeds for the beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry sectors, saw pre-tax profit increase by £800,000, to £3.5m, in the year to the end of June 2016. This was despite turnover falling by £1m to just over £100m. Harbro said international sales grew over the year, both in Europe and in new markets further afield. The company also has a network of 19 shops across Scotland, operating under the Country Store brand. The stores cater for farming and rural communities with a range of products, including fireside supplies, country clothing and footwear. In accounts filed with Companies House, the company said: "As always, the outlook for agriculture is difficult to predict. "We have certainly been experiencing challenging times over the last 12-18 months but the industry is a robust one. "The impact of Brexit is still to be fully understood, although the board are confident that the group will be well positioned for whatever business challenges this may bring about."

The Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, was facing the loss of its collection of 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs. The collection was to be auctioned to help pay off the pottery firm's pension debt. However, a public fundraising campaign launched in September hit its target in just a month. The Art Fund, which led the campaign, will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, before it is loaned to the Wedgwood Museum.

The Wedgwood Museum inherited Waterford Wedgwood plc's pension bill after the firm collapsed in 2009. In 2010 the museum also went into administration, and in 2011 a high court judge ruled its collection could be sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund.

Alison Wedgwood, whose husband Tom is a direct descendant of company founder Josiah Wedgwood, said the collection was "important" for Staffordshire. The collection risked being "sold and scattered around the globe" had the money not been raised, she added.

Tristram Hunt MP, who was involved in the campaign, said the sale was "fantastic news". "The items contained within the Wedgwood collection chart a significant part of Britain's cultural development over centuries and play a crucial part in defining our national identity today," he said.

Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil are trying to avoid a second election by forming a minority government. However, they are struggling to agree on a number of issues, including water charges. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is one of the proposals being considered.

Advertising is a form of marketing communication that employs an openly sponsored, nonpersonal message to promote or sell a product, service, or idea. It can be delivered through a variety of media, including television, radio, print, online, and mobile.

The goal of advertising is to persuade consumers to take action, such as buying a product, visiting a website, or signing up for a service. Advertising can be used to create awareness of a product or service, build brand loyalty, or generate leads.

There are many different types of advertising, including product advertising, service advertising, institutional advertising, and cause advertising. Product advertising promotes a specific product or service. Service advertising promotes a specific service. Institutional advertising promotes an organization or institution. Cause advertising promotes a social or political cause.

Advertising can be a very effective marketing tool, but it can also be expensive. It is important to carefully consider the target audience, the message, and the media before launching an advertising campaign.

Here are some of the benefits of advertising:

* It can help to increase brand awareness and recognition.
* It can help to generate leads and sales.
* It can help to build relationships with customers and prospects.
* It can help to position a company or product in the marketplace.
* It can help to create a positive image for a company or product.

Here are some of the challenges of advertising:

* It can be expensive.
* It can be difficult to measure the effectiveness of advertising.
* It can be difficult to reach the right target audience.
* It can be difficult to create effective advertising messages.
* It can be difficult to compete with other advertisers.

Despite the challenges, advertising can be a very effective marketing tool. When done correctly, it can help to achieve a variety of marketing goals.

Advertising is a form of marketing communication that employs an openly sponsored, nonpersonal message to promote or sell a product, service, or idea. It is differentiated from personal selling in that the message is nonpersonal, i.e., not directed to a particular individual. Advertising is communicated through various mass media, including old media such as newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising or direct mail; or new media such as search results, blogs, websites or text messages.

The goal of advertising is to persuade the target audience to take a particular action, such as buying a product, visiting a website, or signing up for a service. Advertising can be used to create awareness of a product or service, to build brand loyalty, or to generate leads.

There are many different types of advertising, including print advertising, television advertising, radio advertising, online advertising, and mobile advertising. Each type of advertising has its own advantages and disadvantages.

Print advertising is the oldest form of advertising and is still one of the most effective. Print ads can be placed in newspapers, magazines, and other publications. They can also be used to create brochures, flyers, and other marketing materials.

Television advertising is a very effective way to reach a large audience. Television ads can be used to create a strong emotional connection with the target audience. However, television advertising can be expensive.

Radio advertising is a less expensive way to reach a large audience than television advertising. Radio ads can be used to target a specific audience based on their listening habits. However, radio ads are not as effective as television ads at creating a strong emotional connection with the target audience.

Online advertising is a rapidly growing form of advertising. Online ads can be placed on websites, search engines, and social media platforms. Online advertising is a very effective way to target a specific audience based on their interests. However, online advertising can be expensive.

Mobile advertising is a new form of advertising that is growing in popularity. Mobile ads can be placed on mobile devices, such as smartphones and tablets. Mobile advertising is a very effective way to reach a target audience that is always on the go. However, mobile advertising can be expensive.

The effectiveness of advertising can be measured in a number of ways, including brand awareness, sales, and website traffic. Advertising can be a very effective way to reach a large audience and persuade them to take a particular action.

Chelsea defender John Terry was adjudged to have fouled Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao in the build-up to Eden Hazard's opening goal in Chelsea's 1-0 win on Saturday. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp and Graeme Souness all agreed that Terry's challenge was a foul, with Souness saying that Terry "stuck his elbow in the back of Falcao's head". Henry said that he would have wanted a foul in that position as a player, while Redknapp admitted that Falcao could have possibly done better to stay on his feet but that Terry's challenge was still a foul.

Surrey beat Yorkshire by 19 runs in the quarter-finals of the T20 Blast. Surrey were reduced to 8-2 but posted a score of 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes (90) sharing a stand of 130. Yorkshire's run-chase was undermined by a three-wicket burst in nine balls from Stuart Meaker, whose victims included Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Tim Bresnan made 68 but was the last to go as they were all out for 236.

Surrey skipper Gareth Batty said: "Everyone is stepping up to the plate when the team requires, everybody's pulling together. "Davies and Foakes were quite magnificent, that partnership blew the game wide open. "The position we got ourselves to, I thought we should maybe have been 265 or 270. "But we got wickets at the right times and it was always going to be an uphill battle for them once it got down to those final overs."

Yorkshire captain Alex Lees said: "We are all gutted. We have played some great white-ball cricket this season, but when it has mattered we haven't been good enough. "The bowlers were exceptional and we thought it was a reachable target. We needed someone in the top five to make a contribution and we would have reached the target comfortably."

West Ham United beat Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup second round on Wednesday. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored for the Premier League side, who made seven changes following top-flight losses at Manchester United and Southampton. The hosts went close via Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header, but could not find a way past Hammers goalkeeper Adrian. Slaven Bilic's side could have won by a greater margin, but Robins captain Kyle Storer cleared Angelo Ogbonna's fierce header off the line in the first half and, moments later, keeper Jonathan Flatt did well to stop Sakho turning in Ayew's low cross. Cheltenham's exit ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup before Thursday's third-round draw.

Aleister Crowley (1875-1947) was an English occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer. He was born Edward Alexander Crowley in Royal Leamington Spa, Warwickshire, England. He was the son of Edward Crowley, a wealthy businessman, and Emily Bertha Crowley (née Bishop). Crowley was educated at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he studied mathematics and natural sciences. After graduating from Cambridge, Crowley traveled extensively throughout Europe and Asia. He also spent time in the United States, where he met and married Rose Edith Kelly. Crowley and Kelly had one child, a daughter named Lola Zaza. In 1898, Crowley joined the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn, an occult order founded in London in 1888. He quickly rose through the ranks of the order and became one of its most prominent members. However, Crowley's association with the Golden Dawn came to an end in 1904, when he was expelled from the order for his "unethical" behavior. After leaving the Golden Dawn, Crowley founded his own occult order, the A∴A∴, or Argenteum Astrum. The A∴A∴ was a secret society dedicated to the study and practice of magic. Crowley also founded the Ordo Templi Orientis (O.T.O.), an occult order that was based on the teachings of the Golden Dawn. The O.T.O. is best known for its use of sex magic, a practice that Crowley believed was essential for spiritual enlightenment. Crowley was a prolific writer and published numerous books on occultism, magic, and religion. He also wrote poetry, novels, and essays. Crowley's work has been controversial, and he has been accused of being a Satanist and a black magician. However, Crowley has also been praised for his contributions to the study of magic and his insights into the human condition. Crowley died in Hastings, England, on December 1, 1947. He was 72 years old.

Alice Cooper is an American singer, songwriter, and actor whose career spans over five decades. He was born Vincent Damon Furnier on February 4, 1948, in Detroit, Michigan. He is best known for his work in the 1970s, when he released a string of successful albums, including "Love It to Death" (1971), "Killer" (1971), and "School's Out" (1972). Cooper's stage shows were known for their shock value, and he often performed in a straitjacket or with a snake around his neck. He has sold over 50 million albums worldwide.

Cooper was born into a religious family, and his father was a minister. He began playing guitar at the age of 12, and he formed his first band, the Spiders, in 1964. The Spiders released several singles, but they never achieved commercial success. In 1969, Cooper changed the name of his band to Alice Cooper, and they released their debut album, "Pretties for You." The album was a commercial failure, but it helped to establish Cooper's image as a shock rocker.

Cooper's second album, "Easy Action," was released in 1970. The album was more successful than his debut, and it reached number 19 on the Billboard 200 chart. Cooper's third album, "Love It to Death," was released in 1971. The album was a commercial breakthrough, and it reached number 3 on the Billboard 200 chart. The album spawned the hit singles "I'm Eighteen" and "Be My Lover."

Cooper's fourth album, "Killer," was released in 1971. The album was even more successful than "Love It to Death," and it reached number 2 on the Billboard 200 chart. The album spawned the hit singles "Under My Wheels" and "School's Out."

Cooper's fifth album, "School's Out," was released in 1972. The album was Cooper's most successful album, and it reached number 1 on the Billboard 200 chart. The album spawned the hit singles "School's Out" and "Gimme Some Lovin'."

Cooper continued to release successful albums throughout the 1970s, including "Billion Dollar Babies" (1973), "Welcome to My Nightmare" (1975), and "Nightmare on Elm Street" (1985). He also starred in several films, including "The Rocky Horror Picture Show" (1975) and "Wayne's World" (1992).

Cooper has continued to tour and record music throughout the 2000s and 2010s. He released his most recent album, "Paranormal," in 2017. He is also a successful businessman, and he owns several restaurants and casinos.

Cooper is a Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductee, and he has been awarded a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. He is considered one of the most influential rock singers of all time.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot on March 27, 2023. The rifle was inside a hard rifle case and was secured to a truck safe with padlocks and chains. Police believe the thief stole the rifle by breaking the rear right passenger-side window, tying a rope around the rifle case's handle or a cable lock, and using the momentum from another vehicle to then break the case's handle free from the lock. The window frame of the agent's car was pulled from the door, which police believe could indicate the large case was ripped through the shattered window. The FBI agent also reported that his gear bag, backpack, and some clothing and tools were also stolen during the theft. Officers found two skid marks and pieces of rope lying on the pavement near the car, as well as the broken-off handle of the rifle case. The agent's bags and some of his clothing were found at a Residence Inn across the street, but the sniper rifle has not been recovered. The hotel does not have surveillance cameras. Salt Lake City police said the rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer. The Secret Service told Fox 13 Salt Lake City the agency was notified about the stolen rifle before President Obama's visit to Utah earlier this month, but could not comment if the theft prompted an increase of security. Det. McGowan said police do not know if the thief specifically targeted the agent's car.

A sea mine was found in the River Clyde near Gourock, Scotland. An area of the town near the swimming pool was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon. Other residents close by had been advised to open windows, stay indoors near walls and to avoid going outside. An exclusion zone remains in force on the river while experts make safe the mine. It is thought to be a British mine, dating from the 1940s or 1950s. The evacuation affected three streets, with wider safety advice issued to residents within 500m of the device. There was also an exclusion zone at sea of about half a mile, and small boat owners were told not to sail during the operation. Caledonian MacBrayne reported some disruption to ferry services, affecting sailings from Gourock and Rothesay. Ch Insp Elliot Brown, the local area commander for Inverclyde, stressed that the evacuation had been a precautionary measure, and that there was no immediate danger to the community of Gourock. Lt Cdr Tim Castrinoyannakis, the officer in charge of the Royal Navy's Northern Diving Unit, said that due to the deterioration of the mine it was not possible to conclude how much explosive material it still contained. He said that because of this it was decided to move it to a safer place before dealing with it. Inverclyde Council said: "Thanks to residents and businesses in Gourock for their patience while the cordon and safe evacuation procedures were carried out today."

Andrew Kevin Walker (born August 14, 1964) is an American screenwriter. He is best known for writing the screenplays for the films Seven (1995), The Usual Suspects (1995), and Sleepy Hollow (1999). He has also written the screenplays for the films 8mm (1999), The Cell (2000), and Domino (2005).

Walker was born in New York City, New York. He attended the University of Southern California, where he studied film and television. After graduating, he moved to Los Angeles to pursue a career in screenwriting.

Walker's first major screenwriting credit was for the 1995 film Seven. The film was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $327 million worldwide. Walker was nominated for a BAFTA Award for Best Original Screenplay for his work on the film.

Walker's next major screenwriting credit was for the 1995 film The Usual Suspects. The film was also a critical and commercial success, grossing over $273 million worldwide. Walker was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay for his work on the film.

Walker's other screenwriting credits include 8mm (1999), The Cell (2000), Domino (2005), and Sleepy Hollow (1999). He is currently working on the screenplay for the film The Night House.

Walker is a talented screenwriter who has written some of the most successful and critically acclaimed films of the past 25 years. He is a two-time BAFTA nominee and a one-time Academy Award nominee.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, has left the authority by "mutual agreement" after a major error in the electoral register meant that thousands of voters were turned away from polling stations on election day.

An independent investigation has been launched into the problems, which affected voters across the borough.

In a statement issued through the council, Mr Travers said: "I have enjoyed my time at Barnet and I believe the changes we have put in place and the continued programme of growth and transformation will enable the borough to continue to thrive."

A council spokesperson said Mr Travers had "made a valuable contribution to the council during his three and half years as chief executive."

Deputy chief executive John Hooton will take over temporarily while longer term arrangements are put in place, the council said.

On election day, staff at one station said just three of the first 30 voters to show up were on the register. The rest were told to come back later.

Barnet Council apologised for the problems and later offered emergency proxy votes to residents who had been affected.

But voters in the area questioned how the result could be "fair" when not everyone was able to have their say at the ballot box.

A statement released by Mr Travers on Thursday blamed electoral registration lists for the problems.

The council's review will conclude by the end of May and the findings will be presented publicly to the General Functions Committee.

It will look at the "appropriateness" of arrangements in place for the EU Referendum in June.

A spokesman said it was currently in discussions to establish who would lead the investigation.

Angela Bassett is an American actress. She began her film career in the mid-1980s, after earning a bachelor of arts degree from Yale University and a master of fine arts degree from drama school. Angelsberg is a small town in the commune of Fischbach, in central Luxembourg. It is located in the canton of Mersch, about 10 kilometers (6.2 mi) south of the capital, Luxembourg City. The town has a population of about 1,000 people.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpiper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud after playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner draped on his bagpipes in April 2015. He was cleared of two other counts of fraud.

Carpenter, who has played in the city centre for more than 30 years, denied the charges. He said he had piped for the charity in the past but on this occasion he was simply busking.

Kenneth Derbyshire, chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, said he had given Carpenter permission to design and display a banner featuring the eternal flame and the word justice. But he said he had made it clear he was not use it to collect funds for the charity.

Carpenter told the court the banner was a tribute to the victims, not an attempt to deceive anyone. He also told the court he was a familiar face on match days at Anfield and known as a busker to the Hillsborough Justice Campaign.

He will be sentenced in January.

Aristotle was a Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice, on the northern periphery of Classical Greece. His father, Nicomachus, died when Aristotle was a child, whereupon Proxenus of Atarneus became his guardian. At eighteen, he joined Plato's Academy in Athens and remained there until the age of thirty-seven (c. 347 BC). Shortly after Plato died, Aristotle left Athens and, at the request of Philip II of Macedon, tutored Alexander the Great beginning in 343 BC.

Aristotle founded his own school in Athens, the Lyceum, in 335 BC. He died in Chalcis in 322 BC. Aristotle's writings cover many subjects including physics, biology, zoology, metaphysics, logic, ethics, esthetics, poetry, theater, music, rhetoric, psychology, linguistics, economics, politics, meteorology, geology and government. Aristotle provided a complex synthesis of the various philosophies existing prior to him. It was above all from his teachings that the West inherited its intellectual lexicon, as well as problems and methods of inquiry. As a result, his philosophy has exerted a unique influence on almost every form of knowledge in the West and it continues to be a subject of contemporary philosophical discussion.

Aristotle's views on natural science profoundly shaped medieval scholarship. Their influence extended into the Renaissance and were revived during the Scientific Revolution of the 16th and 17th centuries. In the 19th century, Aristotle's ideas were adopted by some German philosophers. This revived interest led to the "Aristotelian revival" of the early 20th century.

Arizona is the 6th largest and 14th most populous of the 50 states in the United States. It is the 48th state and last of the contiguous states to be admitted to the Union, achieving statehood on February 14, 1912. About one-quarter of the state is made up of Indian reservations that serve as the home of 27 federally recognized Native American tribes, including the Navajo Nation, the largest in the state and the United States, with more than 300,000 citizens. Arizona is known for its high population of Native Americans.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is happy that Alexis Sanchez chose to join the Gunners over Liverpool last summer. He believes Sanchez's quick adaptation to English football proves he is one of the best players around. Wenger also played down speculation linking Arsenal with a summer move for Liverpool forward Raheem Sterling.

Wenger said: "At the end of the day, only Sanchez can explain to you why he has chosen us. I don't know why he did that, but we are happy that he made that decision."

"I was (aware of Liverpool's interest), but you never know if it is really true, but I thought it could be because of the interest in Suarez (from Barcelona)."

"In the negotiations, yes, it is a strength - and it makes sense, an exchange and some money for Liverpool."

Wenger believes Sanchez's quick adaptation to English football proves he is one of the best players around.

"If you look at the qualities, efficiency, work-rate, fighting spirit - (he is at the) top," the Arsenal boss added.

"When it (the game) becomes flat, he can revitalise the strengths and dynamics of the team and the supporters."

Ahead of the key Barclays Premier League clash, Wenger was keen to play down any talk of a potential summer transfer move for Liverpool forward Raheem Sterling, who has so far rejected a new contract offer.

Despite the Reds having lost to Manchester United before the international break to dent hopes of another top-four finish, Wenger has been impressed by the way Brendan Rodgers has developed his team following the sale of Luis Suarez and injury to striker Daniel Sturridge.

"He has done very well. I think he found a solution at the right time," the Arsenal manager said.

"They did well last season too, they scored over 100 goals in the Premier League, which is absolutely fantastic."

Mesut Ozil is a German professional footballer who plays as an attacking midfielder for Premier League club Arsenal and the Germany national team. He is known for his creativity, passing, and vision.

Ozil began his senior career with Schalke 04, making his debut in 2006. He then moved to Werder Bremen in 2008, where he won the DFB-Pokal in 2009. In 2010, Ozil signed for Real Madrid for a fee of €15 million. He won the La Liga title in 2012 and the Copa del Rey in 2011 and 2014.

In 2013, Ozil signed for Arsenal for a fee of £42.5 million. He has since won the FA Cup in 2014 and 2015.

Ozil has made over 100 appearances for Germany, scoring 23 goals. He was a member of the German squad that won the 2014 FIFA World Cup.

Artpop is the third studio album by American singer Lady Gaga. It was released on November 11, 2013, by Interscope Records. The album was preceded by the release of the singles "Applause" and "Do What U Want". Artpop received generally mixed reviews from music critics, but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies, becoming Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the United States. The album has sold over 2.3 million copies worldwide.

Artpop is a concept album that explores themes of art, pop culture, and technology. The album's sound has been described as a departure from Gaga's previous work, incorporating elements of electronic dance music, pop, and R&B. The album's production was handled by a variety of producers, including RedOne, Fernando Garibay, DJ White Shadow, and Zedd.

Artpop was supported by the ArtRave: The Artpop Ball, a worldwide concert tour that began in May 2014 and ended in August 2014. The tour was a commercial success, grossing over $80 million.

Artpop has been nominated for two Grammy Awards: Best Pop Vocal Album and Best Pop Solo Performance for "Applause". The album was also nominated for a Brit Award for International Female Solo Artist.

In 2015, Artpop was reissued as Artpop: The Remix, which includes remixes of the album's songs by various artists. The reissue was a commercial failure, failing to chart in the United States.

Despite its mixed critical reception, Artpop has been praised by some critics for its innovative sound and concept. The album has also been credited with helping to popularize electronic dance music in the mainstream.

Ashton Kutcher is an American actor, producer, and entrepreneur. Kutcher has also starred in several romantic comedies, including Guess Who (2005), A Lot Like Love (2005), What Happens in Vegas (2008), and No Strings Attached (2011).

In 1998, he was cast in the role of Michael Kelso on the Fox sitcom That '70s Show. The show was a critical and commercial success, running for eight seasons from 1998 to 2006.

In 2003, Kutcher starred in the comedy film Dude, Where's My Car?. The film was a box office success, grossing over $240 million worldwide. Kutcher followed this with the romantic comedy Just Married (2003), and the science fiction thriller The Butterfly Effect (2004).

In 2005, Kutcher starred in the romantic comedy Guess Who. The film was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $173 million worldwide. Kutcher followed this with the romantic comedy A Lot Like Love (2005), and the comedy film What Happens in Vegas (2008).

In 2011, Kutcher starred in the romantic comedy No Strings Attached. The film was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $140 million worldwide. Kutcher followed this with the action comedy The Spy Who Dumped Me (2018), and the romantic comedy The Beach Bum (2019).

Kutcher is also a successful entrepreneur. In 2003, he co-founded the venture capital firm A-Grade Investments. In 2010, he co-founded the social media company Ooma. In 2013, he co-founded the investment firm Sound Ventures.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, launched his party's manifesto for the 2017 Northern Ireland Assembly election on 22 February 2017. In his speech, he said that the election was a referendum on how the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle was handled, and that the focus had now turned on the Ulster Unionists following his comments about transferring votes to the SDLP.

Nesbitt was asked about the decision of his senior party colleague Danny Kennedy to publicly distance himself from the remarks. He turned to Kennedy, who was sitting behind him on the platform, and said: "It wasn't disappointing, it was actually quite reaffirming to know Danny was listening." The line brought laughter from other candidates and party members.

Under questioning from journalists, Nesbitt denied that he had any regrets or that he had made a mistake. "What I have said consistently is vote Ulster Unionists and then for any candidate that you believe will do the right thing within your community, within your constituency and within the country," he said. He added that he "wouldn't withdraw a word" of what he had said and was thinking only of what what would happen after the election.

"The fact is, if we are going into [Stormont] Castle, it will be with a nationalist party," he said. "Now, would I rather go in with Sinn Féin or the SDLP? I would rather go in with the SDLP."

Nesbitt went on to say that, on Monday, he spent a lot of time time knocking doors in heavily unionist areas with "very little criticism and a lot of support for what I was talking about".

"I am confident in my position and I'm very confident and relaxed that [candidates] behind me are taking different positions in terms of vote transfer," he said. "But people will come back on 2 March to thinking about the £85,000 a day that is going up in smoke, the 10 years of the DUP and Sinn Féin in that castle and the impossibility, no matter what anybody writes in a platform piece for the newspaper, of leopards changing their spots."

The manifesto, entitled 'Real Partnership', includes calls for action in tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritising the York Street interchange, standing up for the LGBT community and "guaranteeing" that no group is worse off because of Brexit. In a section entitled 'Cleaning Up Stormont', the party calls for:

* A new code of conduct for MLAs
* A new independent complaints and standards body
* A new independent electoral commission
* A new independent public appointments commission

On the theme of the election being a referendum, he said it was about "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption". He must hope that message will resonate more strongly than the continuing controversy over his remarks about transferring to the SDLP.

Audioslave was an American rock supergroup formed in Los Angeles, California, in 2001. The band consisted of Soundgarden lead singer and rhythm guitarist Chris Cornell, and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass and backing vocals), and Brad Wilk (drums). The band released three studio albums, Audioslave (2002), Out of Exile (2005), and Revelations (2006), before disbanding in 2007.

Audioslave was formed in 2001 after the breakup of Soundgarden and Rage Against the Machine. Cornell and Morello had been friends for years, and they had previously collaborated on a number of projects, including the song "Like a Stone" for the soundtrack of the film The Matrix. Commerford and Wilk were also friends, and they had played together in Rage Against the Machine.

The band's self-titled debut album was released in 2002 and was a commercial success, reaching number one on the Billboard 200 chart. The album spawned the hit singles "Cochise", "Show Me How to Live", and "Like a Stone".

Audioslave's second album, Out of Exile, was released in 2005 and was also a commercial success, reaching number one on the Billboard 200 chart. The album spawned the hit singles "Be Yourself", "Like a Stone", and "Show Me How to Live".

The band's third and final album, Revelations, was released in 2006 and was a commercial disappointment, reaching number five on the Billboard 200 chart. The album spawned the hit singles "Crowded Places" and "Revelations".

Audioslave disbanded in 2007 after Cornell left the band. The band's members have since reunited with their former bands, with Cornell rejoining Soundgarden and Morello, Commerford, and Wilk rejoining Rage Against the Machine.

In 2017, Audioslave reunited for a one-off performance at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony. The band was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2017.

Australia is a 2008 epic historical drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann and written by Luhrmann and Stuart Beattie. The film stars Nicole Kidman, Hugh Jackman, David Wenham, and Geoffrey Rush. The film is set in Australia in the 1930s and tells the story of Lady Sarah Ashley (Kidman), a British aristocrat who inherits a cattle ranch in the Northern Territory after her husband's death. She must learn to manage the ranch and deal with the harsh Australian landscape and the local Aboriginal people. She also falls in love with Drover (Jackman), a local man who helps her to manage the ranch.

The film was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $211 million worldwide. It was nominated for 10 Academy Awards, including Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Actress for Kidman.

The film was shot on location in Australia, including Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen. The production was a major undertaking, with over 1,000 cast and crew members. The film was also a visual feast, with stunning cinematography of the Australian landscape.

Australia is a sweeping epic that tells a powerful story of love, loss, and redemption. It is a must-see for fans of Luhrmann's work and anyone who loves a good story.

The use of tablet computers in schools is on the rise, but there is no clear evidence that they improve academic performance. However, there is some evidence that they can help to motivate pupils and increase family involvement. Tablets are also becoming increasingly popular among young people, and many take them to bed to continue social media conversations.

A study by the Family, Kids and Youth research group found that 68% of primary schools and 69% of secondary schools are now using tablet computers, at least to some extent. In 9% of schools, every pupil has their own tablet device. The highest use of tablet computers is within academy schools, much greater than in independent schools or other types of state schools.

The study's author, Dr Barbie Clarke, says it is not possible to make a definitive connection between tablet computers and improved results. However, she says head teachers reported a positive impact, and there is evidence that they help to motivate pupils who might otherwise be disengaged.

Dr Clarke says that the role of technology is going to grow in schools. "The type of device might change, but it's not going to go away. It will almost seem ridiculous if some of them are not using technology," she said.

A separate study from the National Literacy Trust and Pearson suggested that touch-screen computers were particularly useful in helping boys and poorer pupils to learn to read. It showed children in poorer households were particularly likely to read on touch-screen computers rather than printed books.

The study on tablet computers in schools shows how much online technology is part of everyday life for young people. Within a sample of schools where every pupil has a tablet computer, a quarter of secondary pupils described themselves as internet "addicts". About two-thirds took a computer device or smartphone to bed with them, used for social media or watching videos.

Findings earlier this year from Ofcom show how tablets have spread quickly within families with children. It showed about 70% of five to 15-year-olds had access to a tablet at home.

Simon Mason, head of Honywood Community School in Essex, said it was not possible to say whether results are changed by any individual factor, but he is a strong advocate of tablet computers in schools. Each pupil has an iPad, which remains the property of the school, but pupils can take them home. Using these computers, he says, is about making sure that the school is in "the current century and not the last". The benefits are "difficult to put into league tables", he says. But they create a "sense of empowerment" for young people and create an ethos in which pupils can feel "trusted and valued". Tablets are preferable to laptops, he argues, more portable, the right size, touch-screen and immediately switched on. The head says that the use of technology in school also reflects the reality of how pupils live at home and what they will find at work. "I think it's really important that schools function in the way that the world is," said Mr Mason.

Canadian folklore is a diverse and rich tradition that includes songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and practices such as traditional food-making and craft-making. Folklore is passed down through generations, often orally, and can be a valuable source of information about a culture's history and values.

Some of the most well-known Canadian folktales include the story of Paul Bunyan, the giant lumberjack, and the tale of the Wendigo, a cannibalistic monster. There are also many regional folktales, such as the story of the Headless Horseman of Ontario and the tale of the Bluenose ghost ship.

Canadian folklore is also rich in proverbs and sayings, such as "No man is an island" and "A penny saved is a penny earned." These proverbs reflect the values and beliefs of Canadians, and they are often used in everyday speech.

Weather lore is another important part of Canadian folklore. There are many sayings about the weather, such as "Red sky at night, sailor's delight" and "A robin in the spring is worth a king." These sayings are based on people's observations of the natural world, and they are often used to predict the weather.

Superstitions are also common in Canadian folklore. Some people believe that it is bad luck to walk under a ladder, while others believe that it is good luck to find a four-leaf clover. Superstitions are often based on fear or ignorance, but they can also be a way of coping with the unknown.

Traditional food-making and craft-making are also important parts of Canadian folklore. Many families have recipes for traditional dishes that have been passed down for generations. There are also many traditional crafts, such as quilting and rug hooking, that are still practiced today.

Canadian folklore is a rich and diverse tradition that reflects the country's history and culture. It is a valuable source of information about the past, and it continues to be an important part of Canadian life today.

Cuadrilla Resources has suspended fracking operations at its Preese Hall site in Lancashire after a 1.5 magnitude earthquake. The tremor, which was felt by at least one person, occurred on Friday 13 May 2022.

The BGS said the earthquake was "felt by at least one person in Poulton-Le-Fylde". "Our analysis places the epicentre of the event to within 2km of the Preese Hall site," Dr Brian Baptie, head of seismology at the BGS, said. "Data from two temporary instruments close to the drill site, installed after the magnitude 2.3 earthquake on 1 April, indicate that the event occurred at a depth of approximately 2km (1.2 miles)."

The BGS said the recorded waveforms are very similar to those from the magnitude 2.3 event last month, which suggests that the two events share a similar location and mechanism.

Cuadrilla said it was taking the "responsibilities very seriously" and that it had stopped fracking operations to share information and consult with the relevant authorities and other experts. "We expect that this analysis and subsequent consultation will take a number of weeks to conclude and we will decide on appropriate actions after that," Mark Miller, chief executive of Cuadrilla Resources, said.

Shale gas drilling, known as "fracking", involves shattering hard shale rocks underground to release gas using either hydraulic pressure or tiny explosions. The process has proved controversial in the US with environmentalists alleging that shale gas leaking into their drinking supply could cause tap water to ignite. But earlier this month the Commons energy select committee called on ministers to support the process in the UK arguing that environmental problems associated with it in the US could be overcome by tight regulation and good industry practice.

The BGS said it was also monitoring fracking as a precaution. There have been two small earthquakes in Lancashire since fracking began in the county in March, including the latest on Friday.

The Arctic Convoys were a series of British and Allied merchant ships that sailed from Britain to northern Russia during World War II to resupply the Soviet Union. The convoys were constantly under threat from German U-boats and aircraft, and the harsh conditions of the Arctic Ocean made the journey even more perilous. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, and thousands of Allied seamen had lost their lives.

In 2012, the Russian Embassy wrote to survivors of the Arctic Convoys that it intended to award them with the Medal of Ushakov, a Russian military decoration awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in the course of defending Russia or its interests. However, the Foreign Office initially blocked the move, as its rules stated that British soldiers could not receive a foreign medal if the act happened more than five years ago.

The British Government created the Arctic Star in 2012 following a long campaign for the convoy veterans to be recognised. However, campaigners believed veterans should still be able to receive the Russian accolade. The Foreign Office allowed an "exception to the rules" last year and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals during his visit to London on 16 June 2013.

The Ushakov medal was presented to 26 British veterans of the Arctic Convoys at a ceremony in London on 25 February 2014. The ceremony was attended by Defence Attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko, Minister-Councillor Alexander Kramarenko from the Russian Embassy, and Able seaman Charles Lewis, 91, from Calmore, Hampshire, who was one of the veterans receiving the medal.

In his speech at the ceremony, Capt Kornienko said: "It [the ceremony] is done for them because they have been expecting for a very long time to be recognized. "It is done for us as it was important for us. "The arctic convoy was a material expression of our wartime alliance and they provided weapons and ammunition that armed us to defeat the Germans on the Eastern front. "We and Britain were in it together."

Able seaman Lewis said: "I certainly don't see myself as a hero - far from it - and I think all my friends and colleagues, many of whom sadly are no longer with us, would regard us as simply doing our bit for the war effort. "Although I have to say that Churchill's famous quote about the Arctic convoys' missions through the North Sea in winter as being 'the worst journey on earth' did strike a chord  - then and now."

Syria missed a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile of chemical weapons on Wednesday, 27 February 2014. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad said a shipment of weapons came under attack twice on its way from Damascus to the port of Latakia. He added that Syria is in war, and the Americans and others have to take this into consideration.

The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims 246 people, including 73 children, have been killed in Aleppo in the last five days alone after barrels containing explosives and metal fragments were dropped by military helicopters. Mr Mekdad insisted that Syria is defending its people against terrorist attacks. He accused the US of "still supporting terrorist elements" in the country.

The Syrian government, via state media, also denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said members of the Islamic Front coalition, dominated by the Ahrar al-Sham brigade and the al-Qaeda affiliate al-Nusra Front, mounted the assault, freeing hundreds of detainees. But state television insisted soldiers and security forces had "thwarted an attack against the prison by terrorist groups".

The Observatory says fighting is still going on, but the Ahrar al-Sham brigade and the Aleppo Media Centre, a citizen-journalist outlet, say rebels now completely control the prison. It is reported to hold at least 3,000 detainees, including Islamists, activists and minors, in horrific conditions.

Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons. The US said last week that so far only about 4% of the stockpile - 30 tonnes - had left the country. US Defence Secretary Chuck Hagel said he was "concerned" that the UN-backed plan was falling behind schedule and said Damascus "had to take responsibility for fulfilling its commitment".

Russia - a key ally of Syria - has said Damascus should complete the transfer of its chemical weapons to the coast for removal by ship by 1 March. A deadline was set last year for all the weapons to be destroyed by the end of June. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), which is overseeing the destruction operation, has admitted the process has been slowed down by security concerns.

Mr Mekdad stressed: "Syria is committed to all its agreements, with the OPCW and the UN Security Council. We shall implement on time all our obligations."

Despacito is a song by Puerto Rican singer Luis Fonsi and Puerto Rican rapper Daddy Yankee. It was released on January 12, 2017, as the lead single from Fonsi's fifth studio album, Vida (2018). The song was written by Fonsi, Daddy Yankee, Erika Ender, and Mauricio Rengifo and Andrés Torres. It is a Latin pop and reggaeton song with lyrics about a man who is trying to seduce a woman.

Despacito was a commercial success, reaching number one in over 40 countries, including the United States, where it became the longest-running number-one single of all time on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. It is also the most-streamed song of all time on Spotify and YouTube.

The song has been remixed several times, including a version with American singer Justin Bieber. The remix was released on April 17, 2017, and became even more successful than the original version, reaching number one in the United States and several other countries.

Despacito has been praised by critics for its catchy melody and danceable rhythm. It has also been credited with popularizing Latin music in the United States and around the world.

Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge (DDLJ) is a 1995 Indian Hindi-language romantic comedy film directed by Aditya Chopra in his directorial debut. It stars Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, with Amrish Puri, Farida Jalal, Anupam Kher, and Mandira Bedi in supporting roles. The film tells the story of Raj and Simran, two young people who fall in love while on vacation in Europe. However, their families disapprove of their relationship, and they must overcome many obstacles in order to be together.

DDLJ was a major commercial success, becoming the highest-grossing Indian film of 1995 and the highest-grossing Indian film of all time until it was surpassed by Hum Aapke Hain Koun..! in 1997. It was also a critical success, winning several awards, including the Filmfare Award for Best Film. The film is considered to be one of the most popular and influential Bollywood films of all time.

The film was shot in India, London, and Switzerland from September 1994 to August 1995. The song "Tujhe Dekha Toh Yeh Jaana Sanam" was shot at the Eiffel Tower in Paris. The song "Le Jayenge Le Jayenge" was shot at the Matterhorn in Switzerland.

The film was released on 20 October 1995. It was a major commercial success, grossing over ₹1.3 billion (US$17 million) worldwide. It was also a critical success, winning several awards, including the Filmfare Award for Best Film.

The film is considered to be one of the most popular and influential Bollywood films of all time. It has been remade in several languages, including Telugu, Tamil, Kannada, Malayalam, and Bengali. It has also been adapted into a stage musical.

Don't Say No is the debut extended play by South Korean singer Seohyun. It was released on January 17, 2017, by SM Entertainment. The EP consists of six tracks, including the lead single "Don't Say No".

Seohyun is a South Korean singer and actress. She debuted as a member of girl group Girls' Generation in August 2007. She has also established herself as an actress, notably through her participation in the original and Korean versions of stage musicals including Moon Embracing the Sun, Gone with the Wind and Mamma Mia.

Don't Say No was a commercial success, debuting at number one on the Gaon Album Chart and selling over 100,000 copies in its first week. The EP also topped the charts in Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Singapore.

The lead single, "Don't Say No", was a moderate success, peaking at number 10 on the Gaon Digital Chart. The song was also a commercial success in Japan, where it reached number 10 on the Oricon Singles Chart.

Don't Say No was well-received by critics. The EP was praised for its mature and sophisticated sound. Seohyun's vocals were also praised, with many critics calling her one of the best vocalists in K-pop.

Don't Say No was a successful debut for Seohyun. The EP showed that she is a talented singer and actress with a bright future ahead of her.

Domenico Scala, who heads up Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian - as is Gianni Infantino, one of the five presidential candidates. Scala excused himself from the 2015 elections as he shared nationality with a candidate, Swiss Sepp Blatter. LFA boss Musa Bility says he will go to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. The battle to replace long-standing president Blatter takes place in 18 days' time.

"Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations is clear that any member of the Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee who has a conflict of interest … is thereby barred from sitting as a member of the Committee and must be replaced," Bility wrote in a letter to Scala on Monday. Ahead of elections in May 2015 between Blatter and Prince Ali of Jordan - both Scala and Claudio Sulser, who was also on the Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, stepped aside for this reason.

"Prior to the final review process, Domenico Scala (as a dual Swiss/Italian national) and Claudio Sulser (as a Swiss national) withdrew from their positions to avoid any appearance of a potential conflict of interest based on nationality," Fifa wrote at the time. However Andreas Bantel, a spokesman for Scala, says "the fact that a member of the ad-hoc electoral committee has the same nationality as a candidate does not result in a conflict of interest.

"There is no such provision whatsoever in the relevant regulations of Fifa," he told BBC Sport. "For the last election period Mr Scala withdrew because the Swiss candidate was the incumbent President. Scala did so in order to avoid even any appearance of a potential conflicted of interest situation and simply as a precautionary measure on a voluntary base.

"For this election there are five candidates with no incumbent President. Hence, there is no potential conflict of interest at all." It remains to be seen whether Bility will go ahead with his threat to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. In his letter to Scala, he wants to know why the same process has not been followed ahead of the 26 February election.

"Following an unprecedented period of sustained turmoil and damage for Fifa as an institution, the fairness and integrity of the current electoral process are absolutely vital for Fifa," Bility wrote. "If we do not receive confirmation from the Fifa Ah-Hoc Electoral Committee within three working days of receipt of this latter that you are stepping down … with immediate effect, the Liberian FA reserves its right to challenge that decision by all available routes." Bility had hoped to participate in the elections himself before being denied by the Electoral Committee in November after failing an eligibility check. On Saturday, the Liberian pledged his vote to Prince Ali while urging his fellow Africans to do the same. Alongside Prince Ali and Infantino, Frenchman Jerome Champagne, Bahrain's Sheikh Salman and South Africa's Tokyo Sexwale are also bidding to replace Blatter as president. The election, which is voted on by Fifa's 209 members, will take place in the organisation's headquarters in the Swiss city Zurich.

In summary, Domenico Scala is the head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee. He is Swiss-Italian, as is one of the five presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino. Scala excused himself from the 2015 elections as he shared nationality with a candidate, Swiss Sepp Blatter. LFA boss Musa Bility says he will go to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. The battle to replace long-standing president Blatter takes place in 18 days' time.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (September 1, 1933 – September 13, 2006) was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. A Democrat, she first came to national attention as the state treasurer of Texas, when she delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995 and was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. Richards was the second female governor of Texas, and was frequently noted in the media for her outspoken feminism and her one-liners.

Ann Richards (October 1, 1935 – April 1, 1982) was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton. She was born in Abilene, Texas, and began singing in church as a child. She moved to Los Angeles in the early 1950s to pursue a career in music. She sang with several big bands, including Stan Kenton's, and released several solo albums. She was also a popular nightclub performer. Richards died of cancer in 1982 at the age of 46.

The UK government is considering selling off high-value social housing to raise money for new social housing. This is a controversial proposal, with some arguing that it would help to reduce the housing crisis, while others argue that it would push low-income families out of expensive areas.

The think tank Policy Exchange has proposed that the government sell off high-value social housing when it becomes vacant. They argue that this would raise £4.5bn a year, which could be used to build 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes.

The government has said that it is considering this proposal, but has not yet made a decision.

Labour has criticized the proposal, saying that it would "drive out hard-working families on low wages from whole neighbourhoods". They argue that the government should instead use a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes.

The National Housing Federation, which represents housing associations, has also criticized the proposal, saying that it would "cleanse" towns of "hardworking people who can't afford to pay high prices".

The government has said that it is committed to providing social housing for those who need it, and that it will continue to invest in affordable housing. However, it is not clear whether the government will decide to sell off high-value social housing.

The proposal to sell off high-value social housing is a controversial one, with strong arguments on both sides. It is likely to be a key issue in the upcoming general election.

Dr. Jack Shephard is the protagonist of the ABC television series Lost. He is a spinal surgeon who was on Oceanic Flight 815 when it crashed on a mysterious island. Jack is a natural leader and is often called upon to make difficult decisions. He is also a skilled surgeon and is able to save many lives on the island. However, Jack is also flawed and makes mistakes. He is often arrogant and does not always listen to others. He also has a drinking problem. Despite his flaws, Jack is a good man who is trying to do the right thing. He is a complex and well-developed character who is one of the reasons Lost is such a popular show.

Lost is an American television drama series that originally aired on the American Broadcasting Company (ABC) from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, over six seasons, comprising a total of 121 episodes. The first season garnered an estimated average of 16 million viewers per episode on ABC. Lost is a story about a group of people who are stranded on a mysterious island after their plane crashes. The show explores themes of survival, faith, and the human condition. Lost was created by J. J. Abrams, Damon Lindelof, and Jeffrey Lieber. The show was produced by ABC Studios, Bad Robot Productions, and Grass Skirt Productions. Lost was a critical and commercial success. The show won numerous awards, including the Golden Globe Award for Best Television Series – Drama and the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Drama Series. Lost is considered to be one of the greatest television shows of all time.

Drake Bell is an American actor, singer, songwriter, and musician. He is best known for his role as Drake Parker on the Nickelodeon television series Drake & Josh. Bell has also released several albums, including It's Only Time (2005), Ready Steady Go! (2006), and A Reminder (2011).

A Reminder is Bell's third studio album, released on October 11, 2011. The album was released independently through Bell's own label, 456 Entertainment. A Reminder was produced by Bell and Josh Abraham. The album features the singles "I Know" and "It's Only Time".

A Reminder received mixed reviews from critics. AllMusic gave the album a positive review, calling it "a solid effort from a talented artist". However, Rolling Stone gave the album a negative review, calling it "a bland and forgettable collection of pop songs".

Despite the mixed reviews, A Reminder was a commercial success. The album debuted at number 10 on the Billboard 200 chart, selling 27,000 copies in its first week. The album has since sold over 100,000 copies in the United States.

A Reminder was supported by a tour of the United States and Canada. The tour began on October 21, 2011 in San Diego, California and ended on December 17, 2011 in Toronto, Ontario.

DreamWorks Animation is an American animation studio that has released 34 feature films, including the franchises Shrek, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls. Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut. It stars Kurt Russell, Dakota Fanning, Kris Kristofferson, and Elisabeth Shue. The film is based on the true story of a retired race horse named Dreamer and his relationship with a young girl named Cale. Dreamer was released in the United States on December 16, 2005.

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising the performances of Russell and Fanning, while others criticized the film's sentimentality. However, the film was a box office success, grossing over $120 million worldwide against its $25 million budget.

Dreamer tells the story of Cale (Dakota Fanning), a young girl who lives on a horse farm with her father, Ben (Kurt Russell). When Ben dies in a car accident, Cale is left to care for the farm and the horses. One of the horses, Dreamer, is a talented race horse who has been injured. Cale decides to train Dreamer to race again, and with the help of Ben's friend, Monty Roberts (Kris Kristofferson), she succeeds. Dreamer wins the Kentucky Derby, and Cale becomes a champion jockey.

Dreamer is a story about overcoming adversity and following your dreams. It is a heartwarming and inspiring film that will stay with you long after you watch it.

Featherstone Rovers have appointed former Swinton Lions coach Paul Duffy as their new head coach. Duffy, 37, has joined the third-placed Championship side on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton. The Scotland assistant coach will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday before the upcoming Super 8 Qualifiers. "He is a fantastic coach and we are very excited to see how his reign here unfolds," chairman Mark Campbell said. "We believe he has done a remarkable job in extremely difficult circumstances at Swinton and he deserves a great deal of credit for his efforts there." Duffy, who played for Leigh, Widnes and Salford during a 16-year playing career, has been replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler at fellow Championship side Swinton.

EA Black Box was a video game developer based in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada. It was founded in 1998 by former employees of Radical Entertainment and later acquired by Electronic Arts (EA) in 2002. EA Black Box was best known for its Need for Speed racing game series, as well as the Skate and Burnout series. The company was closed in 2013.

EA Black Box was founded in 1998 by former employees of Radical Entertainment, a video game developer that was also based in Burnaby, British Columbia. The founders of EA Black Box were all experienced game developers who had worked on a number of successful titles, including the Need for Speed racing game series.

EA Black Box was acquired by Electronic Arts in 2002. EA is one of the largest video game publishers in the world, and the acquisition of EA Black Box gave EA a major presence in the racing game genre.

EA Black Box was best known for its Need for Speed racing game series. The Need for Speed series is one of the most popular racing game series of all time, and it has sold millions of copies worldwide. EA Black Box developed a number of popular Need for Speed games, including Need for Speed Underground, Need for Speed Most Wanted, and Need for Speed Carbon.

EA Black Box also developed the Skate and Burnout series of games. The Skate series is a skateboarding game series, and the Burnout series is a racing game series. Both of these series were popular with gamers, and they helped to establish EA Black Box as a leading developer of racing games.

EA Black Box was closed in 2013. The closure of EA Black Box was part of a larger restructuring effort at EA. EA was facing increasing competition from other video game publishers, and the company decided to focus its resources on its most successful franchises.

The closure of EA Black Box was a major loss for the video game industry. EA Black Box was a talented developer that had created some of the most popular racing games of all time. The closure of EA Black Box left a void in the racing game genre, and it is unlikely that any other developer will be able to fill that void in the near future.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka. The film is a modern retelling of Nathaniel Hawthorne's The Scarlet Letter, set in a contemporary American high school.

Stone plays Olive Penderghast, a high school student who decides to start a rumor that she is sexually active in order to improve her social standing. The rumor quickly spreads, and Olive finds herself caught up in a web of lies and deceit.

Easy A was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $90 million worldwide. The film was praised for its humor, its sharp social commentary, and Stone's performance. It was nominated for two MTV Movie Awards, for Best Female Performance and Best Kiss (for Stone and Penn Badgley).

The film's title is a reference to the scarlet letter "A" that is sewn onto the chest of Hester Prynne, the protagonist of The Scarlet Letter. The letter "A" stands for "adultery," and it is a symbol of Hester's sin. In Easy A, Olive is also given the letter "A," but it stands for "asexual." This is a reference to the fact that Olive is not sexually active, despite the rumors that circulate about her.

The film's plot is similar to that of The Scarlet Letter in that both stories involve a young woman who is ostracized by her community because of her sexual behavior. However, Easy A is a more modern and humorous take on the classic story. The film also explores themes of social media, peer pressure, and the importance of being true to oneself.

Easy A is a well-made and entertaining film that is sure to appeal to a wide audience. It is a funny, thought-provoking, and ultimately empowering story about a young woman who learns to stand up for herself and be true to who she is.

Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon after the Italian goalkeeper won his 147th cap, calling him a "legend of the game". Hart, who won his 50th cap for England in the same match, said he was inspired by Buffon and wanted to continue playing for his country for many years to come.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The Young Lions are the defending champions, having beaten Holland on penalties in the final last year, and progressed to this edition with a 100 per cent record in qualifying. They have been placed in Group D alongside Holland, Italy and the Republic of Ireland this time around and will open their campaign against Italy in Burgas on May 7.

The squad contains talented young players from a host of Premier League clubs including Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo of Chelsea and the Arsenal duo Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, who is called up for the first time. Liverpool pair Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have earned a recall after missing the Elite Round of qualifiers last month, in which England beat Romania, Norway and Slovenia to reach the finals. Esteban Cambiasso is a professional footballer who plays for Leicester City. He has won all the major European competitions a player can during his illustrious career. He is currently seven points adrift at the bottom of the table, with only eight games remaining, knowing that time is running out to save themselves. Cambiasso refuses to give up and admits that keeping Leicester up will feel like winning a trophy. He had an illustrious career at Inter Milan, winning an impressive 15 trophies during his stint. Having not won a game since January, Nigel Pearson's men face West Ham United on Saturday and Cambiasso is still convinced they can avoid the drop. The former Inter Milan star signed for the Foxes in the summer, leaving Italy after ten years and embarking on a new challenge in England. After agreeing to a one-year-deal, Cambiasso has quickly established himself as a key player but it remains to be seen if he'll still be in the East Midlands at the start of next season. Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley after he missed a penalty in their 1-0 win over Burnley.
