Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed and produced by Alfred Hitchcock, and written by Jay Presson Allen. It stars Tippi Hedren, Sean Connery, Diane Baker, and Martin Balsam. The film is about a young woman with a mysterious past who becomes involved with a wealthy businessman.

Marnie is a complex and disturbing film that explores themes of identity, sexuality, and violence. It is considered one of Hitchcock's best films, and Hedren's performance is particularly acclaimed.

The film opens with Marnie (Tippi Hedren) robbing a bank. She is caught and arrested, but she is released when her employer, Mark Rutland (Sean Connery), bails her out. Mark is a wealthy businessman who is attracted to Marnie, and he proposes to her. Marnie accepts, and they are married.

After their wedding, Mark takes Marnie to his home in Bodega Bay, California. Marnie is initially happy in her new life, but she soon begins to have nightmares about her childhood. She also becomes increasingly withdrawn and secretive.

One day, Mark discovers that Marnie has been stealing money from him. He confronts her, and she confesses that she has been stealing since she was a child. She tells him that she is afraid of red, and that she has a recurring nightmare about a man who is trying to kill her.

Mark is determined to help Marnie, and he takes her to see a psychiatrist. The psychiatrist tells Mark that Marnie's fear of red is a symbol of her fear of sex. He also tells Mark that Marnie was abused as a child by her father.

Mark is shocked by this revelation, but he is determined to help Marnie. He takes her to see her father, and he confronts him about the abuse. Marnie's father denies the abuse, but Mark is convinced that he is lying.

Mark and Marnie eventually confront Marnie's father, and he confesses to the abuse. Marnie is finally able to confront her fears, and she begins to heal.

Marnie is a powerful and disturbing film that explores the themes of identity, sexuality, and violence. It is considered one of Hitchcock's best films, and Hedren's performance is particularly acclaimed.

Martin Van Buren was the eighth president of the United States. He served from 1837 to 1841. He was a member of the Democratic Party. He was born in Kinderhook, New York, on December 5, 1782. He died in Kinderhook on July 24, 1862.

Van Buren was a lawyer and politician. He served in the New York State Senate from 1812 to 1820. He was the governor of New York from 1829 to 1832. He was the vice president of the United States from 1833 to 1837. He was the president of the United States from 1837 to 1841.

Van Buren was a strong supporter of Andrew Jackson. He was known as the "Little Magician" because of his political skills. He was the first president to be born in the United States after the American Revolution. He was the first president to be born in New York. He was the first president to be a member of the Democratic Party.

Van Buren's presidency was marked by the Panic of 1837. The Panic of 1837 was a financial crisis that caused a severe recession. Van Buren's response to the Panic of 1837 was not popular. He was defeated for re-election in 1840 by William Henry Harrison.

After his presidency, Van Buren served as the United States minister to Great Britain from 1831 to 1832. He also served as the United States minister to the Netherlands from 1839 to 1841. He was the United States minister to France from 1842 to 1845.

Van Buren was a controversial figure. He was a strong supporter of slavery. He was also a strong supporter of states' rights. He was opposed to the expansion of the United States into new territories.

Van Buren was a complex and fascinating figure. He was a skilled politician who played a major role in the development of the Democratic Party. He was also a controversial figure who was opposed to the expansion of the United States and the abolition of slavery.

Mary of Teck was the Queen consort of the United Kingdom and the Dominions of the British Commonwealth from 1910 until her death in 1953. She was the wife of King George V and the mother of King Edward VIII, King George VI, and Queen Elizabeth II.

Mary was born in 1867 in London, the daughter of Francis, Duke of Teck, and Princess Mary Adelaide of Cambridge. She was educated privately and showed an early interest in music and art. In 1893, she married Prince Albert Victor, Duke of Clarence, the eldest son of King Edward VII and Queen Alexandra. Albert Victor died suddenly in 1892, and Mary became a widow at the age of 25.

In 1901, Mary's brother-in-law, King Edward VII, died, and her husband's younger brother, George, ascended the throne as King George V. Mary became queen consort, and she played an active role in public life. She was involved in a number of charities and organizations, and she also supported her husband in his duties as king.

After George V's death in 1936, Mary's eldest son, Edward VIII, ascended the throne. However, Edward abdicated the throne later that year in order to marry twice-divorced American socialite Wallis Simpson. Mary's second son, Albert, succeeded to the throne as King George VI. Mary supported her son during his reign, and she was a popular figure with the British public.

Mary died in 1953, at the age of 85. She was succeeded by her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.

Matching Models, a London-based temp agency, has been criticized for its job adverts, which have been described as "appalling", "unlawful" and "demeaning to women". The agency's adverts have specified requirements such as "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup" and "a sexy female driver". The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) has said it will be writing to the agency "asking for them to clarify their hiring practices immediately".

The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, has defended the adverts, saying that "our clients are important to us - and looks are important". She has also said that the agency has hired 5,000 people worldwide, including models with tattoos and piercings.

The EHRC's chief executive, Rebecca Hilsenrath, said the adverts were "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women". She said: "It is extraordinary that they are taking this approach and almost certainly falls foul of equality legislation. "If we ever wonder why the battle for gender equality hasn't been won, this is a timely reminder."

Women's equality campaigners have also condemned the adverts. Sam Smethers, chief executive of the Fawcett Society, said: "It is extraordinary that they are taking this approach and almost certainly falls foul of equality legislation. "If we ever wonder why the battle for gender equality hasn't been won, this is a timely reminder."

Employment lawyer James Lynas, partner at Winckworth Sherwood, said the adverts were "clearly unlawful", adding anyone could complain to the EHRC, who have powers to intervene. He said an employment tribunal could find the use of phrases such as "beautiful and attractive" were really code for "young", and in reality discriminatory against older women. He added: "A male driver who genuinely wanted the job could submit an application and sue for sex discrimination if rejected. Compensation for such claims is unlimited. "

A statement on the agency's website states: "It is almost politically incorrect to request someone to work for you that is both attractive as well as professionally equipped with the right set of skills. "However, our company understands the importance of having the right people representing your company, because after all, first impressions count."

But Ms Hilsenrath said: "Matching Models are right about one thing; first impressions count, but the important stuff is not about your hair colour. "If they wish to maintain their reputation, they should act like a business in the 21st Century and consign this type of sexism to the history books."

Under the 2010 Equality Act, it is against the law to say, or imply, that you will discriminate against anyone - including saying that you are unable to cater for disabled workers. Employers are also not allowed to question a candidate's age, sexual orientation, marital status, number of children or plans to have children, disability, race or religion. As for specifying clothing sizes, an employer has to be able to show that it is essential to the nature or context of the work.

Talking about the personal assistant advert, Ms Jansen said: "The client who wants the specific cup size is an older gentleman - he has a specific outfit he designed with Christian Dior. He wants a "Jackie O" look. And he wants a lady with a smaller cup size to fit into the outfit."

"I recently had an Indian businessman who interviewed 60 women from my firm. He wanted a blonde, blue eyed, Greek woman. He hired 6 of them to work on his plane."

Matching Models clients include MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, the Renualt Formula 1 team and Harrods. Ms Jansen said she had hired 5,000 people worldwide and pointed out MTV wanted models with tattoos and piercings.

Luis Suarez has had his four-month ban for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the World Cup reduced to nine competitive international matches.

The Uruguay striker, who has now joined Barcelona, can now train and play in friendly matches.

Suarez's lawyers argued that Fifa's decision to suspend him from all football-related activity was too strong a punishment.

Switzerland-based Cas - an independent body whose rulings are accepted by most sporting organisations - said: "The sanctions imposed on the player by Fifa have been generally confirmed."

But it said preventing Suarez from taking part in any football activity was "excessive", as not allowing him to train would have an impact on the player after the suspension had ended.

World players' union Fifpro said it was "disappointed that the court had decided not to strongly diminish the sanctions" and "remain of the view they are disproportionate in relation to his violation of the Fifa disciplinary code".

It added: "We regret Cas not deciding to reduce the length of Suarez's bans in exchange for an obligation for him to receive treatment."

In addition to being allowed to train and play in friendlies, the former Liverpool player - who moved to Barcelona last month for £75m - can also attend matches and take part in promotional activities.

His legal team said the appeal was a success, arguing Fifa had "misapplied its own rules when considering the case and the sanction it imposed was disproportionate".

Match of the Day presenter Gary Lineker tweeted: "Luis Suarez's appeal against a four-month ban has failed. He is though, sensibly I think, now allowed to train with the team."

"By allowing Suarez to train, Cas appears to have taken into account the club's interests and has emphasised any appropriate sanction for such incidents should be proportionate," said Hannah Clipston, a lawyer specialising in resolving disputes.

"What is proportionate for a repeat offender is different to what is proportionate for a first time offender."

Suarez apologised nearly a week after the incident, despite initially claiming to have lost his balance. He was previously suspended for biting PSV Eindhoven midfielder Otman Bakkal and Chelsea defender Branislav Ivanovic. In 2011, he was also given an eight-match suspension and fined £40,000 for racially abusing Manchester United's Patrice Evra.

Laura Muir, a Scottish middle-distance runner, will not compete in the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies. She finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m at the 2017 World Athletics Championships. Muir says she is "gutted" to miss the Commonwealth Games, but that her studies are a priority. Andy Murray beat Fabio Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 in the third round of Wimbledon on Friday. Murray will play Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday.

Murray looked like avoiding a long, drawn-out contest when he moved ahead early in the third set but a Friday night drama would develop as the light faded. Fognini, 30, showed both his talented and temperamental sides as he got within sight of a fifth set, which would have required the roof to be brought across or both men to return on Saturday.

The Italian, who recently beat Murray on clay in Rome, looked well off the pace when he double-faulted twice in a row to lose the first set, but he began to assert himself in the second. Fognini broke for a second time to lead 3-2 and went on to level at one set all, before firing his 13th baseline winner to just one for Murray by the start of the third set.

At 30-30, Murray was on the defensive and looking increasingly vulnerable, but he clung on with a second serve and the scream of relief jolted him and the Centre Court crowd to life. Across the net, Fognini's challenge was apparently fading, an ankle injury not helping as the errors flowed and the set slipped away.

A gripping fourth set unfolded, with passions rising on and off court as Fognini was penalised a point for a visible obscenity following a gesture, and Murray complaining to the umpire that the Italian was taking too long between points. It was Fognini who took control after Murray double-faulted in game six, but from 5-2 down Murray showed all his fighting qualities to save set points in three consecutive games.

The 15,000 spectators on Centre Court were on their feet as the Briton levelled at 5-5, and Fognini could not halt Murray's momentum as the champion served his way to victory.

"I feel OK," added Murray. "I didn't feel I moved as well as the first couple of matches but I've got a couple of days break now and can work on that and hopefully get myself in a good rhythm and play some good tennis on Monday. "I'm happy to get through the first week and anything can happen from here on."

Steven Gerrard will return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February 2020. He has been linked with the manager's job at League One side MK Dons, but said the opportunity came "too soon" for him. England beat Pakistan by an innings and 225 runs in the second Test at Old Trafford to level the series at 1-1. Scotland beat Georgia 48-11 in the Six Nations Championship on 26 February 2017. Scotland scored five tries, through Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg and Hamish Watson, while Georgia scored two tries, through Vasil Lobzhanidze. Greig Laidlaw converted four tries and kicked two penalties for Scotland, while Merab Kvirikashvili kicked two penalties for Georgia.

Scotland dominated the first half, scoring three tries to lead 24-11 at the break. Seymour opened the scoring for Scotland in the 10th minute, before Lobzhanidze scored Georgia's first try in the 17th minute. Scotland then scored two quick tries, through a penalty try and Maitland, to lead 21-11 at half-time.

Scotland continued to dominate in the second half, scoring two more tries, through Hogg and Watson. Georgia scored a late consolation try through Lobzhanidze, but Scotland ran out comfortable winners.

Scotland's victory was their first in the Six Nations Championship since 2015. They will next play France in Paris on 11 March.

Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson has said that his team is not concerned with the points gap between them and second-placed Manchester City, and that they are only focused on winning their next game. United are 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League table with eight games left to play.

Ferguson also said that he will make changes for Monday's FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea, after seeing Rafael and Anderson suffer injuries at Sunderland, while goalkeeper David De Gea also suffered a knock after a heavy collision with team-mate Nemanja Vidic.

Nico Rosberg won the 2016 Chinese Grand Prix, starting from pole position. His teammate Lewis Hamilton finished fifth after starting from the back of the grid. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel finished second, ahead of team-mate Kimi Räikkönen. Daniel Ricciardo finished fourth for Red Bull, ahead of Daniil Kvyat and Valtteri Bottas.

The race was shaped by an incident-packed opening, with a number of collisions on the first lap leading to the introduction of the safety car on lap four. By that stage, Hamilton and Räikkönen had already pitted once to replace front wings damaged in first-corner collisions.

Räikkönen moved right into Vettel's path as the German moved left to ensure he was not tagged by an aggressive dive down the inside by Kvyat. Hamilton was then turned into by Sauber's Felipe Nasr as he avoided Räikkönen's damaged car swerving back on to the circuit.

Vettel confronted Kvyat about the incident in the pre-podium room after the race, saying: "If I don't go left, you crash into us and we all three go out - you are like a torpedo." Kvyat replied: "We didn't crash." Vettel responded: "You didn't. You were lucky this time." Kvyat shrugged: "I'm on the podium; you're on the podium."

In the post-race interviews, Kvyat added: "You see the gap, you go for it on the inside. You see one car it is hard to see both. It was a risky move, I agree with Seb but you have to take risks and I am on the podium."

At the front, Ricciardo had made a stunning start to take the lead from pole-sitter Rosberg at the first corner. In the process his left-rear wheel had been tagged by Rosberg's front wing. Whether it was that or the debris on the track, Ricciardo suffered a left-rear puncture on lap three, allowing the Mercedes to pass.

Ricciardo would almost certainly not have been able to hold off Rosberg in any case, but his removal from the lead left the German serene out front. Mercedes decided not to stop him under the safety car and when the race re-started on lap nine, Rosberg simply drove off into the distance.

Hamilton, meanwhile, was in the wars. Mercedes stopped him twice under the safety car, doing only one lap on the super-soft tyres in an attempt to ensure he could use only the softs for the rest of the race. So Hamilton had done three stops within the first six laps and he was lying third from last at the restart.

He began his fightback from there, with the Ferraris doing the same - Vettel starting from 11th and Räikkönen not far behind Hamilton, who said his progress had been affected by damage to the car in the incident with Nasr.

"The car was pretty damaged," said the 31-year-old afterwards. "I'm sure it was some aero components but I think it was the suspension as well because it was flexing all over the place."

Mercedes F1 boss Toto Wolff said the front wing had damaged the leading edge of the floor and the barge boards when it came off and that the car had lost a "lot of aerodynamic performance". After a further switch to the medium compound tyres to last the race, Hamilton was not able to recover as much ground as the Ferraris and faces an uphill battle if he is to stop Rosberg winning his first world title this year.

Juan Martin del Potro defeated Stan Wawrinka in the second round of Wimbledon 2017. Del Potro, who is ranked 165th in the world, is playing in his first Grand Slam since the Australian Open in 2014 after having three wrist operations. Australia's Nick Kyrgios is also in the same half of the draw as Murray and remains on course to meet the world number two in the last 16. Kyrgios swept through the second set in just 15 minutes but Brown regained the advantage by taking the third. However, the Australian then won the fourth to move level and, after another rain delay, clinched the fifth set to reach round three.

Spanish 22nd seed Feliciano Lopez will play Kyrgios in the third round, with the winner of that tie then playing either Murray or Australian John Millman in the last 16. Lopez fought back from two sets behind to defeat Italian Fabio Fognini 3-6 6-7 6-3 6-3 6-3.

Elsewhere, there were routine victories for 10th seed Tomas Berdych and 12th seed Jo-Wilfried Tsonga. Berdych beat Germany's Benjamin Becker 6-4 6-1 6-2, while Tsonga triumphed 6-1 6-4 6-3 over Juan Monaco of Argentina.

Powys Council has been awarded a contract to regulate estate agents in Wales. The council will be able to issue warning and banning orders against agents acting dishonestly or breaching estate agent laws. The move follows a decision by the UK government to disband the Office of Fair Trading (OFT). Powys won the competitive bidding process to deliver the service in place of the OFT and will receive £170,000 a year to carry out the work. People complaining about estate agents will still contact their local authority trading standards department, who will prosecute offenders if necessary. However they will refer cases to Powys if they believe parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached. James Munro from Powys council, who will lead the new team, has said he hopes it will show Powys could take on more contracts and outside work in future.

Men in Black II is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film directed by Barry Sonnenfeld and starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn. It is the sequel to the 1997 film Men in Black, and follows the adventures of Agent J (Smith) and Agent K (Jones), two Men in Black agents who protect the Earth from extraterrestrial threats. In the film, J and K must stop an alien criminal from taking over the world.

The film was released on July 3, 2002, and was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $336 million worldwide. It was nominated for two Academy Awards for Best Visual Effects and Best Makeup.

The film opens with a flashback to 1969, when Agent K (Tommy Lee Jones) and Agent Kay (Dan Aykroyd) are tasked with protecting the Earth from an alien threat. The aliens are disguised as humans and are planning to take over the world. K and Kay are successful in stopping the aliens, but K is seriously injured in the process.

The film then cuts to the present day, where Agent J (Will Smith) is now a seasoned Men in Black agent. He is partnered with a new agent, Agent L (Lara Flynn Boyle). J and L are tasked with investigating the disappearance of several people. They soon discover that the people have been abducted by an alien criminal named Serleena (Rene Russo). Serleena is planning to use the people's DNA to create a new race of super-powered aliens.

J and L must stop Serleena before she can complete her plan. They are aided by K, who has been brought out of retirement to help them. J and L must also deal with the return of Edgar the Bug (Vincent D'Onofrio), an alien criminal who was defeated by K in the first film.

J and L are successful in stopping Serleena and Edgar the Bug. They also learn that K is not really human, but an alien who has been disguised as a human for many years. K decides to return to his home planet, but he promises to stay in touch with J.

Men in Black II is a fun and exciting sequel to the original film. It features great action sequences, special effects, and comedy. The film also has a strong cast, with Tommy Lee Jones and Will Smith giving standout performances. If you enjoyed the first film, you will definitely enjoy Men in Black II.

A mendicant is a person who lives by begging. The word comes from the Latin word mendicare, which means "to beg." Mendicants are often associated with religious orders, such as the Catholic mendicant orders, Hindu ascetics, some dervishes of Sufi Islam, and the monastic orders of Jainism and Buddhism.

A monk is a person who practices religious asceticism by monastic living, either alone or with any number of other monks. The word monk comes from the Greek word monachos, which means "single, solitary." Monks may be people who have decided to dedicate their lives to serving all other living beings, or to be ascetics who voluntarily choose to leave mainstream society and live their lives in prayer and contemplation.

Mendicant monks are a type of monk who lives by begging. They typically live in poverty and do not own any possessions. They rely on the generosity of others to provide them with food and shelter. Mendicant monks often travel from place to place, seeking out new opportunities to beg.

Mendicant monks are found in many different religious traditions, including Buddhism, Hinduism, and Christianity. In Buddhism, mendicant monks are known as bhikkhus. In Hinduism, mendicant monks are known as sannyasis. In Christianity, mendicant monks are known as friars.

Mendicant monks play an important role in their respective religious traditions. They are often seen as symbols of poverty and humility. They also serve as a reminder of the importance of giving to others.

Chipotle is partnering with Postmates to offer delivery in 67 cities. The service will have a $5 delivery fee and a 9% service charge. Chipotle is not the only restaurant chain to offer delivery, as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also planning to offer delivery services.

Chipotle is a fast-casual Mexican restaurant chain that was founded in 1993. The company has over 2,000 locations in the United States, Canada, and Europe. Chipotle is known for its burritos, tacos, and bowls, which are made with fresh, high-quality ingredients.

Postmates is a delivery service that was founded in 2011. The company offers delivery from over 300,000 restaurants and stores in over 200 cities in the United States. Postmates uses a fleet of independent contractors to deliver orders.

The partnership between Chipotle and Postmates is a way for Chipotle to expand its reach and offer its food to more customers. The delivery service will allow customers to order Chipotle food from the comfort of their own homes. The delivery fee and service charge will help to offset the costs of the delivery service.

Chipotle is not the only restaurant chain to offer delivery. Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also planning to offer delivery services. The rise of delivery services is a way for restaurants to reach more customers and increase sales.

Michael Vick is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the National Football League (NFL). He played college football for Virginia Tech, where he set numerous school and Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) records, and was recognized as a consensus All-American. Vick was drafted by the Atlanta Falcons with the first overall pick in the 2001 NFL Draft. He quickly became one of the most prolific quarterbacks in the NFL, leading the Falcons to the playoffs in his first three seasons. In 2004, Vick was named the NFL Offensive Player of the Year.

However, Vick's career was derailed in 2007 when he was indicted on federal charges of dogfighting. He was convicted and sentenced to 23 months in prison. After his release from prison, Vick signed with the Philadelphia Eagles in 2009. He played for the Eagles for two seasons before signing with the New York Jets in 2011. Vick played for the Jets for one season before signing with the Pittsburgh Steelers in 2012. He played for the Steelers for two seasons before retiring from the NFL in 2015.

Vick is a controversial figure in the NFL. He is considered one of the most talented quarterbacks to ever play the game, but his career was derailed by his involvement in dogfighting. Vick has since apologized for his actions and has worked to rebuild his image. He is now a successful businessman and advocate for animal rights.

Miracle at St. Anna is a 2008 American war film directed by Spike Lee and written by James McBride. The film is based on McBride's novel of the same name, which tells the story of four African-American soldiers of the 92nd Infantry Division who fight in Italy during World War II. The film stars Denzel Washington, John Turturro, Laz Alonso, Omar Epps, and Chadwick Boseman.

The film is set in 1944, during the Italian Campaign of World War II. The four soldiers, who are all members of the 92nd Infantry Division, are fighting in the Tuscan countryside. The division is made up of African-American soldiers, and it is often discriminated against by the white soldiers and officers of the U.S. Army.

The four soldiers are separated from their unit and find themselves in a small Tuscan village. The villagers are initially suspicious of the soldiers, but they eventually come to trust them. The soldiers help the villagers to defend themselves against a German attack, and they form a strong bond with them.

The film is presented as a flashback, as one of the survivors, Hector Negron, reflects upon his experiences in a frame story set in 1980s New York. Negron is now a successful businessman, but he is still haunted by the memories of the war.

Miracle at St. Anna is a powerful and moving film that tells the story of the African-American soldiers who fought in World War II. The film is a reminder of the courage and sacrifice of these soldiers, and it is a powerful indictment of racism.

The film was nominated for two NAACP Image Awards, for Outstanding Motion Picture and Outstanding Actor in a Motion Picture for Denzel Washington.

Mogadishu is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It is located in the coastal Banadir region on the Indian Ocean. The city has a population of about 2.4 million people. Mogadishu is the center of Somalia's government and economy. It is also home to many universities, hospitals, and other important institutions. The city has a long and rich history. It was founded in the 10th century by the Somali people. Mogadishu was an important trading center for centuries. It was also a major center of Islamic learning. In the 19th century, Mogadishu became a part of the British Empire. It was later occupied by Italy and then by the Soviet Union. In 1960, Somalia gained independence from Italy. Mogadishu became the capital of the new country. The city has been through a lot of turmoil in recent years. It was the site of a civil war from 1991 to 2006. The war caused a lot of damage to the city and its infrastructure. However, Mogadishu has been rebuilding in recent years. The city is now a major tourist destination. It is also home to many international organizations.

Mohra is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai. It stars Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. The film was released on 1 July 1994 and went on to become the second highest grossing Indian film of 1994. The film got nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Ballu is a ruthless gangster who is involved in smuggling, extortion, and murder. Jai and Vikram are determined to bring Ballu to justice, but they soon realize that they are in over their heads. Ballu is a powerful and dangerous man, and he will stop at nothing to protect his interests.

Mohra is a fast-paced and action-packed thriller that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The film is well-made and well-acted, and it features some of the best action sequences ever seen in an Indian film. If you're a fan of action movies, then you'll definitely want to check out Mohra.

Alvaro Morata has joined Real Madrid from Juventus for a fee of up to 30 million euros. The 23-year-old striker has signed a five-year contract with the Spanish club.

Morata, who is playing for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014, after four seasons with Real. The terms of his move to Italy included an option for Real to buy him back, with the fee reported to be up to 30m euros (£23m).

The 2023 Carrbridge World Chainsaw Carving Competition will be held on Saturday, February 25, 2023, in Carrbridge, Scotland. Morse code is a method of transmitting text information as a series of on-off tones, lights, or clicks. It is less sensitive to poor signal conditions than voice, and can be understood by humans without a decoding device. Morse code is often used in amateur radio, and can be sent by improvised methods in an emergency. It is one of the simplest and most versatile methods of telecommunication.

Morse code was invented by Samuel F.B. Morse in the 1830s. It was originally used for telegraphy, but it has since been used for a variety of other purposes, including radio communication, navigation, and signaling.

Morse code is a binary code, which means that it uses only two symbols: a dot and a dash. The length of each symbol is proportional to its frequency of occurrence in English. For example, the letter "E" is the most common letter in English, so it is represented by a single dot. The letter "Z" is the least common letter in English, so it is represented by a dash followed by three dots.

Morse code can be transmitted in a variety of ways, including by telegraph, radio, and sound. It can also be sent by hand using a morse code key, or by foot using a morse code clicker.

Morse code is a simple and versatile method of communication that has been used for over 150 years. It is still used today by amateur radio operators, navigators, and others who need to communicate in difficult conditions.

Karl Haugh, 25, was stabbed to death in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee, Ireland, in the early hours of Sunday, August 7, 2022. Robbie Walsh, of Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh. He has been remanded in custody to appear again in court next week. Two other men arrested over the killing were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions.

At Ennis District Court on Tuesday, Det Sgt Padraig Frawley said it will be alleged that Mr. Walsh was one of three people who entered the Marian Estate in Kilkee shortly after 1:00 a.m. on Sunday and called to houses in the estate looking for Mr. Haugh. Det. Frawley said it will be further alleged that while in the estate, the accused and the two males came across Mr. Haugh and another man and a fight ensued where weapons were used. He said: "Other individuals also arrived who became involved in the fight." Det. Frawley said: "During the course of the altercation, Karl Haugh received a stab wound to his back. Garda arrived at the scene where knives and golf clubs were recovered." He said that Mr. Haugh was brought by ambulance to Limerick University Hospital where he was pronounced dead at 6:00 a.m. local time. He said police recovered a knife handle and a blade at the scene of Mr. Haugh's death and the blade had blood on it.

A judge said the state had given evidence of tension in the area of Kilkee as a result of the killing and remanded Mr. Walsh in custody until August 14.

Google's chairman, Eric Schmidt, has defended the company's tax arrangements, saying that it pays what is "legally required". He has also called for a debate on international tax reform, saying that politicians should set the rules, not companies.

Google has been criticised for its tax arrangements, which have seen it pay relatively little tax in the UK despite generating billions of pounds in revenue there. The company has routed its UK sales through Ireland, where the corporate tax rate is 12.5%, compared to 20% in the UK.

Schmidt has said that Google's tax arrangements are legal and that it is up to the government to change the tax system if it wants companies to pay more taxes. He has also said that Google is willing to pay more tax if the rules are changed.

However, some critics have argued that Google is using legal loopholes to avoid paying its fair share of tax. They have called for the company to be investigated by the tax authorities.

The issue of tax avoidance by multinational companies is a complex one. There is no easy answer to the question of how much tax companies should pay. However, the debate is likely to continue, as governments seek to ensure that multinational companies pay their fair share of tax.

In addition to the debate on tax avoidance, there is also a debate on tax reform. Some people argue that the current system is unfair, as it allows multinational companies to pay lower taxes than smaller businesses. Others argue that the current system is complex and difficult to understand, and that it needs to be simplified.

The debate on tax reform is likely to continue for some time, as there is no easy consensus on how to reform the system. However, it is important to have this debate, as it is essential to ensure that the tax system is fair and efficient.

The Scottish government has said that the UK government's recent spending review places "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure north of the border. The UK government said Scottish ministers would have £390m more in spending available to them next year. Mr Swinney is due to present his 2016-17 spending plans on Wednesday.

The Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 - along with last month's spending review - mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. Mr Swinney said 4.2% of that reduction would come between now and 2019-20.

He said: "The chancellor (George Osborne) has imposed real terms cuts on Scotland every year from now until 2020, and more than £1bn of those cuts are still to come between now and the end of the decade.

"We have demonstrated that the UK government didn't have to take this approach. Debt and the deficit could have been reduced without this scale of cuts that has been chosen by the chancellor.

"Now Scotland has to deal with the reality of the chancellor's decision. We face tough choices in the coming days.

"Against this backdrop, the Scottish government is determined that we will defend and protect the key priorities that the people of Scotland expect us to deliver on."

Mr Swinney said schools, hospitals and the police service in Scotland would "not be sacrificed to the chancellor's austerity obsession". He added:

"In recent years we have been able to deliver better outcomes for the people of Scotland. More police, lower crime, better schools, tuition-free university education and a health budget that is at a record level.

"These commitments demonstrate the prioritisation of the Scottish government."

Responding to Mr Swinney comments, a spokesman for the UK government's Scotland Office said:

"The Scottish government will have £390m more spending available to it next year, which rises to £750m if you include its own underspend.

"The stability of the UK economy means the block grant will be almost £30bn.

"One look at the current oil price tells you this is a much better deal for people in Scotland than the constitutional alternative favoured by the Scottish government.

"The Scottish government should perhaps focus more on gearing up for its new powers and getting the best for Scotland, rather than grievance."

Labour's public services spokeswoman Jackie Baillie said:

"Ahead of the most important budget since devolution, it's time John Swinney backed up his anti-austerity posturing with something real.

"Telling us about pre-election giveaways now and cuts later isn't good enough. This needs to be a long-term budget.

"Scotland needs a government that spends less time congratulating itself on its spin and more time explaining its record.

"Scottish Labour will offer a real alternative to austerity, with different decisions on tax to the Tories, and different decisions on tax to the SNP."

Laura Muir broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British indoor 5,000m record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow on Wednesday, with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan said she felt excited to see her last record broken by Muir. She had earlier raised concerns about whether Muir's race had met all the criteria set by UK Athletics for record-breaking attempts. She had told BBC radio's John Beattie programme it needed to be a "genuine race" and may not have been as "Muir had been the only competitor". "It was a mixed 3K race where all the other girls ran 3K and it was only Laura who finished the 5K," she said. "We were wondering if to get a record ratified you have to have drug testing as well. "So we were just wondering if they had everything in place to actually have it ratified as a record." However, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time was expected to be classified as official. A spokesman said: "The time will undergo ratification but is expected to be confirmed". Rules stipulate that if there is no doping control at an event where a British record is set, there is no requirement for the athlete to submit drug tests. McColgan said Muir had what it took to win world medals. "To run 14.49 indoors is pretty good," she said. "But she is a 3.55 minute 1,500m runner, so you would expect someone like Laura to run (5K) in something like 14.30. "So there's still a lot more in the tank and I don't think that's the fastest 5K she's ever going to run. "She's got the ability to get down to 14.30, which is really mixing it with the top in the world." McColgan said Muir's race, which saw her lap other runners, had been similar to her own record-breaking race 25 years ago. "I ran on my own right from the start with nobody really pushing me at all," she said. "I actually lapped a young Paula Radcliffe about two or three times." McColgan said it was a bonus that her record was beaten by a fellow Scot. "She is world class," she said. "She just needs to get her race tactics right so that she can start winning some medals." Muir broke her own British 1500m record at the Diamond League meeting in Paris in August and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

The 2014 Man Booker Prize shortlist was announced on 9 September 2014. The six shortlisted novels are:

* The Lives of Others by Jhumpa Lahiri
* J by Howard Jacobson
* How to Be Both by Ali Smith
* To Rise Again at a Decent Hour by Joshua Ferris
* We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves by Karen Joy Fowler
* The Narrow Road to the Deep North by Richard Flanagan

The winner will be announced on 13 October 2014 at a ceremony in London.

The 2014 Man Booker Prize is the 46th year of the prize. The judging panel, chaired by AC Grayling, consists of Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven and Erica Wagner.

Last year, the Booker was won by New Zealand's Eleanor Catton for The Luminaries. At 28, she was the youngest-ever winner.

The shortlisted authors each receive £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book. Coverage from this year's ceremony, where the prize will be presented by the Duchess of Cornwall, will be on the BBC News Channel from 2130 BST and on BBC Arts.

The 2014 Man Booker Prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The prize is worth £50,000.

The shortlist was chosen from a longlist of 13 novels. The longlist was announced on 15 July 2014.

The 2014 Man Booker Prize is sponsored by Man Group plc.

Nathan Hughes's three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal on Friday night. The Wasps No 8 was initially suspended after a disciplinary panel ruled he had been "reckless" for failing to prevent his knee colliding with the head of the Welsh Lion, as he scored a try for Northampton on March 27. Hughes was shown a red card for the offence, but that dismissal has now been officially rescinded. Although it was accepted that there had been no intent, the Fiji-born player with England ambitions received a further sanction at the original hearing. Yet, in a stunning twist – and in light of fierce criticism – the ban was thrown out, as the appeal lodged by Wasps was upheld.

North was left unconscious by the clash; a third blow to the head in the space of two months. He has since been advised to take a minimum of a month off from playing, to counter-act his concussion symptoms. Graphic, slow-motion footage of the incident at Franklin’s Gardens led some observers to condemn Hughes, but many more spoke up in his defence. Wasps were incensed that the forward had been suspended – and their dismay was shared by others outside the club. Captain James Haskell said: ‘Astounded would be an under-statement’, while fly-half Andy Goode added: ‘Really can’t believe or understand the ban for Nathan Hughes. There was no intent and I feel the accident has been judged on outcome.’ Former England player Austin Healey branded the sentence a ‘total joke’ and Harlequins captain Joe Marler echoed his sentiment, calling it an ‘absolute joke’.

Hughes was sent off and then banned for three weeks following the incident on March 27. Hughes missed his club’s Champions Cup defeat to holders Toulon last Sunday, as he awaited his appeal hearing. He is now free to return to action immediately, but he is not in the match-day squad for Wasps’ Aviva Premiership trip to London Welsh tomorrow and given the formality of a victory in that fixture, he is unlikely to play again until the visit of Exeter to Coventry on April 26. Jeremy Summers, chairman of the appeal hearing panel, said: ‘The appeal panel considered it appropriate to hear the matter afresh. Having done so and having had the advantage of evidence not before the original panel, it concluded that no act of foul play took place in that the incident occurred accidentally.’

The UK Police Memorial Trust is appealing for £1.5m towards the construction of a permanent memorial to police officers and staff who have lost their lives in the line of duty. The memorial will be located at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, and is expected to be completed by 2019.

The memorial will be dedicated to the courage and sacrifice of police officers and staff who have lost their lives over the past 250 years. It will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out, which will be given to the families of fallen officers, with the names of loved ones as a personal memorial.

The government has committed £1m towards the £4m needed for the memorial. Home Secretary Amber Rudd said it was "entirely fitting" that those officers and staff who give their lives in the line of duty should be remembered with a lasting tribute.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer in an attack outside the Houses of Parliament in March prompted "greater emphasis" on the need for a permanent memorial, according to Sir Hugh Orde, chairman of the UK Police Memorial Trust. He said: "PC Palmer's death has put greater emphasis on the need to create a place where the nation can honour and commemorate our police service and where family, friends and colleagues of those killed on duty can go to carry out personal acts of remembrance."

"We need to establish a fitting memorial that recognises the vital contribution that policing makes to our society and acknowledges the courage and sacrifice made by police officers and police staff who have paid the ultimate price. "That tribute must become part of the fabric of our national life."

Pakistan lifted its ban on YouTube on January 24, 2017, after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the video-sharing website. The ban was imposed in 2012 after the US-made film Innocence of Muslims was uploaded to YouTube. The film was condemned in the Muslim world and sparked widespread protests for its mocking portrayal of the Prophet Muhammad. More than a dozen people died in protests in Pakistan.

The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) said the ban was no longer necessary because Google, which owns YouTube, had now launched a Pakistan-specific version. YouTube has denied claims that the authorities can filter content.

Many young Pakistanis have welcomed the lifting of the ban but some activists want details of the deal with Google. They say there should be greater transparency of the terms agreed between Google and the government.

A Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) official confirmed to the BBC that all internet service providers had been directed to open access to YouTube. The Pakistan Telecommunication Company Ltd posted on its Facebook page on Monday: "Welcome Back YouTube".

Pakistan's ministry of information technology said: "Google has provided an online web process through which requests for blocking access of offending material can be made by the PTA to Google directly. "Google/YouTube will accordingly restrict access to the said offending material for users within Pakistan."

However, a YouTube spokeswoman said government requests for the removal of content would not automatically be granted. "We have clear community guidelines, and when videos violate those rules, we remove them," she said. "In addition, where we have launched YouTube locally and we are notified that a video is illegal in that country, we may restrict access to it after a thorough review."

She said requests by governments for content to be removed would be recorded in YouTube's Transparency Report.

Papua is a province with a number of challenges. The province is home to a number of armed groups, and there is a long-running conflict between the Indonesian government and the Papuan independence movement. The province is also home to a number of human rights abuses.

Joe's Bar in Dungiven was closed for three months after police found people drinking there at 6am on October 6, 2014. The bar's license holder, Colleen O'Neill, was fined £3,000 and James Thomas, who was also working at the bar, was fined £1,000. The judge said O'Neill had an "appalling record" and expressed concern that he did not have the power to impose a custodial sentence.

Joe's Bar in Dungiven was closed for three months after police found several people still at the bar at 6am on October 6, 2014. Till receipts showed alcohol was being served as late as 4:49am. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts of allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. James Thomas, an employee, faced one count of the same charge. The judge said O'Neill had an "appalling record" and expressed concern that he did not have power to impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill was fined £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000.

Paris is the debut studio album by American socialite and businesswoman Paris Hilton. It was released on August 22, 2006, by Warner Bros. Records. The album was produced by Scott Storch, Fernando Garibay, and The Matrix, among others. It incorporates elements of pop, dance-pop, and R&B. The album debuted at number six on the US Billboard 200 chart, selling 36,000 copies in its first week. It was certified Gold by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) for shipments of 500,000 copies. The album's lead single, "Stars Are Blind", was released on July 25, 2006. It reached number 14 on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart and number one on the US Billboard Hot Dance Club Songs chart. The album's second single, "Nothing in This World", was released on October 16, 2006. It reached number 20 on the US Billboard Hot Dance Club Songs chart. The album's third single, "Turn It Up", was released on February 26, 2007. It reached number 12 on the US Billboard Hot Dance Club Songs chart. The album's fourth and final single, "I Just Wanna Be Loved", was released on June 18, 2007. It reached number 11 on the US Billboard Hot Dance Club Songs chart.

Paris received mixed reviews from music critics. AllMusic gave the album a two-star rating, calling it "a collection of bland, forgettable pop songs". The New York Times gave the album a negative review, calling it "a vanity project that is more about promoting Hilton's image than her music". Rolling Stone gave the album a two-star rating, calling it "a collection of bland, forgettable pop songs".

Despite the mixed reviews, Paris was a commercial success. It debuted at number six on the US Billboard 200 chart, selling 36,000 copies in its first week. It was certified Gold by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) for shipments of 500,000 copies. The album was also a success in Europe, reaching the top ten in several countries, including the United Kingdom, Germany, and Switzerland.

Paris was nominated for a Teen Choice Award for Choice Music Album: Female in 2007.

On Friday, 24 December 2022, strong winds caused power cuts, train delays, and speed restrictions on major bridges in Wales. The highest gusts of wind were recorded on Anglesey, where Irish Ferries cancelled six of its fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. Arriva Trains Wales warned of "speed restrictions and possible delays" for all services between Llandudno Junction to Holyhead. The National Trust also closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to the expected high winds. Winds eased into Friday evening, with earlier restrictions on both the A55 Britannia Bridge in north Wales and the M48 Severn Bridge in Monmouthshire lifted. But a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend has seen at least one festive event postponed - Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip in the sea in Denbighshire will now go ahead 24 hours later, on Tuesday, 27 December.

Paul Merson, a former Arsenal and England player, is a pundit for Sky Sports. He has been critical of Andros Townsend, a Tottenham Hotspur and England player, in the past. Merson said that Townsend should not have been called up to the England squad, and that he was "nowhere near good enough" to play for England. Townsend responded by scoring a goal for England in a friendly match against Italy. Merson then admitted that he was wrong to criticize Townsend, and that he was "genuinely pleased" for him. However, Merson was unable to resist having another dig at Townsend after Tottenham drew with Burnley in the Premier League. He tweeted that Townsend had "missed the coach" by being brought on as a substitute with only seven minutes remaining in the match.

Paul Nicholls is an English actor. He is best known for his roles as Joe Wicks in BBC's EastEnders, and as DS Sam Casey in ITV's Law & Order: UK. He has also appeared in films such as The Buddha of Suburbia, The Full Monty, and The Football Factory.

Nicholls was born in Romford, Essex, England. He began his acting career at the age of 12, appearing in the BBC soap opera EastEnders. He played the role of Joe Wicks from 1990 to 1993. After leaving EastEnders, Nicholls appeared in a number of films, including The Buddha of Suburbia (1993), The Full Monty (1997), and The Football Factory (2004).

In 2009, Nicholls returned to television, starring in the ITV police drama Law & Order: UK. He played the role of DS Sam Casey until the show ended in 2014. Nicholls has also appeared in a number of other television series, including Waterloo Road, Holby City, and Casualty.

In addition to his work in film and television, Nicholls has also appeared on stage. He has starred in productions of Romeo and Juliet, Hamlet, and The Importance of Being Earnest.

Nicholls is a talented actor who has enjoyed a successful career in film, television, and theater. He is best known for his roles in EastEnders and Law & Order: UK.

Peking University (PKU) is a major Chinese research university located in Beijing. It is the first modern national university established in China, founded as the Imperial University of Peking in 1898 as a replacement of the ancient Taixue or Guozijian, or Imperial Academy. It also served as the highest administration for education (ministry of education) in China at the beginning of its founding. PKU is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.

PKU is a member of the C9 League, a group of nine leading research universities in China. It is also a member of the Association of American Universities, a consortium of 62 leading research universities in North America. PKU has been ranked among the top universities in the world by major education publications such as Times Higher Education, Quacquarelli Symonds, and Academic Ranking of World Universities.

PKU has a long and distinguished history. It was founded in 1898 during the late Qing Dynasty, and it was originally called the Imperial University of Peking. The university was renamed Peking University in 1912, after the fall of the Qing Dynasty. PKU has played a major role in the development of modern China. It has educated many of China's leaders, including former President Hu Jintao and former Premier Wen Jiabao.

PKU is a large university with over 30,000 students. It offers a wide range of undergraduate and graduate programs in the humanities, social sciences, natural sciences, and engineering. PKU is also home to a number of research institutes and centers.

PKU is a world-renowned university with a strong reputation for academic excellence. It is a major center of learning and research in China and around the world.

Penguin Books was a British publishing company founded in 1935 by Allen Lane. It revolutionized publishing in the 1930s through its inexpensive paperbacks, sold through Woolworths and other high street stores for sixpence, bringing high-quality paperback fiction and non-fiction to the mass market.

Penguin Books was founded by Allen Lane, who was inspired by the success of the American publisher Pocket Books. Lane wanted to create a similar line of affordable paperbacks in Britain, and he secured the rights to publish a number of popular titles from American publishers. The first Penguin books were published in 1935, and they were an immediate success. The books were well-written and affordable, and they appealed to a wide range of readers.

Penguin Books quickly became one of the most successful publishing companies in Britain. The company expanded its list of titles, and it also began to publish original works of fiction and non-fiction. Penguin books were known for their high quality and their affordable price, and they helped to make reading accessible to a wider audience.

Penguin Books continued to be successful after the Second World War. The company expanded into new markets, and it also began to publish books in other languages. Penguin Books is now one of the largest and most respected publishing companies in the world.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) has suggested that Skegness, a seaside resort in Lincolnshire, England, replace its mascot, the Jolly Fisherman, with a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." PETA argues that the Jolly Fisherman is a symbol of animal cruelty, as he is depicted holding a fishing rod and a net. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, has said that the Jolly Fisherman is loved by adults and children alike, and that he does not believe that the character is a symbol of animal cruelty. He has said that PETA's suggestion will be considered by the council, but that he does not think there would be much support for changing the mascot.

The Jolly Fisherman was created in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway to promote Skegness as a seaside resort. The character was originally depicted as a man in a fisherman's hat and coat, with a pipe in his mouth and a fishing rod in his hand. The slogan "Skegness is so bracing" was also used in the original poster.

The Jolly Fisherman has been used in a variety of marketing materials for Skegness over the years, including posters, brochures, and even a television commercial. The character has become synonymous with the resort, and is often used to promote Skegness as a family-friendly destination.

PETA's suggestion to replace the Jolly Fisherman with a fish has been met with mixed reactions. Some people have supported the idea, arguing that the Jolly Fisherman is a symbol of animal cruelty and that Skegness should be a more progressive holiday destination. Others have argued that the Jolly Fisherman is a beloved character and that he should not be replaced.

The decision of whether or not to replace the Jolly Fisherman will ultimately be up to the council of Skegness. It is likely that the council will consider the views of both PETA and the public before making a decision.

Poldark is a British-American historical drama television series based on the novels of Winston Graham. The series is set in Cornwall in the 18th century and follows the life of Ross Poldark, a young officer who returns home from the American Revolutionary War to find his family and estate in ruins. Poldark must rebuild his life and find a new way to make a living, while also dealing with the challenges of love, loss, and betrayal.

The series was first broadcast on BBC One in the United Kingdom on 8 March 2015. It was also broadcast on PBS in the United States. The series has been well-received by critics and audiences alike, and has been nominated for several awards, including the BAFTA TV Award for Best Drama Series.

The cast of Poldark includes Aidan Turner as Ross Poldark, Eleanor Tomlinson as Demelza Carne, Heida Reed as Elizabeth Warleggan, Jack Farthing as George Warleggan, and Ruby Bentall as Morwenna Chynoweth.

The series has been praised for its beautiful cinematography, its well-developed characters, and its complex storylines. It has also been credited with helping to revive interest in the historical fiction genre.

Poldark is a must-watch for fans of historical drama, romance, and adventure. It is a beautifully crafted series that will transport you to another time and place.

A 28-year-old woman was found seriously injured on a pavement in Hamelin, Germany, on Sunday night. She had been dragged by the neck through several streets. The woman's ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, is in custody. Both the victim and the suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is not yet clear. Police have secured the area where the woman was found and have called for witnesses to come forward.

A 12-year-old boy was seriously injured after being hit by a car in Coatbridge, Scotland, on Tuesday afternoon. The boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious. Police are appealing for witnesses to the incident, which happened on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at about 4:40pm.

Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola ripped a hole in his trousers during his team's 6-1 victory over Porto in the Champions League on Tuesday night. The Spanish tactician's underwear was on show after the incident, and he joked after the match: 'I'll have to buy new ones for the next match.'

Guardiola's trousers ripped during a particularly exciting moment in the match, when Bayern were leading 5-0 at half-time. The manager was celebrating a goal when he accidentally caught his leg on a piece of furniture, causing his trousers to tear.

Despite the wardrobe malfunction, Guardiola was in good spirits after the match, which saw Bayern book their place in the semi-finals of the Champions League. He said: 'It was a great night for us. We played very well and deserved to win.'

Guardiola's trousers were not the only thing that was ripped apart on Tuesday night. Porto's defence was also torn to shreds by Bayern, who scored six goals without reply. The Portuguese side were completely outclassed by the German giants, and they will be hoping to avoid a similar fate in the next round.

Bayern will now face either Barcelona or Paris Saint-Germain in the semi-finals. The first leg of the tie will be played on April 25, with the second leg taking place on May 2.

Poseidon is a 2006 American disaster film directed by Wolfgang Petersen and starring Josh Lucas, Kurt Russell, Richard Dreyfuss, Emmy Rossum, and Andre Braugher. It is a remake of the 1972 film The Poseidon Adventure, which was based on the 1969 novel of the same name by Paul Gallico. The film tells the story of a group of survivors who must find a way to escape from the luxury ocean liner Poseidon, which has capsized during a New Year's Eve cruise.

Poseidon was released in the United States on December 12, 2006. It received mixed reviews from critics, but was a box office success, grossing over $181 million worldwide against its $160 million budget.

The film was nominated for two Academy Awards: Best Sound Editing and Best Sound Mixing. It also won the Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Remake or Sequel.

The film begins with a group of passengers and crew celebrating New Year's Eve on the luxury ocean liner Poseidon. The ship is on its way from Athens to New York City.

Suddenly, a massive wave hits the ship, causing it to capsize. The passengers and crew are trapped in the sinking ship.

A group of survivors, led by Dylan Rhodes (Josh Lucas), must find a way to escape from the ship. They must overcome the obstacles of the sinking ship, as well as the dangers of the sea.

The survivors eventually make it to safety, but not before losing many of their friends and loved ones.

Poseidon is a story of survival and hope. It is a film that will stay with you long after you watch it.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick shed tears after veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil bid farewell to the parliament. And she was again visibly emotional after Mr Salmond told the chamber: "It's goodbye from me... for now". Ms Marwick, Mr Salmond and Mr McNeil are among those standing down as MSPs ahead of the election on 5 May.

Mr Salmond, who served as first minister between 2007 and 2014, used his valedictory address to repeat a belief he expressed in his very first speech in the parliament that Scotland was "not divided, but diverse". He said both the country and parliament were on a journey, and added: "Yes we are a country of different views, but we are not divided. There is in fact a broad consensus on the need for this parliament to assume greater responsibility for the governance of Scotland. "And we are definitely stronger - so much stronger - as a result of that".

He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill, but again insisted the bill did not fulfil the pledges which he said had been made by unionist politicians in the last days of the referendum campaign.

There were lighters moments as Mr Salmond, who was speaking before the Chancellor delivered his UK budget, joked that he was aware that he faced competition from a "major attraction down south today". He then added: "However, on balance, I feel that the champion chase at Cheltenham racecourse will not be overshadowed by my remarks."

And the former SNP leader joked that he wished everyone standing in the forthcoming election good luck, "albeit with varying degrees of enthusiasm".

He concluded his address by saying: "Let me leave you with these final thoughts - there is no greater honour in public life than to be a member of this parliament. "There is no greater task than to mould the public purpose of Scotland. There is no greater cause than to serve the people of this country. "And so with that it is goodbye from me... for now".

Ms Marwick thanked Mr Salmond for his contribution both as an MSP and as first minister, and added that he had "served the parliament and Scotland with distinction".

The presiding officer had earlier been moved to tears by a powerful final speech by Scottish Labour backbencher Duncan McNeil, who is stepping down as an MSP after serving in the parliament since it was established in 1999.

Mr McNeil used his address to warn that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly with regard to the committee system. He said: "It will be this parliament's responsibility to ensure there is accountability, there is scrutiny and even opposition when that is necessary. "We must ensure we are capable of meeting that challenge, or we will face the consequences."

He recalled how former Labour MP Robin Cook came to Holyrood to look at the lessons that could be learned when it came to reforming Westminster. But Mr McNeil said: "It saddens me to say we now have to do a bit of learning from them and how they run their business."

Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also bowing out of Holyrood. In her speech, she joked she would miss her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney, especially "his huge outbursts of faux indignation".

In conclusion, the following are the core pieces of information described in the passage:

* Presiding officer Tricia Marwick shed tears after veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil bid farewell to the parliament.
* Mr Salmond, who served as first minister between 2007 and 2014, used his valedictory address to repeat a belief he expressed in his very first speech in the parliament that Scotland was "not divided, but diverse".
* Mr McNeil used his address to warn that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly with regard to the committee system.
* Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also bowing out of Holyrood.
