Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding to be held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas on April 23. The winning couple will be announced next Monday and will receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite, airfare, and concert tickets. Priscilla has been involved in the look and feel of the chapel, which is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of the singer's artifacts outside his iconic Memphis, Tennessee, home. Couples wanting to be the first to wed at the chapel must submit a video or photos along with an explanation detailing why they deserve the prize.

Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts by Noël Coward. It tells the story of two former spouses, Elyot Chase and Amanda Prynne, who meet again on their respective honeymoons with their new spouses, Victor Prynne and Sibyl Chase. The play explores the themes of love, marriage, and divorce.

The play was first produced in London in 1930, and it was a critical and commercial success. It was subsequently adapted into a film in 1931, and it has been revived on stage numerous times.

Private Lives is a witty and sophisticated comedy that has been enjoyed by audiences for over 90 years. It is a classic example of Coward's work, and it is a must-see for fans of British comedy.

The play is set in the present day (1930) and takes place in a hotel in France. The characters are all wealthy and well-educated, and they speak in a sophisticated and witty manner. The play is full of clever wordplay and double entendres, and it is a delight to listen to.

The plot of the play is simple but effective. Elyot and Amanda are former spouses who have been divorced for five years. They meet again on their respective honeymoons with their new spouses, Victor and Sibyl. The four of them are immediately attracted to each other, and they begin an affair.

The play explores the themes of love, marriage, and divorce. Elyot and Amanda are both passionate and impulsive people, and they are drawn to each other despite their past history. Victor and Sibyl are both more level-headed, and they are initially shocked by Elyot and Amanda's behavior. However, they eventually come to understand and accept their relationship.

The play is a comedy, but it also has a serious message. It suggests that love is not always easy, but it is always worth fighting for. It also suggests that marriage is not always easy, but it is a commitment that should be taken seriously.

Private Lives is a classic comedy that has been enjoyed by audiences for over 90 years. It is a witty and sophisticated play that explores the themes of love, marriage, and divorce. It is a must-see for fans of British comedy.

The Russian parliament is considering two bills that would make it easier for Ukrainians to obtain Russian citizenship. The first bill would allow Ukrainians to apply for Russian passports at Russian diplomatic missions before 1 August, and they could become citizens after two months, instead of waiting a year, as is currently the norm. The second bill would speed up the procedures for issuing Russian passports. Passport applicants would not have to pay a state tax, and previous residence in Russia would no longer be required. In addition, they would not have to have sufficient funds to support themselves and would not have to give up their Ukrainian citizenship.

The bills have been linked directly to the situation in Ukraine, where pro-Russian separatists are demanding that the country join Russia. The bills are seen as a way for Russia to increase its influence in Ukraine and to counter the pro-Western government in Kiev.

The bills have been met with criticism from the Ukrainian government and from the West. The Ukrainian government has accused Russia of trying to destabilize the country and of violating its sovereignty. The West has warned Russia against taking any further steps that could undermine Ukraine's territorial integrity.

The bills are still under consideration by the Russian parliament. It is not clear when they will be voted on or if they will be passed.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was killed in Brecon on 8 May 2022. He was off-duty and on his way back to the barracks when he was attacked outside a bar called The Cellar. CCTV footage showed the soldier being punched, going to the ground and being beaten until he no longer moved. Vallely then dragged his body from the scene before fleeing. The trial was told the killer had been on a seven hour drinking binge and in the hour before the attack was boasting he was the "hardest man in Brecon". His friend Mr Evans was cleared of any involvement in the attack, after the jury was told he had left the scene before the start of any violence. Senior investigating officer Det Supt David Guiney, from Dyfed-Powys Police, called the attack "a despicable act" that "shocked" the community of Brecon. "I plead with anyone who plans a night out drinking with their friends to please, walk away from any conflict, do not resort to violence," he said. A family tribute described Pte Boyd as an "all-rounder" who had "a promising career ahead of him which has been cut short". The tribute read: "Matthew was full of life. He was loving, caring and loyal. He was always playing jokes on his peers and family, and always brought smiles to our faces." It said Vallely had created "a void in our family that will never be filled", adding the "unbearable pain" was something they will have to live with for the rest of their lives. "During this trial, it has been mentioned that Jake Vallely called himself the 'hardest man in Brecon' on the night that he murdered Matthew," the tribute said. "He couldn't have been more wrong. There has been such a massive outpouring of love from the community in Brecon towards our family; in our mind, those are the strongest people in Brecon."

Jake Vallely was found guilty of manslaughter and sentenced to 12 years in prison.

The Quran is the central religious text of Islam, believed by Muslims to be a direct revelation from God (Allah) to the Islamic prophet Muhammad. It is widely regarded as the finest work in classical Arabic literature. The Quran is divided into 114 chapters (surahs) which are further divided into verses (ayahs). The Quran is believed to be the most important source of Islamic law and theology.

Muslims believe that the Quran was revealed to Muhammad by the angel Gabriel over a period of 23 years, beginning when he was 40 years old and ending shortly before his death in 632 CE. The Quran was originally written down on parchment and palm leaves, and was later compiled into a single volume.

The Quran is a collection of revelations that Muhammad received from God. These revelations were not written down at the time they were received, but were instead memorized by Muhammad and his followers. After Muhammad's death, his followers compiled these revelations into a single volume, which is now known as the Quran.

The Quran is divided into 114 chapters (surahs), which are further divided into verses (ayahs). The surahs are not arranged in chronological order, but rather in order of decreasing length. The longest surah is Al-Baqarah (The Cow), which has 286 verses. The shortest surah is Al-Kawthar (Abundance), which has only three verses.

The Quran is written in Arabic, and is considered to be the perfect and inimitable word of God. Muslims believe that the Quran is a guide for all aspects of life, and that it provides guidance on everything from how to worship God to how to live a moral and ethical life.

The Quran is a central part of Islamic worship, and is recited daily in prayers. It is also used as a source of law and guidance in all aspects of life. The Quran is a rich and complex text, and its interpretation has been the subject of much debate and discussion throughout Islamic history.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco team-mate Nabil Dirar believes the Colombian must be regretting his failed loan move to Manchester United. Falcao moved to Old Trafford on a season-long loan last summer but has struggled to hit the heights he achieved before suffering a serious knee injury. United will have to pay £46million to make Falcao's transfer permanent but having only scored four goals all season Louis van Gaal's side are unlikely to take up that option. Dirar has revealed that Falcao was not happy in France but thinks he would have been better off staying at Monaco.

Raees is a 2017 Indian Hindi-language crime film directed by Rahul Dholakia and produced by Ritesh Sidhwani and Farhan Akhtar under Excel Entertainment. The film stars Shah Rukh Khan, Mahira Khan, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui. It is based on the life of Abdul Karim Lakdawala, a bootlegger who was active in Gujarat in the 1980s and 1990s.

The film was released on 25 January 2017. It received mixed reviews from critics, with praise for Khan's performance but criticism for its length and screenplay. The film was a commercial success, grossing over ₹1.30 billion worldwide.

Raees is set in the 1980s in Gujarat, India. Raees Alam (Shah Rukh Khan) is a bootlegger who runs a liquor empire in the city of Ahmedabad. He is a ruthless and ambitious man who will stop at nothing to achieve his goals. Raees is also a Robin Hood figure who helps the poor and needy in his community.

Majmudar (Nawazuddin Siddiqui) is a police officer who is determined to bring Raees to justice. He is a corrupt and ruthless man who will use any means necessary to achieve his goals. Majmudar is also a family man who is devoted to his wife and children.

Raees and Majmudar are on a collision course, and their rivalry will have devastating consequences for both of them.

Raees is a powerful and gripping film that tells the story of a man who will stop at nothing to achieve his goals. The film is well-acted and directed, and it is sure to keep you entertained from beginning to end.

Rage Against the Machine is an American rock band formed in Los Angeles, California, in 1991. The band consists of vocalist Zack de la Rocha, guitarist Tom Morello, bassist Tim Commerford, and drummer Brad Wilk. Rage Against the Machine is known for their politically charged music and their outspoken criticism of the U.S. government and other institutions. The band's music is a fusion of heavy metal, rap, and funk, and their lyrics often deal with social and political issues such as racism, poverty, and police brutality.

Rage Against the Machine released their self-titled debut album in 1992. The album was a critical and commercial success, and it helped to establish the band as one of the most important and influential rock bands of the 1990s. Rage Against the Machine's second album, Evil Empire, was released in 1996. The album was even more successful than their debut, and it cemented the band's reputation as one of the most important and influential rock bands of the era.

Rage Against the Machine's third album, The Battle of Los Angeles, was released in 1999. The album was another critical and commercial success, and it featured the band's most well-known song, "Killing in the Name". Rage Against the Machine's fourth and final album, Renegades, was released in 2000. The album is a collection of covers of songs by other artists, and it features the band's most well-known cover, "How I Could Just Kill a Man".

Rage Against the Machine disbanded in 2000 after de la Rocha left the band. The band's members have since pursued other projects, including Audioslave, Prophets of Rage, and One Day as a Lion. Rage Against the Machine reunited in 2007 and have since performed together on a number of occasions.

Rage Against the Machine is one of the most important and influential rock bands of the 1990s. The band's music is a fusion of heavy metal, rap, and funk, and their lyrics often deal with social and political issues such as racism, poverty, and police brutality. Rage Against the Machine has been praised for their outspoken criticism of the U.S. government and other institutions, and they have been credited with helping to inspire a new generation of political activists.

Ralph Fults was a Depression-era outlaw and escape artist associated with Raymond Hamilton, Bonnie Parker, and Clyde Barrow of the Barrow Gang. He was born on January 23, 1911, in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. Fults began his criminal career at the age of 16 when he was arrested for stealing a car. He was sentenced to five years in prison, but he escaped after only two years. After his escape, Fults became a fugitive and joined the Barrow Gang. He participated in several robberies and shootings with the gang, and he was eventually captured and sentenced to life in prison. However, he escaped from prison again in 1934. Fults was finally captured and put in prison for good in 1935. He was released from prison in 1954 and died on March 16, 1993.

Randy Mario Poffo (November 15, 1952 – May 20, 2011), better known by the ring name "Macho Man" Randy Savage, was an American professional wrestler and color commentator best known for his time in the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now WWE) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW).

Savage was born in Columbus, Ohio, and began his professional wrestling career in 1973. He wrestled for several different promotions in the 1970s and 1980s, including the American Wrestling Association (AWA), the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA), and the World Wrestling Federation (WWF).

In 1985, Savage signed with the WWF. He quickly became one of the WWF's top stars, winning the WWF World Heavyweight Championship twice. He also feuded with some of the WWF's biggest stars, including Hulk Hogan, The Ultimate Warrior, and Ric Flair.

In 1994, Savage left the WWF and signed with WCW. He continued to be a top star in WCW, winning the WCW World Heavyweight Championship four times. He also feuded with some of WCW's biggest stars, including Hulk Hogan, Sting, and Kevin Nash.

Savage retired from professional wrestling in 2000. He died in 2011 at the age of 58.

Savage was a popular and successful professional wrestler. He was known for his flamboyant style, his over-the-top persona, and his catchphrases, such as "Ohhhh yeah!" and "Snap into a Slim Jim!" He was also a talented wrestler, and he was a two-time WWF World Heavyweight Champion and a four-time WCW World Heavyweight Champion.

Savage was inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame in 2015.

Reign Over Me is a 2007 American comedy-drama film written and directed by Mike Binder, and produced by his brother Jack Binder. Distributed by Columbia Pictures, the film was released on March 23, 2007. The film stars Adam Sandler as Charlie Fineman, a dentist who is still grieving the loss of his wife and two children in the September 11 attacks. When he runs into his old college roommate Alan Johnson (Don Cheadle), Charlie reluctantly allows Alan to help him through his grief. The film also stars Jada Pinkett Smith, Liv Tyler, and Saffron Burrows.

Reign Over Me received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising Sandler's performance and Binder's direction, while others found the film to be too sentimental. The film was a box office disappointment, grossing only $30 million worldwide against its $50 million budget.

Plot
Charlie Fineman is a dentist who lives in New York City. He is still grieving the loss of his wife and two children in the September 11 attacks. One day, he runs into his old college roommate Alan Johnson, who is now a successful businessman. Alan invites Charlie to dinner, and Charlie reluctantly agrees.

Alan tries to help Charlie through his grief, but Charlie is reluctant to open up. However, over time, the two men become friends, and Charlie begins to heal.

One day, Charlie tells Alan that he is going to move to Los Angeles. Alan is upset, but he knows that it is what Charlie needs to do. Charlie leaves New York, and Alan promises to stay in touch.

The film ends with Charlie and Alan talking on the phone. Charlie tells Alan that he is doing well, and Alan is happy to hear it. The two men promise to stay in touch, and they hang up the phone.

Themes
Reign Over Me is a film about grief and loss. It explores the ways in which people cope with tragedy, and the importance of friendship and support. The film also deals with the aftermath of the September 11 attacks, and the impact that the attacks had on people's lives.

Critical reception
Reign Over Me received mixed reviews from critics. Some critics praised Sandler's performance and Binder's direction, while others found the film to be too sentimental.

On Rotten Tomatoes, the film has an approval rating of 52% based on 153 reviews, with an average rating of 5.7/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "Reign Over Me is a well-acted and well-directed film, but it's also a bit too sentimental for its own good." On Metacritic, the film has a weighted average score of 46 out of 100, based on 35 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".

Box office
Reign Over Me was a box office disappointment, grossing only $30 million worldwide against its $50 million budget.

Accolades
Reign Over Me was nominated for one award, the Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy for Sandler.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt have sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. But the 41-year-old former Inter Milan and Parma right back, capped 25 times by Brazil, angered Massone again after Ceahlaul were beaten 2-0 by mid-table FC Botosani on Saturday. Ze Maria represented Brazil on 25 occasions during an international career spanning five years. The result left Ceahlaul 16th in the standings, six points adrift of safety. Ze Maria replaced Florin Marin in January to become Ceahlaul's third coach this season. He will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

A survey of 1,000 parents found that four out of five children who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. Half of the parents said their children had asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas. Aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular.

The survey was conducted online between 26 February and 5th March among a panel of parents who had at least one child in school aged 4-17 years old.

England's School Food Trust commissioned the research after a survey by the Mumsnet website suggested some parents gave their children packed lunches because they thought they were too fussy to eat anything else.

Trust chairman, Rob Rees, said: "Every parent knows it's a nightmare watching their child push food around the plate. "School meals can be a great way to help parents encourage their children to try new foods and to increase the variety of foods in their diet."

Mumsnet co-founder, Carrie Longton, said: "Getting children to eat healthily is every parent's dream, but meal times at home can often be a battle ground and emotionally charged. "From Mumsnetters' experience it seems that once at school there's a desire to fit in with everyone else and even some positive peer pressure to boast about the variety of what foods you can eat. "School meals have also moved on quite a bit from when Mumsnetters were at school, with healthier options and more variety."

School meals in England now have to comply with strict nutritional guidelines. About four in 10 primary school children in England now eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools. More children in Scotland eat school lunches - about 46%.

A new stretch of land emerged overnight along the coastline of Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, on Hokkaido Island, Japan. The mass, which has risen some 30 to 50ft above sea level, measures roughly 1,000- 1,640ft long, and 100ft wide. Geologists believe the emergence is a result of a landslide nearby, when melting ice and snow caused a section of land to drop, pivoting the underwater area into the air. The new stretch of land came as a complete surprise to the locals, as there was no indication of the land movement overnight. Authorities have not been able to determine exactly when the landslide hit the snow-covered coastline, but they do not expect it to expand further.

Yune is a talented actor who has appeared in a variety of films and television shows. He is best known for his roles in "The Fast and the Furious," "Mission: Impossible II," and "Marco Polo."

Robert Palmer was a writer, music journalist, and musician. He is best known for his books, including Deep Blues; his music journalism for The New York Times and Rolling Stone magazine; his work producing blues recordings and the soundtrack of the film Deep Blues; and his clarinet playing in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

Palmer was born in New York City in 1945. He began his career as a journalist in the early 1960s, writing for magazines such as Esquire and The Village Voice. In 1967, he joined the staff of Rolling Stone magazine, where he wrote about music and culture for over 20 years.

Palmer's first book, Deep Blues, was published in 1981. It is a comprehensive study of the blues, from its origins in Africa to its development in the United States. The book was praised by critics and became a bestseller.

Palmer also wrote several other books, including Rock & Roll: An Illustrated History (1986), The Rolling Stone Illustrated History of Rock & Roll (1995), and Deep Blues: A Musical and Cultural History of the Mississippi Delta (2002).

In addition to his writing, Palmer was also a musician. He played clarinet in the 1960s band the Insect Trust. He also produced several blues recordings, including the soundtrack of the film Deep Blues.

Palmer died in 1997 at the age of 51. He is survived by his wife and two children.

Roma beat Napoli 1-0 in Serie A on Saturday, ending their four-month winless streak at home. Miralem Pjanic scored the only goal of the game in the 25th minute, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several key saves to preserve the victory. The win moves Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio in second place, while Napoli's winless streak extends to five matches.

The number of migrants crossing the Mediterranean Sea to Italy has increased significantly in recent months. In the first three months of 2015, Italy registered more than 10,000 migrants arriving, and about 2,000 were rescued at sea during the first weekend of April. Most migrants come from countries in West Africa as well as Somalia and Syria. They use Libya as a country of transit. At least 480 migrants have died while crossing the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year, often because of bad weather and overcrowded vessels used by smugglers. Sometimes the captains and crews abandon the ships, leaving passengers to fend for themselves.

On Tuesday, a spokesman with Save the Children told CNN the group fears 400 migrants could be missing, citing testimony from survivors who said their ship carrying 550 people capsized in the Mediterranean Sea about 80 miles off the Libyan coast. The Italian coast guard, however, told CNN that while it is taking the report seriously, it cannot confirm such an incident and has not yet found evidence at sea to indicate a migrant boat carrying approximately 550 has capsized with 145 rescued. An operation that included boats and planes did not find any survivors, nor bodies, nor any evidence to indicate a particular boat capsized, Coast Guard official Filippo Marini said.

The recent upsurge in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy has put a strain on Italian resources. The Italian government has been criticized for its handling of the situation, and some have called for the European Union to do more to help.

The European Union has responded by increasing funding for border control and rescue operations. However, some critics say that the EU is not doing enough to address the root causes of the migrant crisis, such as poverty and conflict in Africa.

The migrant crisis is a complex and challenging issue. There is no easy solution, but it is important to understand the causes of the crisis and to work together to find a solution.

Roy Oliver, a police officer in Balch Springs, Texas, was indicted on a murder charge in the April 2017 shooting death of Jordan Edwards, a 15-year-old black teenager. Oliver was fired from the police department a few days after the shooting.

The shooting occurred after police responded to a report of underage drinking at a house party. Oliver and another officer arrived at the party and approached a car that was leaving the scene. Oliver fired into the car, striking Edwards in the head. Edwards died at the scene.

Police initially said that the car had reversed "aggressively" towards Oliver, but video footage of the shooting showed that the car was driving away from Oliver when he opened fire.

Oliver is facing a charge of murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. He is currently free on bail. If convicted, he could face up to 99 years in prison.

The shooting has sparked protests in Balch Springs and across the country. The Edwards family has filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the city of Balch Springs and Oliver.

The case is being closely watched as it could have implications for the use of deadly force by police officers.

Scientists and charities are calling on the Welsh government to roll out the HPV vaccine to boys, as well as girls. They say the vaccine will protect boys from head and neck cancers, which are on the rise. The Welsh government says it is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision.

The HPV vaccine is already offered to girls aged 12 and 13 in Wales. It protects against the human papilloma virus, which can cause cervical cancer, as well as other types of cancer, including head and neck cancer.

Scientists say the vaccine is safe and effective, and that it could save lives. They say it is important to vaccinate boys as well as girls, as boys can also get head and neck cancer.

The Welsh government says it is committed to protecting the health of its citizens, and that it will consider the evidence before making a decision on the HPV vaccine.

Sean Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career in television with a brief appearance in episode 112 of Little House on the Prairie (December 4, 1974), directed by his father Leo Penn. Following his film debut in the drama Taps (1981) and a diverse range of film roles in the 1980s, including Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982), Penn garnered critical attention for his roles in the crime dramas At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993). He became known as a prominent leading actor with the drama Dead Man Walking (1995), for which he earned his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received another two Oscar nominations for Woody Allen's comedy-drama Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and the drama I Am Sam (2001), before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River and a second one in 2008 for Milk.

Penn has also directed several films, including The Indian Runner (1991), The Crossing Guard (1995), Hurlyburly (1998), and Into the Wild (2007). He has also been involved in political activism, and has been arrested several times for protesting against the Iraq War and the death penalty.

In 2016, Penn was awarded the Legion of Honor by French President François Hollande. He is also a recipient of the Cecil B. DeMille Award, the Golden Globe Award for Best Director, and the BAFTA Award for Best Direction.

Sheikh Ali Salman, the leader of Bahrain's main opposition party, al-Wefaq, has called for national dialogue to be meaningful, the government must show its willingness to offer "concrete solutions". He also called for the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists who have been sentenced to between five years and life in prison on evidence widely accepted as having been obtained under torture.

Sheikh Salman acknowledged that many young protesters had lost faith in the main opposition parties, but he believed that the only way forward was to work with reformists within the Sunni Muslim royal family. He noted that hours before King Hamad brought in Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) troops to restore order and crush dissent on 14 March 2011, the crown prince and opposition had agreed a seven-point plan that would have moved Bahrain towards a constitutional monarchy.

Sheikh Salman was "hopeful" that the new US Secretary of State, John Kerry, would "do more than his predecessor", Hillary Clinton, to pressure Bahrain to improve its human rights record. He also called on the UK government to speak out publicly about the crisis in Bahrain, rather than just urging reform in private.

Sheikh Salman reiterated al-Wefaq's position that it would continue to call for "peaceful demonstrations", even though all public gatherings and rallies are currently banned in Bahrain. He said that this was the only way open to them to put pressure on the government.

Speech recognition is the process of converting spoken language into text. It is a subfield of computational linguistics that incorporates knowledge and research in the linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering fields.

Speech recognition is a challenging task because of the variability of human speech. Speech can be affected by factors such as the speaker's accent, the noise in the environment, and the speaker's emotional state.

Despite these challenges, speech recognition has become increasingly accurate in recent years. This is due to advances in machine learning and artificial intelligence.

Speech recognition is used in a variety of applications, including voice-activated assistants, dictation software, and closed captioning.

The earthworks were discovered in Acre state, which is located in the western Amazon rainforest. The team, which was led by Dr. Neil Loader of Swansea University, investigated ditched enclosures that were concealed for centuries by bamboo-dominated rainforest. The enclosures are up to 100 meters long and 50 meters wide, and they are thought to have been built by people who lived in the area around 2,000 years ago.

The team said the function of these mysterious sites is still little understood. They are unlikely to be villages, since archaeologists have recovered very few artefacts during excavation, and their layout does not suggest they were built for defensive reasons. Instead it is thought they were used only sporadically, perhaps as ritual gathering places, similar to the Maya pyramids of Central America, or Britain's own Stonehenge.

Although Dr. Loader - who has analysed soil samples from the geoglyphs - said the surroundings in which they were built were very different to other ritual sites around the world. He looked at phytoliths - a type of microscopic plant fossil made of silica - to reconstruct ancient vegetation; charcoal quantities, to assess the amount of ancient forest burning; and carbon stable isotopes, to indicate the type of vegetation growing there in the past. "The indications are that the geoglyphs were constructed amongst taller vegetation. So, unlike the towering Maya pyramids of Central America, they were likely not visible above the forest canopy, and this raises questions about their purpose," he explained.

It had been assumed prior to the arrival of Europeans in the early 16th Century, the Amazonian forests had been pristine ecosystems, free from human influence. But the new research indicates a wide variety of plant species spread over 6,000 years, which could only have been artificially brought together by humans. It suggested instead of burning large tracts of forest - either for geoglyph construction or agricultural practices - people transformed their environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees such as palms. The team have likened it to a form of "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. They said there is "tantalizing evidence" to suggest the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests may retain a strong legacy of these ancient "agroforestry" practices to this day.

The findings of this study provide new insights into the history of human occupation of the Amazon rainforest and the ways in which people have interacted with the environment over time. They also suggest that the Amazon rainforest is not as pristine as it is often portrayed, and that it has been shaped by human activity for thousands of years.

T2 Trainspotting is a 2017 British comedy-drama film directed by Danny Boyle and written by John Hodge, based on the novel of the same name by Irvine Welsh. It is the sequel to the 1996 film Trainspotting, and stars Ewan McGregor, Ewen Bremner, Jonny Lee Miller, Robert Carlyle, Shirley Henderson, and Kelly Macdonald. The film follows the characters 20 years after the events of the first film, as they deal with the consequences of their past actions.

The film was released in the United Kingdom on January 27, 2017, and in the United States on March 17, 2017. It received positive reviews from critics, with praise for its performances, direction, and screenplay. The film was a box office success, grossing over $279 million worldwide against its $16 million budget.

T2 Trainspotting was nominated for two BAFTA Awards, for Best British Film and Best Adapted Screenplay. It was also nominated for two Golden Globe Awards, for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy and Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy for McGregor.

The film is set in and around Edinburgh, Scotland. The characters are all in their 40s now, and they are dealing with the consequences of their past actions. Renton (McGregor) is now a successful businessman, but he is still haunted by his past. Sick Boy (Bremner) is still a drug addict, and he is trying to make a living as a pimp. Spud (Miller) is still struggling with addiction, and he is trying to get his life back on track. Begbie (Carlyle) is still in prison, but he is about to be released.

The film follows the characters as they try to deal with their past and move on with their lives. It is a dark and funny film that explores the themes of addiction, redemption, and friendship.

Taran Killam is an American actor, comedian, writer, and producer. He is best known for his work on Saturday Night Live, where he was a cast member from 2006 to 2016. He has also appeared in films such as The Hangover Part II, The Lego Movie, and Ted 2. Killam is married to actress Cobie Smulders.

Killam was born in Waterloo, Ontario, Canada, to Erin and Kevin Killam. He has two brothers, named Chris and Aaron. Killam attended St. David Catholic Secondary School in Waterloo. He then went on to study acting at the University of Victoria in British Columbia.

After graduating from university, Killam moved to New York City to pursue a career in comedy. He joined the Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre, where he performed in sketch comedy shows. In 2006, Killam was cast as a cast member on Saturday Night Live. He remained on the show for ten seasons, until 2016.

During his time on SNL, Killam impersonated a variety of celebrities, including Donald Trump, Mitt Romney, and Justin Bieber. He also co-wrote and starred in several SNL sketches, including "The Californians" and "The Digital Short."

In addition to his work on SNL, Killam has appeared in a number of films, including The Hangover Part II, The Lego Movie, and Ted 2. He has also starred in the television series The Mindy Project and Single Parents.

Killam is married to actress Cobie Smulders. They have two children together.

Tatum O'Neal is an American actress. She is the daughter of actor Ryan O'Neal and actress Joanna Moore. Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises. It is the second-largest Spanish-language broadcast television network in the United States, after Univision. Telemundo's programming includes news, sports, entertainment, and reality shows. The network is headquartered in Miami, Florida.

Telemundo was founded in 1954 as Spanish International Network (SIN). It was acquired by NBC in 2002 and renamed Telemundo. The network has since expanded its reach to include cable and satellite television, as well as digital platforms.

Telemundo is a major player in the Spanish-language media landscape in the United States. It is the most-watched Spanish-language network in the country, and its programming is available in over 100 million homes. Telemundo is also a major producer of Spanish-language content, and its shows are exported to over 100 countries around the world.

Telemundo is a significant part of the American media landscape. It is a major source of news and entertainment for Spanish-speaking Americans, and its programming is a reflection of the diversity of the Hispanic community in the United States.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, on Wednesday afternoon. Three vehicles collided, and a 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries, a five-year-old boy with chest pain, a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries, and a six-year-old girl suffering from abdominal pain were flown to the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. A man also suffered hand lacerations and two females escaped injuries. The affected stretch of the highway was closed off, with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

Boris Nemtsov, a Russian opposition politician, was assassinated in February 2015. Before his death, he was working on a report that accused President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine. The report, entitled Putin. War, was published posthumously by Nemtsov's colleagues.

The report presents evidence that Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive to securing all major victories claimed by the pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk. It also includes interviews with volunteer soldiers who admit that it was Russian generals, not separatists, who directed the main battles in eastern Ukraine.

The report has been praised by some for its thoroughness and its evidence of Russian involvement in the conflict. However, it has also been criticized by others for its lack of objectivity and its reliance on unnamed sources.

The report is likely to further strain relations between Russia and the West. It is also likely to fuel the debate within Russia about the country's involvement in Ukraine.

The report's main findings are as follows:

* Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive to securing all major victories claimed by the pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk.
* Russian generals, not separatists, directed the main battles in eastern Ukraine.
* Volunteer soldiers were paid $2,000-3,000 a month to fight in Ukraine.
* Russia spent 53bn roubles ($665m; $1bn) on the conflict.
* The report was based on facts that have already appeared in Russian and foreign media.
* The report's authors say putting the facts together and describing the human and economic cost of the conflict makes a very compelling case for accusing President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends.
* Russia has consistently denied accusations that it has sent regular troops and armour to help rebels in eastern Ukraine, arguing that any Russians serving there are "volunteers".
* The report's authors say the evidence they have gathered shows that this is not true.
* The report is likely to further strain relations between Russia and the West.
* It is also likely to fuel the debate within Russia about the country's involvement in Ukraine.

The 100 is a post-apocalyptic science fiction television series that follows a group of 100 juvenile delinquents who are sent to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. Despite its criticisms, The 100 remains a popular and critically acclaimed show. It is a show that is sure to entertain and keep you on the edge of your seat.

The 14th Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso, was born in 1935 in Taktser village, Amdo, Tibet. He was selected as the tulku of the 13th Dalai Lama in 1937 and formally recognized as the 14th Dalai Lama at a public declaration near the town of Bumchen in 1939. During the 1959 Tibetan uprising, the Dalai Lama fled to India, where he currently lives as a refugee.

The Dalai Lama is a Buddhist monk and the spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism. He is also a Nobel Peace Prize laureate and a global advocate for peace, compassion, and human rights. He has traveled extensively throughout the world, giving teachings and meeting with leaders of all faiths.

The Dalai Lama's teachings are based on the Buddhist principle of compassion. He believes that all beings are interconnected and that we have a responsibility to help others. He also believes that we can achieve inner peace through meditation and mindfulness.

The Dalai Lama is a powerful voice for peace and compassion in the world. He has inspired millions of people with his teachings and his example. He is a true global leader and a beacon of hope for a better future.

The 2005 Hindu Kush earthquake was a magnitude 6.5 earthquake that struck northeastern Afghanistan on December 12, 2005, at 21:47 UTC. The epicenter was near the town of Hindu Kush, about 100 kilometers (62 mi) northeast of Kabul. The earthquake caused widespread damage in Afghanistan and Pakistan, killing more than 5,000 people and injuring more than 20,000. The earthquake also caused significant damage to infrastructure, including roads, bridges, and buildings.

The Hindu Kush is a mountain range that stretches near the Afghan-Pakistan border, from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan. The Hindu Kush range has numerous high snow-capped peaks, with the highest point in the Hindu Kush being Tirich Mir or Terichmir at 7,708 meters (25,289 feet) in the Chitral District of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan.

The 2005 Hindu Kush earthquake was caused by the movement of the Indian and Eurasian tectonic plates. The Indian plate is moving northward at a rate of about 4 centimeters (1.6 inches) per year. As the Indian plate moves northward, it collides with the Eurasian plate. This collision causes the Indian plate to deform and eventually break, which releases energy in the form of earthquakes.

The 2005 Hindu Kush earthquake was a reminder of the seismic hazard that exists in the Hindu Kush region. The region is located in a tectonically active area, and earthquakes are a common occurrence. The earthquake also highlighted the need for improved building codes and construction practices in the region.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish athlete, broke the Scottish 1500m record on February 25, 2016, with a time of 4:19.12. She finished second in the race, behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. Muir's time is the second-fastest ever run by a British woman, behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir is hoping to secure a spot on the British team for the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. She will compete in the British trials in Birmingham from June 24 to 26.

Rosie O'Donnell, a 50-year-old American actress, comedian, and talk show host, had a heart attack last week. She wrote about her experience on her blog, saying that she was "lucky to be here" after falling ill at home and looking up her symptoms online. O'Donnell wrote that she searched "women's heart attack symptoms", which included sudden nausea and aches, before taking a few aspirin. She visited a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent into an artery that was 99 per cent blocked. O'Donnell said her chest began to ache last week and she became nauseous and feverish after helping a woman who was struggling to get out of her car in her Nyack village home, near New York. In the blog entry on her website, a poem entitled "my heart attack", O'Donnell revealed the type of attack was known as the "widow maker". The star, who has acted in several films and TV shows including Drop Dead Diva, Will and Grace and Nip/Tuck, also said she did not call the emergency services. However, she issued a warning to her readers: "Know the symptoms ladies, listen to the voice inside, the one we all so easily ignore, call 911." She recently hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network but the daily talk and gameshow was cancelled in March due to low ratings.

A 56-foot converted trawler was taking on water 6 miles west of South Stack, Anglesey, Wales, on Saturday, February 25, 2023. The crew radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST, and the Holyhead coastguard launched a lifeboat. The lifeboat crew placed a pump on board the boat and towed it to Holyhead. The boat was not in danger of sinking, and the crew were not injured.

British artist David Simpson has won the 2023 John Moores Painting Prize for his work Squint (19). The 76-year-old, who received the £25,000 prize at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery, was one of the shortlisted artists in 1991. Simpson, who has also made the prize longlist on three other occasions, said finally winning was "very nice indeed".

Judge Ansel Krut said Squint (19) was "quite extraordinary", even though it was a "difficult painting to look at". The work depicts a leper squint, which Simpson said were "holes made in the sides of medieval churches so the undesirables could look through to the service and somehow take part". He said it was one of a series of paintings he has been working on, some of which were "much bigger".

The relatively small size of Squint (19) - which is about 7ft (2.1m) in height - was one of the reasons Simpson entered it into the competition, though he also admitted that it "seemed to be a good idea to send one that I was conversant with and was working with". He said the prize money would be spent on "stretches, canvas and - particularly - good quality paints". "I spend a lot of money on materials, so this money is going to go to a good cause."

Krut said Simpson's piece was "a little bit like a tone poem - when you spend some time with it, it gradually starts to build a picture". "Technically, it's very subtle and his language is very minimal, very reduced, but when you enter into it, you get into this broad field of great sympathy, because of the subject matter. "We couldn't have asked for a better painting."

Established in 1957, the biennial John Moores Painting Prize is one of Britain's oldest art awards. Previous winners include David Hockney and Peter Doig. Sir Peter Blake, who is now the prize's patron, won the junior title in 1961.

The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy (in a dual role) and directed by Ron Underwood. The film is set in 2089 on the moon, where Pluto Nash (Murphy) owns a nightclub called "The Blue Moon". When a group of mobsters try to take over his club, Pluto must team up with a beautiful singer (Rene Russo) and a wise-cracking robot (Jim Brown) to save his business.

The film was a critical and commercial failure, grossing only $7.1 million worldwide against a production budget of $100 million. It was nominated for four Razzie Awards, including Worst Picture, Worst Actor (Murphy), Worst Supporting Actress (Russo), and Worst Screenplay.

Despite its poor reception, The Adventures of Pluto Nash has developed a cult following in recent years. Some fans appreciate the film's campiness and over-the-top action sequences. Others enjoy Murphy's dual performance and the film's retro-futuristic setting.

Whether you love it or hate it, The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a unique and unforgettable film. It's a must-see for fans of science fiction, action comedies, and Eddie Murphy.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in results declared from Saturday's elections. It is the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military ruled ended in 1999. It lost the presidential poll last month for the first time. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May, after he defeated President Goodluck Jonathan.

The PDP's decline has been reinforced by results from Saturday's elections for governors and state assemblies, reports the BBC's Bashir Saad Abdullahi from the capital, Abuja. The party lost for the first time in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, the home of outgoing Vice-President Namadi Sambo. It also lost control of Adamawa, one of three states badly hit by militant Islamist group Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the party managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. Taraba is the only result still outstanding, while the election in Imo state was declared inconclusive, because the number of spoilt ballot papers was larger than the margin of victory. Elections were not held in seven states.

Analysis: Chris Ewokor, BBC Africa, Abuja

The APC has made historic gains, relegating the once-powerful PDP to a regional party. The PDP failed to get a national spread of votes, doing well only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. Most states in the north went to the APC, along with Nigeria's commercial hub, Lagos, in the south-west. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states. This will be of huge concern to President-elect Muhammadu Buhari, as militant groups could disrupt oil production and starve the federal government of much-needed oil revenue.  It is unlikely that the PDP governors in the five states would help Gen Buhari rein in the militants.

In parts of the country, the elections were marred by violence due to stiff rivalry, and the battle for power and money. Ethnic differences also fuelled the conflict in some areas, but overall the elections have been more peaceful than in previous years, raising hopes that Nigeria's democracy is maturing.

Why Jonathan lost?

Buhari's historic victory

Nigeria's 36 governors enjoy wide powers and are extremely influential. Some, especially in oil-producing areas, control bigger budgets than those of national governments in some neighbouring West African countries.

The Independent National Electoral Commission (Inec) reported 66 violent incidents at polling stations - higher than in the presidential poll. Most of the violence took place in Rivers and other southern states, where voting at some polling stations had to be extended.

On Sunday, Inec also announced that the APC had retained power in Lagos state. It means that when Gen Buhari takes over the presidency it will be the first time that the party of the president has controlled Lagos - the commercial capital - since the advent of multi-party democracy in 1999.

Our correspondent says the PDP will have to go through a period of introspection, and then rebuild itself under a new leader. The party was in power for 16 years, and voters felt that it was time for change, he says. It had been hit by the defection of governors and MPs to the APC ahead of the elections. The PDP also faced widespread allegations of corruption during its rule, and was accused of failing to do enough to end an Islamist-led insurgency in the north-east where it suffered huge defeats.

The Apple II is an 8-bit home computer designed primarily by Steve Wozniak and manufactured by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.). It was introduced in 1977 and was one of the first highly successful mass-produced microcomputer products. The Apple II was a significant breakthrough in the history of personal computing, and it helped to popularize the use of home computers.

This made it more affordable than other home computers at the time, and it also appealed to users who wanted to learn more about how computers worked. The Apple II was also one of the first home computers to be equipped with a color display, which made it more visually appealing than other home computers.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) in Singapore has returned a 1,000-year-old bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari to India. The sculpture was purchased by the ACM in 2007 from New York dealer Art of the Past, but the company's manager later admitted selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the bronze being returned. The allegations first came to light during a 2012 court case against the firm for trafficking antiquities.

The sculpture is thought to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu in southern India. The decision to return the item came after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Indian government body looking after its antiquities, the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The ASI submitted an official request for the return of the sculpture in May, according to the museum.

"While there is no conclusive proof that the sculpture was stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India, ACM took note of the confession of Aaron Freedman, who was the manager of Art of the Past, of dealing in looted Indian antiquities and of criminal possession of 150 stolen objects," the museum said in a statement.

It was one of 30 objects ACM bought from the art dealer, although none of the others are thought to be listed as stolen. The ASI was reportedly allowed to view them, anyway. The museum said it will take legal action to get compensation for the apparent fraud.

The return of the sculpture is a victory for the ASI, which has been working to recover stolen antiquities for years. It is also a reminder of the importance of provenance research when acquiring works of art.

Tesco, the British supermarket giant, has agreed to sell its loss-making US food chain Fresh & Easy to Yucaipa Companies, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm. The deal is worth £150m, but part of that is a loan which may be paid back. Also, if Yucaipa is successful and the business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake.

Fresh & Easy, which operates 200 stores across California, Nevada and Arizona, has lost money since opening in 2007. Tesco did not specify which stores are being transferred to Yucaipa, but it is understood the remaining 50 shops will be closed.

Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees are to transfer to the new business as part of the deal. Tesco said in a statement that this is an "orderly and efficient exit from the US market".

Under the terms of the deal, Tesco will loan the new business around £80m. Yucaipa is a Los Angeles based private equity company focused on supermaket and restaurant businesses and is run by billionaire investor Ron Burkle.

In April of this year, Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years.

Dame Sarah Storey won her 16th Paralympic gold medal in the women's C5 time trial on Wednesday, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland.

The 37-year-old Briton, who is targeting further Paralympic success at next year's Games in Rio de Janeiro, said: "It's a massive relief to win. I've been working really hard for this and it's great to see it pay off."

Storey is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals. She has won 11 gold, eight silver and three bronze medals in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. She won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and has now won 21 world titles across both sports.

Storey began her sporting career in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005. She has since become one of the most successful athletes in Paralympic history.

In the time trial, Storey set a new world record of 32 minutes and 32.22 seconds to finish ahead of Harkowska (34:35.22) and Germany's Denise Schindler (34:40.22).

Storey said: "I'm really happy with that. I knew it was going to be a tough race, but I was able to put in a good performance and come away with the win."

Storey will now turn her attention to the road race on Saturday, where she will be looking to win her 17th Paralympic gold medal.

Hereford United was expelled from the Football Conference on 10 June 2014 after failing to meet a deadline to pay their football creditors. The club had been in financial trouble for some time, and their expulsion was the culmination of a long-running saga.

The Bulls' fate had been in the balance since the full extent of their financial worries emerged in the weeks since their dramatic final-day escape sent Chester down instead. Chester have been reinstated as a Conference Premier club and Hayes & Yeading will stay in Conference South.

The Conference had originally offered a payment deadline of Thursday, 5 June. The club's debt to their football creditors, including former boss Martin Foyle, members of the current squad, other club staff and clubs from whom the Bulls loaned players during the 2013-14 season, added up to £148,000. That deadline was extended three times, to Friday, 6 June, then again to Saturday, 7 June and for a third time until Thursday, 12 June. But it became clear on Tuesday that the Bulls, taken over last week by London businessman Tommy Agombar, would not make that deadline - and the Conference has now acted.

The last team to be expelled from the Conference was Chester City in February 2010. They reformed as Chester FC two months later - and it is now they who have taken the Bulls' place, following a dramatic final day of the season when, almost simultaneously, a late Hereford winning goal at Aldershot and a Salisbury equaliser at Chester kept the Bulls up. By way of an added twist, Chester announced on Tuesday that Kingsley James, who was in Hereford's team that day, has moved to Bumpers Lane.

Hereford United Supporters' Trust make offer to buy the club for £1 and clear their £220,000 debts

Former Bulls boss Martin Foyle serves winding-up petition over unpaid wages, after players reveal they have not been fully paid too

Case adjourned for 28 days at Royal Court of Justice

Tommy Agombar takes over as new Hereford owner

Hereford fail to meet 17:00 BST deadline to pay football creditors, and are threatened with expulsion, subject to Conference board vote

Hereford meet with Conference board and are given new deadline of 7 June. The deadline is moved to 9 June, then 12 June

Hereford expelled from Football Conference

And former Hereford boss Foyle, now manager at Southport, chose the same day to sign another player from that same Bulls team, keeper Dan Lloyd-Weston, who opted to leave as he was still owed part of his salary.

When last season ended, despite months of fundraising efforts by fans, as well as generous donations from fans of other clubs, the Bulls faced debts of approximately £225,000. They still owe over £70,000 to clear the latest PAYE tax demand from HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).

An offer was made by one of the club's main fan bodies, the Hereford United Supporters' Trust (HUST), on the back of pledges made by their backers, to buy the club for £1 and take over the running at Edgar Street. But, although chairman David Keyte held talks with them, they were not the preferred option. Keyte was reported to have been in talks with three different rival bidders before Agombar's takeover.

The downward spiral of Hereford's financial situation since being relegated from the Football League in May 2012 has been exacerbated by falling gates. The average attendance for the 2013-14 season at Edgar Street was 1,758, little over half the average gate they attracted of 3,270 in League Two just five years ago.

The expulsion of Hereford United is a sad day for football. The club has a proud history, dating back to 1892, and has produced some great players, including England internationals John Aldridge and Kevin Keegan. But the club's financial problems have been well-documented for some time, and their expulsion from the Conference was the inevitable outcome.

It is a shame that Hereford United has been forced to go out of business, but it is important to remember that the club is more than just its players and its staff. It is also the fans, who have shown great loyalty and support over the years. The fans will be the ones who suffer most from the club's demise, and it is to them that our thoughts go at this difficult time.

The Electoral Commission has raised concerns about the number of duplicate applications to vote in the 2017 general election. It said that a significant proportion of applications were likely to have been duplicates, and that this had caused significant administration and financial burdens for electoral officials. The watchdog said that this issue should be addressed by clearer information on registration sites, including potentially a verification function.

The Electoral Commission also said that it took the issue of double voting very seriously, and that anyone with information should contact the police. It stressed that although some people - including students and those with second homes - may lawfully be able to register in more than one constituency and cast more than one vote in local elections, voting twice in a general election was an offence punishable by an unlimited fine.

Labour's shadow minister for voter engagement, Cat Smith, said voting twice was a serious offence and police needed to have the resources to prosecute people suspected of doing so. "A blanket ban on being registered at two addresses would exclude those who for reasons of work or study need to be registered in two places," she said. "This cannot be an attempt to make it harder for young people and students to register to vote."

In May 2014, Sinn Féin MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted that he wondered how many people Tom Elliott, a member of the Ulster Defence Regiment (UDR), had harassed and shot. Elliott served in the UDR for 10 years and has a clear MoD record. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour of posting it.

The Freeport Doctrine was a political doctrine articulated by Stephen A. Douglas during the 1858 Illinois Senate race. The doctrine stated that the federal government could not interfere with slavery in the territories, as long as the people of the territory did not want it. This doctrine was in direct opposition to the Republican Party's platform, which called for the containment of slavery.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Douglas in response to a question posed by Abraham Lincoln during the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates. Lincoln asked Douglas how he would enforce the Fugitive Slave Act in a territory where the people had voted against slavery. Douglas responded by saying that the people of the territory could decide for themselves whether or not to enforce the law. This response angered many Republicans, who saw it as a betrayal of the principle of popular sovereignty.

The Freeport Doctrine was a major factor in Douglas's defeat in the 1858 Senate race. It also helped to split the Democratic Party, as many southern Democrats opposed the doctrine. The doctrine would later be used by Abraham Lincoln to justify his decision to issue the Emancipation Proclamation.

The Freeport Doctrine was a significant event in the history of the United States. It helped to shape the debate over slavery and ultimately led to the Civil War.

The Penibaetic System is the southernmost of the three systems of mountain ranges of the Baetic System in the southern Iberian Peninsula. The Penibaetic System is a complex mountain range, with a variety of different geological features. The highest peak in the Penibaetic System is Mulhacén, which is 3,478 meters (11,411 feet) tall. The Penibaetic System is a popular destination for hiking, climbing, and skiing.

The Road to El Dorado is a 2000 American animated musical adventure comedy film produced by DreamWorks Animation and released by DreamWorks Pictures. It was directed by Bibo Bergeron, Don Bluth, and Gary Trousdale, and stars Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Rosie Perez, Armand Assante, Edward James Olmos, Jim Cummings, and Tobin Bell. The film is set in the 16th century and tells the story of two Spanish con men, Tulio and Miguel, who find a map to the legendary city of El Dorado. They are pursued by the conquistador Hernán Cortés and his army, and must use their wits and cunning to stay one step ahead of them. Along the way, they encounter a beautiful princess, Chel, and must help her save her people from Cortés.

The film was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $347 million worldwide. It was praised for its animation, music, and humor. The film was nominated for two Academy Awards, for Best Original Song and Best Original Score.

The film's plot is as follows:

Tulio and Miguel are two Spanish con men who are down on their luck. The S&P BSE SENSEX is a stock market index of 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is one of the 30 companies that make up the SENSEX. It is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

The SENSEX is a free-float market-weighted index, which means that the weight of each company in the index is based on the free-float market capitalization of the company. The free-float market capitalization is the market capitalization of the company after taking into account the number of shares that are available for trading.

The SENSEX is a widely followed index and is considered to be a good indicator of the performance of the Indian stock market. The index is calculated and published by the Bombay Stock Exchange.

The SENSEX was launched on January 1, 1986, with a base value of 100. The index has since grown to over 50,000 points. The highest level that the SENSEX has reached was 61,245.73 points on January 21, 2008. The lowest level that the SENSEX has reached was 2,659.85 points on March 29, 2009.

The SENSEX is a good indicator of the performance of the Indian economy. The index has been on a bull run since 2014, and has reached record highs. The bull run is being driven by strong economic growth in India, as well as by foreign investment.

The SENSEX is a good investment for investors who are looking to invest in the Indian economy. The index is a good way to gain exposure to the Indian stock market, and to the performance of the Indian economy.

Saturn Corporation, also known as Saturn LLC, is a registered trademark established on January 7, 1985, as a subsidiary of General Motors. It was created to compete with Japanese automakers in the United States market. Saturn was known for its innovative marketing and customer service, as well as its focus on quality and value. The company was discontinued in 2009.

Saturn was founded by General Motors CEO Roger Smith in 1985. Smith believed that GM needed to create a new brand to compete with Japanese automakers, which were gaining market share in the United States. Saturn was designed to be a different kind of car company, with a focus on customer service and quality.

Saturn's first car, the S-Series, was introduced in 1990. The S-Series was a front-wheel drive sedan that was available in three body styles: coupe, sedan, and wagon. The S-Series was well-received by critics and consumers, and it helped to establish Saturn as a credible competitor in the US market.

In 1993, Saturn introduced the L-Series, a midsize sedan. The L-Series was also well-received, and it helped to further solidify Saturn's reputation for quality and value.

In 1996, Saturn introduced the Vue, a compact SUV. The Vue was a success, and it helped to expand Saturn's product lineup.

In 2002, Saturn introduced the Aura, a midsize sedan. The Aura was a critical and commercial success, and it helped to further cement Saturn's reputation as a quality automaker.

In 2009, General Motors announced that it would be discontinuing the Saturn brand. The decision was made due to declining sales and the need to focus on GM's core brands.

Saturn was a successful brand that helped to change the way that cars were marketed and sold in the United States. The company's focus on customer service and quality helped to make it a popular choice for consumers. Saturn's legacy will continue to live on in the cars that it produced and the people who drove them.

Scotland women's national football team is currently in pole position to qualify for the 2017 UEFA Women's Euro. They have won all five of their qualifiers so far and host Iceland on Friday, September 1st. A win would all but secure their place in the finals.

Striker Jane Ross is desperate to make it to the finals after play-off losses for Euro 2013 and last year's World Cup. "Now that we're in this position, it would be devastating," she said. "We've been so close and fallen at the last hurdle twice now trying to get to major competitions. It would be more heartbreak than humiliation."

Iceland, ranked one place above the Scots at number 20 in the world, are also unbeaten after four wins from four. The outcome of Friday's contest and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September is likely to decide who tops the group.

"Obviously reaching the finals is everyone's aim," said 24-year-old Bayern Munich forward Evans. "It's been my aim since I got into the squad, and [veteran goalkeeper] Gemma Fay has been aiming for it for 15 years. I think it's going to be emotional if we do get there, although we're taking it step by step, trying not to think too far ahead."

With the best six of the eight group runners-up also qualifying automatically, Scotland are in pole position to reach next summer's finals in the Netherlands without the need for a play-off.

"Iceland are top seeds in the group," Evans noted. "They're a really good side and we've always had tough games against them. But we know we've got a really good chance to beat them. It would be fantastic to have a big crowd at Falkirk. Having the fans behind us makes a huge difference."

Evans is one of 12 players in the current 20-strong squad who play outside Scotland, with five at English clubs, four in Sweden and two at Seattle Reign in the United States National Women's Soccer League, including newly-crowned BBC Women's Footballer of the Year Kim Little.

Perth-born Evans recently celebrated winning the women's Bundesliga in her first season at Bayern, rubbing shoulders with the likes of Franck Ribery and Arjen Robben as they joined the victorious men's squad for a rapturous reception on the balcony at Munich's New Town Hall.

"It was mind-blowing, completely mind-blowing," she recalled. "There were thousands of people cheering when we came out. We had a party with the men's team on the Saturday night, having been in their stadium on the Saturday just to get congratulated. I actually walked out with Franck Ribery at the Town Hall, but, in the photos, Arjen Robben is in the background. I don't know them very well, but they were all really chatty, really good with us."

Evans, who won four Scottish Women's Premier League titles and six domestic cups with Glasgow City before moving to Germany with Turbine Potsdam, believes the benefits of having more players in the world's top leagues benefits the national team as they close in on a first major finals.

"Germany has been at the top of women's football for a long time now - it has really developed over there," she added. "The league is good, arguably one of the best in the world for competitiveness, and we have a hard game every week. Even within the Bayern set-up, there is such good competition. Just being able to train with those players every day makes you better. I'm really privileged. The league in Scotland is improving, but the girls playing abroad bring something different. It is a different culture, a new way of playing, and that adds to the national team."

Blackpool and Colchester United played out a 1-1 draw in League One on Saturday. Jamille Matt gave Blackpool the lead after 12 minutes, but Kurtis Guthrie equalised for Colchester from close range after 17 minutes. Blackpool had chances to win the game, but Tom Aldred headed wide from close range and Jim McAlister had a shot saved. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was shown a straight red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

Here are some key points from the match:

* Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso jinked past his man and delivered a pinpoint chip into the area, where Jamille Matt turned the ball home from three yards.
* Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe denied Matthew Briggs with a sensational save to push the ball behind after 17 minutes, but the visitors did equalise from the resulting corner as Kurtis Guthrie prodded in from close range after a goalmouth scramble.
* Somehow, Colchester failed to re-take the lead on the stroke of half-time as Slocombe produced a brilliant save from George Elokobi's close-range effort, before Guthrie headed against the bar from two yards.
* Blackpool should have clinched the win 15 minutes from time, as Tom Aldred was found unmarked from a corner, but he headed wide from eight yards.
* Colchester finished the game with 10 men, after substitute Sean Murray was shown a straight red for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

Overall, it was a disappointing result for Blackpool, who will feel they should have won the game. However, they will take heart from the performance of their goalkeeper, Sam Slocombe, who made a number of excellent saves.

Novak Djokovic and Nenad Zimonjic lost to Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in the men's doubles final at the Rio Olympics. The Serbs lost 6-4 6-4.
