A fire broke out on a ferry travelling from Mallorca to Valencia on Tuesday afternoon. The fire quickly spread and the ship was evacuated. At least three people were injured and taken to hospital. The ship is now adrift and may sink.

The fire broke out on one of the car decks of the ferry, the Sorrento. The cause of the fire is not yet known. The fire quickly spread and the ship was evacuated. The passengers and crew were taken to safety on lifeboats.

At least three people were injured in the fire. One person is reported to be seriously hurt. The injured were taken to hospital by helicopter.

The ship is now adrift and may sink. The Spanish authorities are working to salvage the ship.

The fire is a major incident and has caused widespread disruption. The passengers and crew are safe, but the ship is a total loss. The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

The South Wales Coalfield is a large region of south Wales that is rich in coal deposits. It is located in the South Wales Valleys, which are a series of valleys running south from the Brecon Beacons to the Bristol Channel. The coalfield is one of the largest in Europe, and it has been a major source of coal for the British economy for centuries. The coalfield is also home to a number of important industrial towns, including Merthyr Tydfil, Newport, and Cardiff.

The South Wales Coalfield was formed during the Carboniferous period, when the area was covered by a shallow sea. The seabed was rich in organic matter, which was buried and compressed over time to form coal. The coalfield was first exploited in the 18th century, and it reached its peak production in the early 20th century. However, the coal industry declined in the second half of the 20th century, and the last deep mine in the South Wales Coalfield closed in 2015.

The South Wales Coalfield is a significant part of Welsh history and culture. The coal industry played a major role in the development of the Welsh economy, and it also had a profound impact on Welsh society. The coalfield was a major source of employment for many Welsh people, and it also helped to shape the Welsh identity.

The South Wales Coalfield is a beautiful and important part of Wales. It is a place of great natural beauty, and it is also home to a rich history and culture. The coalfield is a place that is worth visiting, and it is a place that is worth learning about.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior White House official who acts as the spokesperson for the executive branch of the United States government. The press secretary is appointed by the president and serves at the president's pleasure. The position does not require the advice and consent of the U.S. Senate. The press secretary is responsible for providing information to the media about the president, senior executives, and policies. The press secretary also holds regular press briefings. The position is a very prominent non-Cabinet post.

Here are some of the most notable White House Press Secretaries in history:

* James Brady: Brady served as press secretary under President Ronald Reagan from 1981 to 1989. He was seriously injured in the assassination attempt on Reagan in 1981 and remained partially paralyzed for the rest of his life.
* Dee Dee Myers: Myers served as press secretary under President Bill Clinton from 1993 to 1998. She was the first woman to hold the position.
* Ari Fleischer: Fleischer served as press secretary under President George W. Bush from 2001 to 2003. He was known for his aggressive style and his defense of the Bush administration's policies.
* Dana Perino: Perino served as press secretary under President George W. Bush from 2007 to 2009. She was the first woman to hold the position on a full-time basis.
* Jay Carney: Carney served as press secretary under President Barack Obama from 2011 to 2014. He was known for his calm demeanor and his ability to handle difficult questions from the media.
* Josh Earnest: Earnest served as press secretary under President Barack Obama from 2014 to 2017. He was known for his sense of humor and his ability to connect with the media.
* Sarah Huckabee Sanders: Sanders served as press secretary under President Donald Trump from 2017 to 2019. She was known for her loyalty to Trump and her willingness to defend his policies.
* Stephanie Grisham: Grisham served as press secretary under President Donald Trump from 2019 to 2020. She was known for her close relationship with Melania Trump and her defense of the Trump administration's policies.
* Jen Psaki: Psaki served as press secretary under President Joe Biden from 2021 to 2022. She was known for her calm demeanor and her ability to handle difficult questions from the media.
* Karine Jean-Pierre: Jean-Pierre is the current press secretary under President Joe Biden. She is the first Black woman and first openly LGBTQ person to hold the position.

The 2017 Where We Are on TV report by GLAAD found that 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters appeared on scripted broadcast, cable and streaming series in the 2016-17 season. This is an increase of 10% from the previous year. The report also found that 16 transgender characters appeared on TV this year, up from seven in 2016.

However, the report also found that more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off on TV this year. This includes characters like Poussey Washington and Bea Smith, who met violent ends in Orange is the New Black and Wentworth respectively.

The report also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, thanks mostly to shows like Empire, Luke Cage and How to Get Away with Murder.

GLAAD's president Sarah Kate Ellis said it was "heartening to see progress being made" but said numbers were "only part of the story". She said that it was important to look at the quality of the representation of LGBT characters on TV, and to ensure that they are not just token characters.

The report also found that LGBT characters are still underrepresented on TV, making up only 4.4% of all characters on scripted broadcast, cable and streaming series. This is below the percentage of LGBT people in the US population, which is estimated to be 4.5%.

The report also found that LGBT characters are more likely to be portrayed as villains or criminals than straight characters. For example, 20% of LGBT characters on TV were villains or criminals, compared to only 10% of straight characters.

The report also found that LGBT characters are more likely to be killed off on TV than straight characters. For example, 10% of LGBT characters on TV were killed off, compared to only 6% of straight characters.

The report's findings suggest that there is still a long way to go to achieve full and accurate representation of LGBT people on TV. However, the report also shows that progress is being made, and that there is a growing awareness of the importance of LGBT representation on TV.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun in Winchburgh, Scotland. She survived, but her left back leg had to be amputated. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to come forward.

The Scottish government held a consultation on licensing air weapons last year, but a majority of respondents opposed the plan. The Scottish SPCA is calling on the government to implement licensing as a matter of urgency.

Air guns are dangerous weapons that can cause serious injuries or death. They should only be used by people who have a legitimate reason for doing so. The Scottish government should introduce licensing to ensure that only responsible people have access to air guns.

J. Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur who has made significant contributions to the fields of genomics and synthetic biology. He is best known for his role in the Human Genome Project, which sequenced the human genome, and for his work on creating the first synthetic life form.

Venter was born in 1946 in Salt Lake City, Utah. He showed an early interest in science and engineering, and he earned a bachelor's degree in biochemistry from the University of California, San Diego in 1969. He then went on to earn a Ph.D. in molecular biology from the University of California, San Francisco in 1975.

After completing his Ph.D., Venter worked as a research scientist at the National Institutes of Health (NIH). In 1984, he co-founded the Institute for Genomic Research (TIGR), a private research institute that focused on sequencing genomes. TIGR was one of the first institutions to use automated sequencing technology, and it played a leading role in the Human Genome Project.

In 1998, Venter left TIGR to found Celera Genomics, a company that was dedicated to sequencing the human genome faster than the public project. Celera's efforts were successful, and the company published the first draft of the human genome in 2000.

After the completion of the Human Genome Project, Venter turned his attention to synthetic biology. In 2006, he founded the J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI), which is dedicated to the study of synthetic biology. JCVI was the first institution to create a synthetic life form, which it did in 2010.

Venter's work has been controversial at times, but he is widely respected as a pioneer in the fields of genomics and synthetic biology. He has received numerous awards for his work, including the National Medal of Science and the Lasker Award.

In addition to his scientific work, Venter is also a successful entrepreneur. He has founded several companies, including TIGR, Celera Genomics, and JCVI. He is also the author of several books, including "A Life Decoded" and "The Sorcerer's Apprentice."

Venter is a visionary scientist who has made significant contributions to our understanding of life. His work has the potential to revolutionize many fields, including medicine, agriculture, and energy. He is a true pioneer in the field of synthetic biology, and his work is sure to have a profound impact on the world in the years to come.

The bodies of Hannah Witheridge, 23, and David Miller, 24, were discovered on a beach in Koh Tao, Thailand on September 15, 2014. Two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, were arrested and charged with the murders. The UK police have now completed their review of the Thai police investigation and will be returning to the UK to compile their report and update the families of Hannah and David on their findings. The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns about the police investigation, but the Thai authorities have denied any wrongdoing. The two suspects are due to stand trial in Thailand in January 2015.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. A man in his 80s was also taken to hospital. Detectives want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the death. He is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build. He is believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Anyone with information has been urged to contact police or Crimestoppers.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a 17-year-old boy, was stabbed to death in an alleyway in Kenton, London, on Saturday night. He had been at a party in the area when a fight broke out. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed in the incident and is in a stable condition in hospital. A 21-year-old man, two 15-year-old boys and a 14-year-old boy have been arrested in connection with the stabbing.

A boy from Northern Ireland has been waiting for a place at a special school for over six months. His mother has had to give up her job to look after him, and he is missing out on education and social interaction. The Education Authority has said that it is reviewing the need for special school places, but the boy's mother is worried that this situation will happen to other families.

The boy's mother told the BBC that her son does not understand why his brother and sister are able to go to school but he is not. "He really misses being around people, he doesn't like being isolated, but unfortunately the way the system has been working so far has actually worked to isolate him more," she said.

The family has now been told that an extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school and the hope is that their son will be able to start there in the next few weeks. However, the boy's mother is worried that this same situation will happen to other families as the special needs school system is packed to capacity.

"The schools are being put in the position where they have a family like us who desperately require a place in the school, but they really have no capacity there because the school is already over-subscribed," she said.

The BBC asked the Education Authority for a response to the concerns the family has raised but its spokesperson said they could not comment on individual cases. "As we have a duty to protect the privacy rights of the child, it would be unacceptable to publicly discuss their specific and highly sensitive needs", they said.

In relation to special school provision in general, they said the Education Authority was "currently reviewing the profile of need for special school places in Northern Ireland and is endeavouring to ensure that places are available close to where the children reside".

"This work is ongoing and is designed to assist with the placement of children with effect from 2016," the spokesperson added.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared in 2002 at the age of five, was found living with his father in Cleveland, Ohio. His father, Bobby Hernandez, was arrested and charged with tampering with records. Julian's mother has been notified of his recovery.

The FBI received a tip on October 30 that Julian may be the long-missing child after problems he had applying for college. The agency worked with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm the boy's identity.

Julian's father is also charged with tampering with records in Ohio so he could obtain a driver's licence in 2012. He is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 (Â£164,100) bail.

Authorities suspected around the time of the boy's disappearance that his father was possibly the culprit. A missing persons database shows that Mr Hernandez said he was taking his son to pre-school in August 2002 but then fled.

The Isle of Wight Council has offered free crossings on the Cowes chain ferry until 2 July in recognition of the problems that have plagued the new vessel since it launched in May. The council has also ordered a review of the project by auditors.

The chain ferry has broken down, run aground and been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to "training issues". Cars have also been damaged getting on and off.

Shopkeeper Angie Booth, who owns Valu-4-U in East Cowes, said: "Whether I come out of this and survive I am not sure - other businesses too. We are bearing the brunt of the loss of almost six months of trade. "Will you compensate local businesses, the same as for damaged cars?"

Transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation was up for discussion. He added: "I don't think it's a disaster. It's a prototype. There are bound to be teething problems. There were electrical problems which the company has rectified."

He said the council authorised the manufacture of ramp extensions to resolve the problem of vehicles scraping the concrete. He said groundings were an issue with seamanship, which had been resolved.

The council has also said it will be holding a public meeting to discuss the problems with the ferry.

The new chain ferry in Cowes has been plagued with problems since it launched in May. It has broken down, run aground, and been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Cars have also been damaged getting on and off.

The council has ordered a review of the project and is offering free crossings until 2 July to allow feedback. Compensation for local businesses is up for discussion.

The council leader said it had been a "frustrating and disappointing start" to the ferry. Transport councillor Ian Ward said he did not think it was a disaster, but acknowledged there had been problems.

Manchester City and Chelsea have been charged by the Football Association following the mass brawl that marred their Premier League clash on Sunday.

The charge follows the mass fracas in the 95th minute of the game at Etihad Stadium, which Chelsea won 3-1. City had forward Sergio Aguero and midfielder Fernandinho sent off, but Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas will not face any further action.

City manager Pep Guardiola apologised for his team's part in the incident. Aguero, 28, received a four-match ban for what was his second dismissal for violent conduct this season, following a high and late challenge on Chelsea defender David Luiz. Fernandinho clashed with Fabregas in the scuffle that followed Aguero's challenge, and the Brazil midfielder will serve a three-match ban.

Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

The FA said in a statement: "Manchester City and Chelsea have been charged following their Premier League fixture on Sunday [3 December 2017].

"It is alleged that both clubs failed to ensure their players conducted themselves in an orderly fashion during the 95th minute of the fixture.

"The clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December 2017 to respond to the charge."

The incident occurred after Aguero was shown a red card for a high challenge on Luiz. Fernandinho then clashed with Fabregas, and both players were also sent off.

Guardiola apologised for his team's part in the incident after the match.

"I apologise for what happened," he said. "It was a bad situation. I don't like it. I don't like it when my players do it.

"I don't like it when the other team does it. It's not good for football.

"I apologise to the fans, to the Premier League, to the referee. It's not good."

Aguero's four-match ban means he will miss City's next four Premier League games against West Ham, Bournemouth, Stoke and Everton.

Fernandinho's three-match ban means he will miss City's next three Premier League games against West Ham, Bournemouth and Stoke.

Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, has accused Olam, a Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader, of sourcing palm oil from rogue companies that contribute to the haze that is caused by forest fires in Indonesia. Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, have rejected the allegations.

The report says Olam and Temask could be unwittingly encouraging unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to the haze that is caused by the fires. It also says Olam created a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies" that allowed the vast majority of its product to be bought from unknown sources.

But Olam chief executive Sunny Verghese told the BBC that the firm had a "very vigorous sourcing policy and we insist that there is zero tolerance for burning, so it's a 'no burn-no peat-no deforestation' compliance policy". The company only agreed to release the names of its 14 suppliers on Monday, having previously resisted calls by Mighty to do so. Mr Verghese said he believed the firm's current suppliers all met Olam's strict requirements, but added that the vetting and verification process would take several more years to complete. He added that producers who do not comply with the company's sustainable principles would be removed from its supply chain.

Since Temasek is the majority stake holder in Olam, Mighty's allegations could link Singapore's state fund to the devastating annual haze affecting Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia - if the claims of sourcing from rogue palm oil producers are proven. Temasek's investment in Olam means that "the people of Singapore have unwittingly financed what is likely one of the world's black boxes for the kind of unsustainably produced palm oil that fuels the haze," the report says.

Temasek has dismissed the allegations, explaining that they "fully support no-burn policies for land clearance, and would urge oil palm companies and plantation owners to do the same." The fund told the BBC: "Olam's operations are properly matters for the board and management of Olam to address. "As a matter of proper governance, Temasek does not direct the business operations of our portfolio companies, including Olam."

It would be fair to say that the palm oil industry globally has a troubled track record. It is one of the world's biggest industries, projected to be worth $88bn by 2022 but also often accused of unfair and illegal labour practices, as well as deforestation and the burning of plantations. Green groups and palm oil executives often find themselves at loggerheads with one another - NGOs say that the industry is wilfully turning a blind eye to environmentally unfriendly practices, while palm oil executives claim it is an industry-wide problem, and policing third party suppliers is impossible. Activists say governments need to punish palm oil firms that don't comply with acceptable standards of protecting the environment - but changing the government mindset can be challenging, because the reality is many of these firms bring jobs and investment to rural areas.

The report also highlights concerns in the African state of Gabon, where according to Mighty, Olam "bulldozes rainforests to establish monoculture palm oil plantations," bringing the same practices to Africa "that have destroyed vast natural landscapes in Southeast Asia". In response to the accusation that Olam is responsible for vast forest clearings through its joint ventures with the government of Gabon, Olam said its private-public partnerships in the country strove to be both responsible and transparent. "We agree with Gabon's sovereign right to convert a tiny percentage of its least valuable forested land for agriculture, so long as it is responsibly and transparently done," it said. "Our plans and progress for developing sustainable palm oil plantations have been shared transparently with stakeholders and put in the public domain."

The allegations against Olam are serious and could have a significant impact on the company's reputation. If the allegations are proven, they could also lead to calls for sanctions against Olam and Temasek. It remains to be seen how the allegations will be resolved, but they are a reminder of the challenges facing the palm oil industry.

Adrian Gill was a British journalist and writer who died on January 15, 2023, at the age of 68. He was known for his witty and often controversial writing, which appeared in publications such as The Sunday Times, The Spectator, and The Guardian. Gill was also the author of several books, including "The Angry Island" and "The Last Englishman."

Gill was born in Edinburgh, Scotland, in 1954. He studied art at Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design and the Slade School of Fine Art in London. After graduating, he worked as a journalist for several magazines, including The Face and The Independent. In 1983, he began writing for The Sunday Times, where he would remain for the rest of his career.

Gill's writing was often praised for its wit and intelligence. He was also known for his willingness to tackle controversial subjects, such as race, class, and religion. In 1998, he was criticized for describing the Welsh as "dark, ugly little trolls." In 2009, he was censured by the Press Complaints Commission for describing Clare Balding as a "dyke on a bike."

Despite his controversial reputation, Gill was also a popular and respected figure in the British media. He was a regular panelist on the BBC's "Question Time" and was a frequent contributor to other television and radio programs. He was also the author of several best-selling books, including "The Angry Island" and "The Last Englishman."

Gill was diagnosed with cancer in 2022. He died on January 15, 2023, at the age of 68. He is survived by his partner, Nicola Formby, and their two children.

Gill's death was met with widespread tributes from the British media. The Guardian called him "one of the most original and provocative writers of his generation." The Independent said he was "a brilliant and fearless journalist who never shied away from a challenge." The Times said he was "a true original who will be missed by all who knew him."

Gill's legacy will be one of a writer who was unafraid to speak his mind, even when it was unpopular. He was a true original who will be missed by all who knew him.

The 2016 Indian Premier League (IPL) is the tenth season of the Indian Premier League, a professional Twenty20 cricket league established by the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) in 2008. The tournament is being held from 9 April to 29 May 2016. The eight teams that are participating in the tournament are:

* Mumbai Indians
* Kolkata Knight Riders
* Royal Challengers Bangalore
* Sunrisers Hyderabad
* Delhi Daredevils
* Kings XI Punjab
* Chennai Super Kings
* Rising Pune Supergiants

The tournament is being played in a round-robin format, with each team playing each other twice. The top four teams at the end of the league stage will qualify for the play-offs. The play-offs will consist of a qualifier, an eliminator, and the final.

The qualifier will be played between the top two teams in the league stage. The winner of the qualifier will directly qualify for the final, while the loser will play the winner of the eliminator in the second qualifier. The eliminator will be played between the third and fourth placed teams in the league stage. The loser of the eliminator will be eliminated from the tournament, while the winner will play the loser of the qualifier in the second qualifier.

The final will be played between the winners of the qualifier and the second qualifier. The winner of the final will be crowned the champions of the 2016 Indian Premier League.

The following are the leading run-scorers, wicket-takers, and highest individual scores in the 2016 Indian Premier League:

* Leading run-scorers: David Warner (294 runs), Virat Kohli (267 runs), AB de Villiers (249 runs)
* Most wickets: Mitchell McClenaghan (9 wickets), Bhuvneshwar Kumar (8 wickets), Mustafizur Rahman (7 wickets)
* Highest individual score: Quinton de Kock (108 runs), David Warner (90 not out), Gautam Gambhir (90 not out)

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire, on 2023-02-25 at about 14:15 BST. The motorcyclist, who lived locally, was pronounced dead at the scene. The tractor driver was not injured. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle while emergency services were at the scene.

The pound fell against the dollar and euro on Monday, as investors grew increasingly nervous about the possibility of Britain leaving the European Union. The pound was down 0.2% against the dollar at $1.4226. Against the euro, sterling was down 0.6% at â‚¬1.2605 and weakened by 1% against the Japanese yen to just over 151. Investors have been spooked by data showing the chances of a Remain vote have fallen, although markets have also been rattled by global economic worries. With 10 days to go before the referendum vote, two polls at the weekend put the Leave camp ahead, while betting firm Betfair said the implied probability of a vote to Remain had now fallen to 68.5% from almost 80% a week earlier.

"We expect incoming polls to move the pound more aggressively than before," said Charalambos Pissouros, senior analyst at IronFX Global. "If new polls continue to show a tight race between the two campaigns as we approach the voting day, the outcome is likely to become even more uncertain and hence, volatility in sterling is likely to heighten further."

BBC economics editor Kamal Ahmed said hedge funds had been placing bets - short-selling - on expectations that the value of sterling will sink further. "The bears are in town," he said.

Joe Rundle, head of trading at ETX Capital, said the markets were now on full Brexit alert. "Polls show it's now too close to call and markets are responding with some very twitchy activity. Sterling has shed more than 2% in two sessions to retrace its April lows."

Worries about the economic impact of leaving the EU were also blamed for a big fall in Asian stock markets. Japan's Nikkei index closed 3.5% down, while Hong Kong's main index slid 2.5%.

The reaction on London's FTSE 100 was muted initially, with the index down 0.3% in morning trading. However, the FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1% at 6,044.9 points, with Lloyds Banking Group the biggest faller, down 4.2%.

On Sunday, Leave campaigner Nigel Farage told BBC1's Andrew Marr Show that sterling had recently been strengthening. "Sterling is up since March. Since Brexit became a possibility, sterling is up and FTSE is exactly the same level it was in March," he said. He also pointed out that a weaker pound was good for UK exporters. Last week, official figures showed that the UK trade deficit narrowed in April on the back of a jump in exports.

However, many analysts believe that a vote to leave the EU would lead to a sharp fall in the pound, as investors would lose confidence in the UK economy. This would make imports more expensive and could lead to higher inflation. It could also make it more difficult for UK businesses to compete in international markets.

The pound's fall on Monday is a sign of the growing uncertainty about the UK's future in the EU. With just 10 days to go before the referendum, the outcome is still too close to call.

The offices of the Turkish dailies Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked on Thursday morning. The attacks happened almost at the same time, early on Thursday. Windows in both buildings were shattered by the gunfire, Istanbul police said. "Numerous spent bullet casings were also found at both scenes," the police added. They are now hunting the assailants. So far no group has claimed it was behind the attacks.

The two papers support the governing AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The Yeni Akit offices are 20km (12 miles) away from the Yeni Safak building.

Last September, pro-government protesters attacked the offices of the daily Hurriyet, accusing the paper of misquoting President Erdogan.

No casualties were reported in the attacks on Thursday.

On Wednesday, representatives from more than 160 countries decided to set aside a radio frequency for the satellite tracking of planes at the World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC), organised by the UN's International Telecommunication Union (ITU). The deal will enable satellites to receive transmissions, known as automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B), that aircraft currently only send to other aircraft and to ground stations. This will allow "real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world," said Francois Rancy, head of the ITU's Radiocommunication Bureau.

The disappearance of flight MH370 exposed weaknesses in worldwide air navigation systems. The current system leaves around 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. Soon after the plane disappeared, Malaysia's communication minister urged the ITU to help find new ways of transmitting flight data in real-time.

The Malaysia Airlines flight was en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing when air traffic control staff lost contact with it. The plane is long believed to have crashed into the southern Indian Ocean. In July part of an aircraft wing was found on Reunion Island. Malaysian authorities later confirmed the debris to be from the missing MH370 plane.

Following Wednesday's decision, ITU Secretary-General Houlin Zhao said the agency had "responded in record time to the expectations of the global community on the major issue concerning global flight tracking." The UN's aviation arm, the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO), has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines. These will include aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes, or more in case of emergency, reported Reuters.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register an interest in the former Devonport-based ships. The BBC understands no proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. Those who have registered an interest are finalising their bids with viewings set to take place in late February and March. A final decision is not expected until the spring.

The government's Disposal Services Authority, which is handling the sale, wants to award at least one of the frigates to a UK ship recycler to determine the capacity of the UK's industry in the field. Penny Mordaunt, Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, said it was important UK recyclers had the chance to prove themselves in the field but she was also keen to see at least one of them saved from the scrapyard. She added: "For anyone that has served on a ship it's your home, you've literally been through the wars with it... and you want them to have a noble second life. "My preference is to go for the reef and diving attraction. "We've got to get best value for the budget but a reef would also generate income for part of the country through tourism."

The Ministry of Defence has previously said it will "consider all options" for the frigates to ensure "best financial return for the taxpayer". A spokeswoman would not comment on the number or nature of the bids received due to "commercial sensitivity".

Originally designed as a specialist anti-submarine ship, the Type 22 frigate evolved into a powerful surface combatant with substantial anti-surface, anti-submarine and anti-aircraft weapons systems. They were also known for having excellent command and control, and communication facilities, making them ideal flagships on deployments, with a complement of about 280 crew. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for £3m.

Here is a summary of the key points:

* The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour.
* Bidders had until 23 January to register an interest in the former Devonport-based ships.

Kevin Pietersen is looking to make a sensational return to the England cricket team after being sacked in 2014. He posed for the Surrey team photo before the start of the new county championship season, and looked in deep thought as he sat right at the end of the team photo. However, he was otherwise in a jovial mood as a potentially sensational return to the England set-up took a step closer.

Pietersen's sacking in 2014 was controversial, and his return to the international set-up would be a major talking point. He last featured at international level during the last Ashes tour for England in Australia last year, in a disastrous trip which saw his side suffer a whitewash series defeat. With England hoping to regain the urn this summer on home soil, Pietersen has rejoined Surrey in an attempt to force his way back into the Test set-up.

Surrey play Oxford MCCU in a MCC University match on Sunday.

The dress is a blue and black dress that went viral in February 2015 after a Tumblr user posted a photo of it and asked people what color they saw. The dress was seen by some as white and gold, while others saw it as blue and black. The debate over the dress's color quickly spread to other social media platforms, with people arguing about it on Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram. The dress even made it to the news, with articles about it appearing in major newspapers and magazines. The debate over the dress's color eventually died down, but it remains one of the most talked-about viral moments of recent years.

The dress was originally a $59.99 maxi dress sold by Roman Originals, a British clothing company. The dress was available in two colors: "Champange" and "Royal Blue." However, when the photo of the dress was posted on Tumblr, many people saw it as white and gold. This led to a debate about the dress's color, with people arguing about it on social media and in the news.

The debate over the dress's color was so intense that it even caused some people to question their own perception of reality. Some people said that they saw the dress as white and gold, but then later saw it as blue and black. Others said that they could see both colors at the same time.

The debate over the dress's color eventually died down, but it remains one of the most talked-about viral moments of recent years. The dress has been referenced in pop culture, and it has even been used in marketing campaigns. The dress is a reminder of the power of social media to spread information and to create debate.

A planning inquiry is underway in Ebbw Vale to determine whether a new motorsports circuit can be built on common land. The development would involve taking over 250 hectares (600 acres) of land, and would require the construction of a new road and bridge.

The inquiry has heard conflicting accounts from experts over the environmental impact of the development. Natural Resources Wales said it was "difficult to conclude" that the replacement land was of equal value, but it was not opposing the development overall. But an ecology report presented by the developers said there would be a "net gain" in biodiversity because the plans included work to enhance other habitats nearby - which the Gwent wildlife trust argued against.

The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry in Ebbw vale, before Welsh government ministers have the final say on whether the plans can go ahead.

The development has been met with opposition from some local residents, who are concerned about the impact on the environment and the loss of common land. They have also raised concerns about the noise and traffic that the circuit would generate.

The developers say that the circuit would bring economic benefits to the area, and that it would be a world-class facility that would attract visitors from all over the world. They also say that the environmental impact of the development would be minimal, and that the replacement land would be of equal value to the common land that would be lost.

The inquiry is expected to last for several weeks.

The exhibition Growing Up in the City at the Museum of Liverpool showcases 25 photographs that capture the lives of children in Liverpool over more than 100 years. The photographs provide a snapshot of childhood in Liverpool, as well as a thought-provoking social history of the city. The oldest image dates back to 1887 and shows three children dressed up for a fancy dress ball. Another image shows a young maid who was sent out to work. The exhibition was curated by Kay Jones, who painstakingly trawled through hundreds of images from the National Museums Liverpool's collections before deciding on the final 25. Growing Up in the City is at the Museum of Liverpool until 25 September.

The exhibition is divided into three sections: "Playing Out," "Working Children," and "Special Occasions." The "Playing Out" section features photographs of children playing in the streets, parks, and beaches of Liverpool. The "Working Children" section shows images of children who were sent out to work, often in dangerous and unhealthy conditions. The "Special Occasions" section includes photographs of children celebrating holidays, attending school, and participating in other activities.

The exhibition provides a unique glimpse into the lives of children in Liverpool over the past 100 years. It is a reminder of the challenges that children have faced, as well as the joys and triumphs of childhood.

Two women in Scotland have been scammed out of money by people claiming to work for BT. The first incident saw a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills tricked by someone claiming to work for BT. Now a woman in Stranraer has lost money to a caller who said he was contacting her about problems with her internet. He claimed to be from BT technical support and gained remote access to her computer to take the cash. The Sandyhills incident happened on 15 September with the Stranraer con taking place seven days later. PC Siobhan Pellett said: "The ease with which these people seem to be able to gain access to their victim's computer is frightening and the sums of money being taken are substantial. "We are asking people to be very, very careful when answering a cold call from someone who tries to gain remote access to their computer in order to rectify an alleged fault. "Our message is worth repeating once again that people should never, never give out any banking details or account numbers over the telephone. "Banks, building societies and reputable businesses never ask for this information."

Here are some tips to avoid being scammed:

* Never give out your personal information, such as your bank account number or credit card number, to someone you don't know.
* Be suspicious of any caller who asks for personal information or tries to gain remote access to your computer.
* Hang up on any call that makes you feel uncomfortable.
* Report any suspicious calls to the police.

James Milner has retired from international football after 61 caps for England. The 30-year-old made his senior debut in 2009 and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships. He scored his first and only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, picking up 46 caps after making his first appearance in 2004. He said the decision to retire was "about common sense" and wished Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters success in the future.

Conor McGregor has requested to use 8oz gloves for his boxing match against Floyd Mayweather. The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) will debate the matter on August 16. If approved, it would be the first time 8oz gloves have been used in a boxing match at 154lbs.

McGregor has used 4oz gloves in his UFC career, which offer less cushioning and theoretically lead to punches being more punishing. Mayweather has not yet submitted a waiver to use 8oz gloves, but his team has asked the NAC about the process.

The NAC's executive director, Bob Bennett, said he has never seen a move to 8oz gloves at 154lbs before. Rules state that 10oz gloves are used from 135lbs upwards but bouts between 135lbs and 147lbs can use 8oz gloves if waivers are signed and the NAC feels the move is justified.

"Even if they are both in agreement, our number one policy is the health and safety of the fighters," said Bennett. "To deviate from our regulations at a difference of 7lbs would be for the chairman and commissioners to determine."

McGregor, 29, will make his boxing debut in what could be the richest fight in history. The UFC lightweight champion's move from the octagon to the ring to face Mayweather, 40, has prompted criticism from major boxing personalities such as Oscar De La Hoya and Gennady Golovkin.

But Bennett says he studied a "litany of information" on the Irishman before telling his chairman there were "several reasons to approve the fight". Bennett said that McGregor's UFC rival Nate Diaz played a role in him forming his opinion.

"I spoke to Virgil Hunter, who trains many top fighters and has worked with the likes of Andre Ward," said Bennett. "He used Nate Diaz a dozen times for sparring and said he rated him as an outstanding boxer.

"Then you put Nate in the ring with Conor and Conor knocks him down with several shots. Add in that Conor has a granite-like chin, add in that he's 12 years younger than Floyd, and add in that he's taller and longer.

"Floyd is probably one of the smartest fighters, he has the art of getting in getting shots and getting out. But he hasn't knocked anyone out in 10 years. Ricky Hatton was probably the last one in 2007 because when he KO'd Victor Ortiz in 2010, he wasn't defending himself.

"That in essence is it. There were several reasons to approve this fight."

McGregor floored Diaz three times on his way to a points win in August 2016, avenging a defeat via submission five months earlier. Since sanctioning the fight, Bennett has had access to three videos showing McGregor's progress and told BBC Sport: "He's good to go."

He also advised McGregor's camp to employ a boxing referee in order to feel comfortable with the rules, advice which led to the hiring of Hall of Fame official Joe Cortez, 73. Cortez said he oversaw an "out of control" sparring session between McGregor and Paulie Malignaggi. The former two-weight world champion has since left the camp after reacting angrily to images of him on the canvas during a sparring session.

A 34-year-old woman, formerly known as David Ayrton, has been found guilty of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. The defendant, who has learning difficulties, denied the charge but was found guilty by a jury at Portsmouth Crown Court. She will be sentenced on 4 March.

The court heard that Ayrton met the girl in the garage in the autumn of 2004. The two of them were alone in the garage, and Ayrton raped the girl. The girl shouted and swore at Ayrton to stop the attack, but her friends had not woken up. She had "only drunk a can and a half of Foster's" and clearly recollected the events.

The court heard that in 2014 Ayrton told a worker at the care home where she lived in Fordingbridge, Hampshire, about the attack. The worker reported the matter to the police, and Ayrton was arrested.

Ayrton denied the charge, but was found guilty by a jury at Portsmouth Crown Court. She will be sentenced on 4 March.

The judge, Ian Pearson, remanded Ayrton into custody and said it was likely she would be held at a male prison. He added: "If I were to release on bail there are substantial grounds to believe she would be a risk to herself and a risk of failing to attend for whatever reason. "I will therefore have to remand in custody. It will have to be a male prison in Winchester but it will be an issue for the prison service."

He also told the jury at Portsmouth Crown Court: "It's been a slightly unusual case and it's not been an easy case."

The court heard that Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted to commit suicide last summer. Protocols have been put in place for her detention at the prison, a court officer explained.

During the trial Ayrton spoke about her sexuality, and said she she had not "made any physical changes or enhancements" to her body or taken any medication. She changed her name in 2012.

The victim said she shouted and swore at Ayrton to stop the attack, but her friends had not woken up. She had "only drunk a can and a half of Foster's" and clearly recollected the events.

The court heard that in 2014 Ayrton told a worker at the care home where she lived in Fordingbridge, Hampshire, about the attack.

The victim said she was "shocked and scared" when Ayrton raped her. She said she had "never been in a situation like that before" and "didn't know what to do".

The victim said she had been "struggling" since the attack and had been diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder. She said she had been "having flashbacks" and "nightmares" about the attack.

The victim said she was "relieved" that Ayrton had been found guilty and said she hoped that the verdict would "bring her some closure".

The glowing blue letters that once lit the Bronx from above Yankee Stadium failed to find a buyer at an auction at Sotheby's on Wednesday. The 13 letters were expected to bring in anywhere from $300,000 to $600,000, but the only person who raised a paddle - for $260,000 - was a Sotheby's employee trying to jump start the bidding. The current owner of the signage is Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased the 10-feet-tall letters for an undisclosed amount after the stadium saw its final game in 2008.

The 68-year-old Yankee said he wanted 'a new generation to own and enjoy this icon of the Yankees and of New York City.' The letters had beamed from atop Yankee Stadium near Grand Concourse in the Bronx since 1976, the year before Jackson joined the team. ESPN reports Jackson, who attended the auction, bought the letters 'on a lark.' Jackson joked that once he saw the size of the letters, some of which are also 10-feet-wide, he realized he might have gotten ahead of himself. He promised before the auction that if the letters were bought by a bidder in the United States, he would fly out to see the signage himself at the winner's home.

In addition to the letters, Sotheby's was auctioning off a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s. Despite the Mets memorabilia being estimated at only $20,000 to $30,000, it raked in a winning bid of $112,500 at auction.

On Tuesday, US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks five miles east of Sumas, Washington. The agents ordered the men to halt, but one of them dropped his backpack, fired a weapon at the agents, and ran. The other man, identified as Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody. Canadian and US police searched for the fugitive on foot and by helicopter, putting up road blocks. Nathan Hall, a Canadian citizen, was arrested by the Abbotsford Police Department in British Columbia early on Wednesday morning. According to border patrol agents, the backpacks Mr Hall and Mr Laviolette were carrying contained a total of 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy. Also inside one backpack was a California driver's licence with the name of William Nickerson but a picture of Nathan Hall. Investigators later arrested a Bellingham, Washington woman, Kali Henifin, who they say planned to pick the two men up at the border. They also arrested her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, who allegedly told officers he was to be paid $11,000 (Â£7,270) to drive the drugs to San Francisco. Ms Henifin told agents they had been monitoring police radio communication on a mobile phone when they heard a report of a shooting and left the area. The three defendants in US custody face conspiracy as well as drug possession and distribution charges. The wooded area a few miles east of a highway border crossing is a well-known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

In December 2016, six workers were exposed to low levels of radiation while working on EnQuest's Thistle platform, off Shetland. The workers were employed by Wood Group, which had a contract with EnQuest. The workers were removing a piece of pipework when they were exposed to the radiation. The level of exposure was less than 1% of the level at which it is reportable to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE). However, EnQuest advised the HSE of the matter at the time.

EnQuest has appropriate control measures in place which are designed to prevent exposure to naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM). Following an investigation, additional precautionary steps have been taken to further ensure that personnel avoid any such exposure.

Wood Group said the health and safety of its people is always its top priority. As a precaution following the incident, the company downmanned its employees from the platform in order to conduct medical assessments. Wood Group fully supported EnQuest in a detailed joint investigation and continues to reinforce the application of its health and safety procedures, to ensure the safety of its employees.

The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) said it has been made aware of this incident. However, it was not reportable under the present RIDDOR system (Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations) and no staff raised the issue with HSE separately so no investigation has been carried out.

The workers have been told the levels of radiation may not cause them long-term harm, but they are continuing to undergo tests. One of the workers, Steve Innes, said EnQuest had failed in its duty of care. He said the workers had all been working on the pipework without the proper PPE (personal protective equipment), because they had assumed it was clear. He said they had been in shock when they were told about the radiation exposure.

Innes said he would like somebody to take the case on who's not frightened of the companies.

A 20-year-old man has died after a two-vehicle crash on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness on Saturday afternoon.

The incident occurred at around 2.30pm when a black Ford Focus and a white Ford Transit van collided.

The driver of the Focus, who was the only person in the car, was pronounced dead at the scene.

The driver of the van and a passenger were both taken to Raigmore Hospital in Inverness with minor injuries.

The road was closed for several hours while emergency services dealt with the incident.

Police Scotland are appealing for witnesses to the crash to come forward.

Anyone with information is asked to contact the Road Policing Unit at Dingwall on 101, quoting incident number 2339 of 25 February 2023.

Bolivia has passed a law that allows children as young as 10 to work, as long as they have parental permission. The law also sets harsher punishments for violence against children. The International Labour Organization (ILO) says the law breaches international regulations on child labour.

The law was passed by Congress earlier this month and signed into law by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales, who was travelling to Brazil.

Garcia said the new legislation reflects the needs of Bolivia, one of the poorest countries in South America.

"President Evo [Morales] intervened to make sure we found a balance between the reality and the law, between rights and international treaties," added Garcia.

More than 500,000 children already work to supplement the family income in Bolivia according to the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef). Many work cleaning shoes and selling food in stalls in La Paz and other Bolivian cities. But others face extreme conditions in mines and in agriculture fields.

Morales's socialist government hopes the law will help eradicate extreme poverty in Bolivia.

The ILO says children under the age of 15 should not be allowed to work. But it allows a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries.

"It would have been easier to pass a law in line with international conventions, but it would not be enforced because Bolivia's reality has other needs and characteristics," said Garcia.

The ILO says it is studying the legislation to decide whether it breaches international regulations on child labour.

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving the local authority. Richard Ellis is leaving on Friday at the end of his contract. Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are both going under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, the leader of the opposition SNP group, said the departures were indicative of the council's inability to hold on to senior staff. He said he expected further departures in the coming months. Mr Ellis is the council's former interim director of corporate governance, and has also been acting as deputy chief executive for several months. Mr Monaghan is head of the chief executive's office, while Mr Sutherland is head of human resources and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the trio for their "dedication and professionalism".

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck Italy on February 25, 2023. The epicenter was 35 kilometers north of the city of Lucca, and the tremor was felt as far away as Milan and Florence. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.

Italy is prone to earthquakes. In 2009, almost 300 people died in a quake in L'Aquila in the central Abruzzo region. The country's National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology (INGV) said the latest quake struck at 15:48 (14:48 GMT), with its epicenter in Garfagnana. Several aftershocks of lower magnitude were felt across a large area.

Phone lines were down and power supplies were cut in the Garfagnana area, Italian news agency Ansa reports. As a precaution, schools were said to have been evacuated in the immediate vicinity and were to be checked for any damage. In Milan, top floors of tall office blocks shook and the quake was also felt in the cities of Bologna and Modena. In Lucca, people poured out into the streets, Ansa said.

Last May, two earthquakes in the same area left more than 20 people dead. The strongest tremor was magnitude-6 and caused significant damage. Alessandro Amato of the INGV said the latest tremor "came out of nowhere", and described it as a classic earthquake for the area - "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow".

Italy is still trying to recover from the aftermath of the deadly earthquake in L'Aquila. Six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of multiple manslaughter in October 2012 for giving a falsely reassuring statement. The group, all members of the National Commission for the Forecast and Prevention of Serious Risks, were accused of having provided "inaccurate, incomplete and contradictory" information about the danger of the tremors felt ahead of the 6 April 2009 quake. At a meeting a few days before the deadly quake, they had told officials in L'Aquila that, while a major earthquake was not impossible, it was not likely. On the night of the quake, many people are said to have remained in their homes and died because of the advice, while others who had decided to remain outside in the street survived.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in the dining room of his home on Mugga Way, Red Hill, Canberra in July 2012. Costa was suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the murder, according to forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen. Mullen believes that Costa's mood fluctuated from "moment to moment" and that he was in a confused mental state at the time of the killing. Costa's state of mind is critical to the case, as the jury can return a not guilty verdict if Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

The Bridgwater Community Hospital is to be rebuilt at a cost of £33m. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit and X-ray and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital was built in 1813 and is cramped and outdated. The new hospital is expected to be completed by autumn 2014.

The money for the new hospital is part of the coalition's £330m investment for new NHS facilities across England. The remaining balance of the project will be paid for by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust.

Matron Sue Taylor said that the current hospital is very old and in the summer it is very, very hot. In the winter it is quite cold, there's lots of maintenance, lots of running repairs - it's a poor old tired building now. She said that sometimes your environment can have such an impact when you're trying to recover from an illness - we make the best of what we've got but when you walk into a new build it just lifts you and gives you that feeling of well-being.

In the past five years, three out of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced. Work has also got under way on the new Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton.

Dr Donal Hynes, a Bridgwater GP and medical director at Somerset Primary Care Trust, said that the new hospital will make a huge difference for him and his relationship with his patients. He said that this is a great vote of confidence of the developments that have been achieved in Somerset where GPs, nurses, and therapists have got together to deliver a whole package of care that can be delivered in a one-stop shop setting.

Somerset PCT hopes to build the new hospital on land at Bowers Lane, which will depend on planning permission. The aim is to get the hospital finished by autumn 2014.

The Northern Ireland government has announced plans to establish a new industry-led agri-food marketing body. The move was welcomed by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster and Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill. The new body will play a pivotal role in providing strategic leadership and direction for the marketing activities of both government and private sector organisations. It is seen as a significant and exciting opportunity for the Northern Ireland agri-food industry to work together for the benefit of the entire sector.

OneWeb is a company that is building a constellation of satellites to provide broadband internet access to the world. The company has partnered with Airbus to build the satellites, and the first 10 satellites are scheduled to launch in April 2020. The company plans to have a total of 600 satellites in orbit by the end of 2020, and over 2,000 satellites by the middle of the decade.

OneWeb's satellites will be in low Earth orbit, about 1,200 kilometers above the Earth. This will allow them to provide high-speed internet access to remote areas that are not currently served by traditional broadband providers. The satellites will also be able to provide internet access to ships and airplanes.

OneWeb's satellites are being built using a new manufacturing process that is designed to be more efficient and cost-effective than traditional satellite manufacturing methods. The satellites are being built on an assembly line in Toulouse, France.

OneWeb is not the only company that is building a constellation of satellites to provide broadband internet access. SpaceX, Boeing, and ViaSat are also working on similar projects. However, OneWeb is the first company to launch satellites for its constellation.

The launch of OneWeb's satellites is a major milestone in the development of broadband internet access from space. If OneWeb is successful, it will provide high-speed internet access to millions of people around the world who do not currently have access.

OneWeb's satellites are also expected to have a significant impact on the space debris environment. The company has committed to de-orbiting its satellites within five years of their end of life. This will help to reduce the risk of collisions between satellites and other objects in space.

Overall, OneWeb's project is a major step forward in the development of broadband internet access from space. The company's satellites have the potential to provide high-speed internet access to millions of people around the world who do not currently have access. OneWeb's satellites are also expected to have a significant impact on the space debris environment.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person your spouse has committed adultery with. Family lawyers say that, in most cases, involving a third party adds "conflict and complexity". The Ministry of Justice said there was "no obligation" to name people.

The online form has been updated to make the legal process more user-friendly - especially as some complete the process without seeking legal advice. The guidance on the form highlights that it is "not normally necessary" to name the person your spouse committed adultery with. But Georgina Hamblin, director at divorce lawyers, Vardags, said people are "unlikely to read the much smaller print or choose to ignore it".

The older version of the form left a space for so-called "co-respondents" to be named where appropriate. "The new form flatly asks for 'the name of the person your spouse has committed adultery with'," Ms Hamblin explained. "This is an invitation which I fear most broken hearts will not be able to refuse."

If you name the person your husband or wife committed adultery with, they become part of the court case. They will be sent copies of the paperwork and given a chance to respond. If they don't respond, proceedings may be delayed and could incur more costs.

According to the latest statistics, there were just over 100,000 divorces granted in England and Wales in 2015. Adultery was the reason for 12,148 of them. "Unreasonable behaviour" accounted for 46,815.

Ms Hamblin said 80% of the new clients she deals with in matters of adultery "want to get the new partner involved and to have their chance to say what they think of them".

"But it puts the petitioner in a bad light. We have to talk clients down from doing that," she said. "Judges take a very dim view of petitioners trying to bring in new partners and embroil them in proceedings."

When you apply for a divorce you must prove your marriage has broken down and give one of the following reasons:

* Adultery
* Unreasonable behaviour
* Desertion
* Two years' separation with consent
* Five years' separation

A Ministry of Justice spokesman said: "It has always been possible for a petitioner to name the person they believe their spouse has committed adultery with on divorce application forms.

"As set out in the previous form, and more clearly in the new form, there is obviously no obligation to do so. This is a relevant part of divorce proceedings."

A speed camera that has been turned around and is pointing at a house in Birmingham will be removed. The camera, which has not been working for two years, was decommissioned in 2013. The council is aware of the issue and will send an engineer to remove the camera. There are no plans to include the camera in a new pilot scheme. The owners of the house were not available for comment.

Russell Brand has been accused of hypocrisy for campaigning for economic and political "revolution" to help poorer people, while living in a luxury home. He has defended himself by saying that he is trying to change the system, and that his personal wealth is irrelevant.

Brand has been a vocal critic of the rich and powerful, and has called for a more equal society. He has also been involved in a number of campaigns to help the poor, including the Occupy movement.

However, his critics say that he is a hypocrite for living in a luxury home while claiming to speak up for the poor. They say that he is part of the problem, and that he should not be lecturing others about inequality.

Brand has responded to these accusations by saying that he is trying to change the system, and that his personal wealth is irrelevant. He says that he is not trying to be a role model, and that he is simply trying to do what he believes is right.

The debate over Brand's hypocrisy is likely to continue. However, it is clear that he is a controversial figure who is not afraid to speak his mind.

Police found a large cannabis farm in a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

The plants were found in "an elaborate grow house". Police said they were worth an estimated £1 million.

The man was arrested on suspicion of cultivating cannabis and production of a controlled drug. He is currently in police custody.

The investigation is ongoing.

13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. He has since received an outpouring of support from people all over the world, including a massive billboard erected in Holywood by a mystery donor. The hashtag #prayforjosh has gone viral, and Josh's classmates have been using it to show their support. Josh's family and friends are grateful for the kindness of strangers, and they are hopeful that Josh will make a full recovery.

The poverty rate in the United States was 15% in 2011, meaning 46.2 million Americans were in poverty. This was the same as the poverty rate in 2010, but it was up from 12.5% in 2007. The real median income of households in the country dropped by 1.5% in 2011. The average poverty threshold for a family of four in 2011 was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6% in 2011, the first time there has been an annual rise in the index since 1993. The percentage of Americans lacking health insurance fell to 15.7% from 16.3%, the report also said.

The poverty rate is the percentage of the population that lives below the poverty line. The poverty line is a measure of income that is used to determine who is considered poor. The poverty line is set by the federal government and is based on the cost of food, clothing, shelter, and other necessities.

The poverty rate in the United States has been increasing in recent years. In 2010, the poverty rate was 15.1%, the highest it had been since 1993. The increase in the poverty rate is due to a number of factors, including the Great Recession, which caused many people to lose their jobs and their homes.

The increase in the poverty rate has had a number of negative consequences. Children who grow up in poverty are more likely to drop out of school, become unemployed, and commit crimes. They are also more likely to have health problems and to die prematurely.

There are a number of things that can be done to reduce poverty in the United States. One important step is to create more jobs. Another important step is to provide affordable housing and healthcare. Finally, it is important to invest in education and job training so that people can get the skills they need to get good jobs.

Melania Trump, the wife of President-elect Donald Trump, has said she will not move to the White House with her son Barron until he finishes the school year. This is a break from tradition, as most first ladies have moved to the White House with their children as soon as possible.

There are a few reasons why Melania Trump may have made this decision. First, Barron is 10 years old, and it can be disruptive for children to change schools in the middle of the year. Second, Melania Trump has said that she wants to be a stay-at-home mom for Barron. Third, the White House is a large and busy place, and it may not be the best environment for a young child.

Melania Trump's decision has been met with mixed reactions. Some people have praised her for putting her son's needs first. Others have criticized her for not being willing to make the sacrifice of moving to the White House.

It remains to be seen how Melania Trump's decision will affect her role as first lady. She has said that she wants to focus on issues like cyberbullying and child welfare. However, it will be difficult to do this if she is not living in the White House.

Here are some additional details about Melania Trump's decision:

* Melania Trump is the first first lady in modern history to not move to the White House with her husband and children.
* Barron Trump is the youngest child of a president to live in the White House since John F. Kennedy Jr.
* Melania Trump has said that she will move to the White House after Barron finishes the school year in June.
* The White House is a 55,000-square-foot mansion with 132 rooms.
* The White House has a staff of over 100 people.
* The White House is located at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, D.C.

The NHS Improvement regulator wants the NHS to reduce its spending on agency staff by £1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap was introduced in October 2022 to limit the amount that hospitals, mental health trusts and ambulance services can pay agency staff. The cap is £55% above normal shift rates for any staff, from doctors and nurses to administration staff. Only senior managers are exempted.

The aim of the cap is to reduce the overall cost of agency staff as well as getting hospitals to reduce their reliance on them. Agency staff are more expensive because the NHS has to cover the agency fees and employers costs, such as National Insurance contributions, when it buys them in.

NHS Improvement said the progress being made was "promising", but it still leaves the NHS short. The latest accounts suggested NHS trusts were 10% down on where they wanted to be. And while the agency bill is falling it is not yet clear whether spending on other parts of the pay bill has risen.

The figures released by NHS Improvement do not cover NHS "bank" staff - effectively the health service's in-house agency - or money spent getting employed staff to do overtime.

NHS Improvement said it would start publishing "league tables" of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending later this year. Information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust would also be collected amid suspicion some people are still earning large sums from agency work.

It found examples of hospitals being quoted double the rates for doctors. In one case a trust was quoted £130 an hour for a surgeon when the cap is meant to be £76, while another was quoted £70 an hour for a junior doctor when the fee is meant to be £35.

NHS Improvement chief executive Jim Mackey said: "The NHS simply doesn't have the money to keep forking out for hugely expensive agency staff. There's much more to be done."

The live-action Beauty and the Beast film will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. It stars Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, Kevin Kline as Maurice, and Emma Thompson as Mrs Potts. The film is directed by Bill Condon.

The live-action Beauty and the Beast movie will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. It stars Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, Kevin Kline as Maurice, and Emma Thompson as Mrs Potts. Bill Condon will direct the movie.

Bernard Matthews, a British turkey firm, was sold to the food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. Unite, the union representing the workers, had fears that the new owners would not take on the existing workers' pension scheme. However, Unite regional officer Steve Harley said that they had productive talks with the new owners and were given guarantees that all current agreements would be honoured. Unite said it understood that the Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004 and that its members presently have an alternative pension scheme which is unaffected the takeover. The Boparan Private Office, the "chicken king" Mr Boparan's private investment, confirmed that the current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under the new ownership. Mr Harley met with representatives from Boparan at the Great Witchingham headquarters. He said: "It was made clear that the new owner wishes to restore Bernard Matthews to its former position as a highly profitable business." This would be achieved by greater investment in the business, cost savings and utilising the present spare capacity at Bernard Matthews to process chicken and not just turkeys."

A man was shot and killed in Sheffield on Wednesday afternoon. The victim was found with a gunshot wound to his chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, close to the city centre. He was taken to Northern General hospital but died from his injuries. Local residents said the man was a member of a family who live close to the scene of the shooting. They said relatives had been gathering for a family celebration when the attack occurred. Many came out of the house to try to help him after hearing the shot, neighbours said. There have been a number of shootings in Sheffield in recent weeks, although all the previous incidents have been in the north of the city and not close to the Upperthorpe area. On Monday, a 25-year-old man was seriously injured when he was shot in the street in the Shiregreen area. Earlier this month, an elderly couple were left shocked when shots were fired through their living room window in the Southey Green area - an incident police believe was a case of mistaken identity. In January shots were fired at houses in two separate incidents in the same street in High Green.

The UK government and the Scottish government have agreed to hold monthly meetings to discuss Brexit negotiations. The UK government has said it will keep Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland up-to-date about the talks, but the Scottish government has said it needs more clarity about the UK's negotiating strategy. The UK government is hoping the High Court judgment on how Article 50 will be triggered will be overruled on appeal to the Supreme Court next month. However, the Scottish government will seek to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal.

The UK government and the Scottish government have agreed to hold monthly meetings to discuss Brexit negotiations. This is a positive development, as it will allow the two governments to work together to ensure that the best possible deal is reached for the whole of the UK. However, it is important that the UK government provides greater clarity and transparency on its negotiating strategy. The Scottish government has said that it needs to know whether the UK government wants to remain inside the single market or the customs union. This is essential information, as it will have a major impact on Scotland's economy.

The UK government is hoping the High Court judgment on how Article 50 will be triggered will be overruled on appeal to the Supreme Court next month. This would allow the UK government to trigger Article 50 without the need for the approval of the Scottish Parliament. However, the Scottish government is seeking to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal. This is a significant development, as it could potentially delay the UK's exit from the EU.

Overall, the situation regarding Brexit is still very uncertain. However, the agreement to hold monthly meetings between the UK government and the Scottish government is a positive development. It is important that the UK government provides greater clarity and transparency on its negotiating strategy, as this is essential for Scotland's economy.

A new £45m education campus in Kilmarnock will be named after the renowned Scottish writer William McIlvanney. The campus, which will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre, is due to be completed in 2023.

McIlvanney was born and educated in Kilmarnock, and was a passionate advocate for education. He was also a prolific writer, and is considered one of the most important Scottish writers of the 20th century. His work often explored the social and political issues of his time, and he is credited with helping to popularise the genre of Tartan Noir.

The decision to name the new campus after McIlvanney was welcomed by his family and friends. His son, Liam McIlvanney, said that it was "a fitting tribute to a great writer and a great man".

The new campus will be a major addition to the educational facilities in Kilmarnock. It will provide a state-of-the-art learning environment for pupils of all ages, and will help to ensure that Kilmarnock remains a vibrant and prosperous community.

Doncaster Rovers' 0-0 draw with Fleetwood Town on Saturday was a match that tested the patience of even the most ardent fan. The media team faced a tough challenge when they were faced with sticking up the match highlights on the club's YouTube channel. So they made it short and sweet, just 27 seconds in fact with 14 seconds of match action. Just enough time for the kick off, a goal kick and the final whistle.
