Underdog was released in the United States on August 3, 2007. The film received mixed reviews from critics, with praise for its animation and voice acting, but criticism for its plot and humor. The film's plot is as follows:

Vedam is a 2010 Indian Telugu-language drama film written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi. The film stars Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham. The film is about two brothers who are separated at birth and raised in different families. The elder brother, Arjun, is a happy-go-lucky guy who lives in the present. The younger brother, Siddharth, is a serious and responsible guy who lives in the past. The two brothers are reunited when they are adults, and they must learn to deal with their differences. The film was a critical and commercial success, and it was remade in Hindi as Son of Sardaar (2012).

The film begins with the birth of two twin brothers, Arjun and Siddharth. Arjun is born first, and he is taken away by his father, a wealthy businessman. Siddharth is born second, and he is taken away by his mother, a poor farmer. The two brothers are raised in different families, and they grow up to be very different people.

Vietnam is a country in Southeast Asia. It is bordered by China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Vietnam has a population of over 92 million people, making it the 14th most populous country in the world. The capital city of Vietnam is Hanoi.

Vietnam is a socialist republic. The Communist Party of Vietnam is the sole governing party in the country. The current president of Vietnam is Nguyễn Xuân Phúc.

Vietnam has a long and rich history. The country was ruled by the Chinese for over a thousand years, from 111 BC to 939 AD. After gaining independence, Vietnam was ruled by a series of dynasties until the French colonization in the late 19th century. Vietnam gained independence from France in 1954 after the First Indochina War. The country was then divided into North Vietnam and South Vietnam. The Vietnam War, which lasted from 1954 to 1975, was fought between the two countries. North Vietnam won the war and the country was reunited.

Vietnam is a developing country. The economy of Vietnam has been growing rapidly in recent years. The country is a major exporter of rice, coffee, and seafood. Vietnam is also a popular tourist destination.

Vietnam is a beautiful country with a diverse landscape. The country has mountains, forests, beaches, and rivers. Vietnam is also home to a number of historical and cultural sites.

Some of the popular tourist destinations in Vietnam include:

* Ha Long Bay: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, Ha Long Bay is a beautiful bay with thousands of limestone karsts and islets.
* Ho Chi Minh City: The former capital of South Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh City is a vibrant city with a rich history.
* Hanoi: The capital of Vietnam, Hanoi is a historic city with a number of temples, pagodas, and museums.
* Mekong Delta: A vast delta in the south of Vietnam, the Mekong Delta is a popular tourist destination for its floating markets and canals.
* Da Nang: A city in the central part of Vietnam, Da Nang is known for its beautiful beaches and its Marble Mountains.
* Huế: A city in the central part of Vietnam, Huế was the capital of Vietnam from 1802 to 1945. The city is home to a number of historical and cultural sites, including the Imperial City.
* Hội An: A city in the central part of Vietnam, Hội An is a UNESCO World Heritage Site known for its well-preserved ancient town.
* Sapa: A town in the northern part of Vietnam, Sapa is a popular tourist destination for its stunning scenery and its ethnic minority villages.
* Ninh Bình: A province in the northern part of Vietnam, Ninh Bình is home to a number of historical and cultural sites, including the Trang An Landscape Complex.
* Hạ Long: A city in the northern part of Vietnam, Hạ Long is a popular tourist destination for its beautiful scenery and its Hạ Long Bay.

Vietnam is a beautiful and diverse country with a rich history and culture. It is a popular tourist destination and a developing economy.

Wales is a country in the United Kingdom. It is located in the west of the island of Great Britain. Wales is bordered by England to the east, the Irish Sea to the north and west, and the Bristol Channel to the south. The capital and largest city is Cardiff.

Wales is a unitary principality, which means that it has its own government and parliament. The head of state is the Queen of the United Kingdom, who is represented in Wales by the Lord Lieutenant of Wales. The head of government is the First Minister of Wales, who is currently Mark Drakeford.

Wales has a population of over 3 million people. The official language is Welsh, but English is also widely spoken. The majority of the population is Christian, with the Church in Wales being the largest denomination.

Wales is a beautiful country with a rich history and culture. It is a popular tourist destination, with attractions such as Snowdonia National Park, the Brecon Beacons National Park, and the Pembrokeshire Coast National Park.

Wales is also a country with a strong industrial heritage. The South Wales Coalfield was one of the most important coalfields in the world, and the mining industry played a major role in the development of Wales.

Today, Wales is a modern and prosperous country. It is a member of the European Union and the United Nations. Wales is a proud country with a strong sense of national identity.

The Industrial Revolution was a period of rapid social and economic change that began in Great Britain in the late 18th century and spread to other parts of the world in the 19th century. The Industrial Revolution was characterized by the development of new technologies, such as the steam engine, the spinning jenny, and the power loom, which led to the growth of factories and the mass production of goods. The Industrial Revolution also led to the growth of cities, as people moved from rural areas to find work in factories.

The Industrial Revolution had a profound impact on Wales. The development of the mining and metallurgical industries transformed the country from an agricultural society into an industrial nation. The South Wales Coalfield was one of the most important coalfields in the world, and the mining industry played a major role in the development of Wales. The exploitation of the South Wales Coalfield caused a rapid expansion of Wales' population.

The Industrial Revolution also had a negative impact on Wales. The working conditions in factories were often dangerous and unhealthy, and the wages of workers were low. The Industrial Revolution also led to the pollution of the environment.

Despite the negative impacts, the Industrial Revolution had a positive impact on Wales. The development of the mining and metallurgical industries led to the growth of the Welsh economy. The Industrial Revolution also led to the development of a Welsh national identity.

The US has suspended its participation in bilateral channels with Russia that were established to sustain the cessation of hostilities in Syria. The US accused Russia of failing to live up to its own commitments and of targeting critical infrastructure such as hospitals. Russia denied the allegations and accused the US of failing to fulfil its own commitments. The US and Russia were due to convene in Geneva to try to co-ordinate air strikes against jihadist groups, but American officials were told to return home. The US also said that it would withdraw personnel "that had been dispatched in anticipation of the possible establishment of the Joint (US-Russian) Implementation Centre". However, the two sides would keep talking about counter-terrorism operations in Syria to avoid unnecessary clashes.

The US and Russia have been working together to try to end the civil war in Syria, but their efforts have been hampered by a lack of trust and cooperation. The US accuses Russia of supporting the Syrian government, which is responsible for the deaths of thousands of civilians. Russia accuses the US of supporting terrorist groups in Syria.

The suspension of the bilateral channels is a major setback for the efforts to end the civil war. It is unclear how the US and Russia will be able to work together to address the humanitarian crisis in Syria.

The video discusses the changing nature of consumer goods in the UK over the past 50 years. It highlights three key factors that have driven this change: the arrival of new technologies, such as the domestic freezer and washing machine; the rise of cheaper imports; and the changing tastes and preferences of consumers.

The video also explores how the ownership of some of the UK's biggest brands has changed over time. It shows that many of these brands are now owned by foreign companies, and that this has had a significant impact on the products that are available to consumers.

Overall, the video provides a fascinating insight into the changing nature of consumer goods in the UK. It is a must-watch for anyone interested in the history of consumerism or the future of the UK economy.

Here are some additional details about the topics discussed in the video:

* The domestic freezer: The domestic freezer was invented in the 1930s, but it wasn't until the 1950s that it became widely available to consumers. The arrival of the freezer had a major impact on the way people shopped and cooked. It allowed people to buy food in bulk and store it for longer periods of time, which led to a decline in the popularity of fresh produce.
* Washing powder: Washing powder was first invented in the 18th century, but it wasn't until the 20th century that it became widely available to consumers. The arrival of washing powder had a major impact on the way people did laundry. It made it much easier to clean clothes, and it led to a decline in the popularity of hand-washing.
* Cheaper imports: The UK has always been a trading nation, but the nature of trade has changed significantly over the past 50 years. In the past, the UK imported mainly raw materials and exported manufactured goods. However, in recent years, the UK has become a net importer of manufactured goods, and this has led to a decline in the number of manufacturing jobs in the country.
* Changing tastes and preferences: The tastes and preferences of consumers have changed significantly over the past 50 years. In the past, people were more likely to buy British-made goods. However, in recent years, there has been a growing trend towards buying foreign-made goods. This is partly due to the fact that foreign-made goods are often cheaper, but it is also due to the fact that consumers are now more aware of the global marketplace.
* Ownership of brands: The ownership of many of the UK's biggest brands has changed significantly over the past 50 years. In the past, these brands were mostly owned by British companies. However, in recent years, many of these brands have been acquired by foreign companies. This is partly due to the fact that foreign companies are often more willing to pay high prices for brands, but it is also due to the fact that foreign companies are often better at marketing and selling brands in the global marketplace.

William Jefferson Clinton, also known as Bill Clinton, was the 42nd President of the United States. He was born on August 19, 1946, in Hope, Arkansas. He served as president from 1993 to 2001. His first inauguration was held on January 20, 1993.

Clinton's presidency was marked by economic prosperity and a balanced budget. He also signed into law the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and the Family and Medical Leave Act.

Clinton was impeached by the House of Representatives in 1998 for perjury and obstruction of justice. He was acquitted by the Senate in 1999.

Winter's Tale is a 1983 novel by Mark Helprin. It is a fantasy novel set in New York City and the fictional city of Anastasia. Peter Lake and Beverly Penn have a son, named Auberon. Auberon is a beautiful and healthy child. He is the only person who can see Peter Lake's true nature. Peter Lake is a fairy, and he is able to fly. He takes Auberon on many adventures, and they travel to many different worlds.

Beverly Penn dies, and Peter Lake is heartbroken. He leaves Auberon with Isaac Penn, and he goes on a journey to find a way to bring Beverly Penn back to life. He travels to the city of Anastasia, which is a magical city that exists in the middle of the ocean. In Anastasia, Peter Lake meets a woman named Anna, who is the daughter of the king and queen of Anastasia. Anna is a beautiful and kind woman, and she falls in love with Peter Lake.

Peter Lake is able to bring Beverly Penn back to life, but she is not the same person she was before she died. She is now a fairy, and she is able to fly. Peter Lake and Beverly Penn are happy in Anastasia, but they are also lonely. They miss their son, Auberon, and they want to be with him. They decide to leave Anastasia and return to New York City. They take Anya with them, and they travel to the city of New York.

Peter Lake and Beverly Penn are reunited with their son, Auberon. They are happy to be together again, and they live happily ever after.

A study by the Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are less likely to get one. The study, which looked at 4,600 workers, found "no support" for the "reticent female" theory, whereby women avoided asking for more money. For what it claimed was the first time, the study eliminated any impact from part-time workers earning less than their full-time counterparts, by comparing full-time males with full-time females, and part-time males with part-time females. When like-for-like male and female workers were compared, men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked, the study found. The research also concluded there was no evidence for the idea that women were reluctant to ask for a salary increase because they were more wary of upsetting their boss, or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. When analysing the results, the researchers took into account the size of the employer and the industry, whether the workers were a parent, as well as their qualifications. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey. Australia is thought to be the only country to systematically record whether employees had asked for a pay rise, and why they had or had not done so. Andrew Oswald, professor of economics and behavioural science at the University of Warwick, said he was surprised by the findings. "The fact that women don't ask for pay rises as often as men is a popular theory. It's a very common thing for women to say and believe, but all of the evidence is anecdotal, so it's very hard scientifically to do a proper test of this." He said one possibility was that unsuccessful men who asked for a pay rise, but did not get it, kept it to themselves, while women "were more straightforward and tell their friends". "Having seen these findings, I think we have to accept that there is some element of pure discrimination against women," Prof Oswald added. "It could be that Australia is odd. But it's a modern industrial economy halfway in character between Britain and the US, so I think that's unlikely." The study also found differences according to age, with women and men under 40 both asking for and receiving pay rises at the same rate, which the researchers said could mean that negotiating behaviour had started to change. Dr Amanda Goodall from Cass Business School - part of City, University of London - and a co-author of the study, said: "The study potentially has an upside. Young women today are negotiating their pay and conditions more successfully than older females, and perhaps that will continue as they become more senior."

The UK is also committed to spending 2% of its GDP on defence, but this is likely to fall below 2% in the next few years. This is because the UK's economy is growing more slowly than other countries, and the government is facing pressure to cut spending in other areas.

The UK's defence policy is facing a number of challenges, and it is unclear how the next government will address them. Further cuts to the defence budget could make it difficult for the UK to respond to the threats it faces, and the future of the UK's nuclear deterrent is also uncertain.

YouTube is an American video-sharing website headquartered in San Bruno, California. Founded by three former PayPal employees—Chad Hurley, Steve Chen, and Jawed Karim—in February 2005, the site allows users to upload, view, rate, share, add to favorites, report, comment on videos, and subscribe to other users. It offers a wide variety of user-generated and corporate media videos. Available content includes video clips, TV show clips, music videos, short and documentary films, audio recordings, movie trailers, live streams, and other content such as video blogging, short original videos, and educational videos. Most content on YouTube is uploaded by individuals, but media corporations including CBS, the BBC, Vevo, and Hulu offer some of their material via YouTube as part of the YouTube partnership program. Unregistered users can only watch videos on the site, while registered users are permitted to upload an unlimited number of videos and add comments to videos. Videos deemed potentially inappropriate are available only to registered users affirming themselves to be at least 18 years old.

Bad Romance is a song by American singer Lady Gaga. It was released on October 23, 2009, as the lead single from her second extended play (EP), The Fame Monster (2009). Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy from Stretford, Manchester, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer, in December 2019. He underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumour, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy. After a year of treatment, he was given the all-clear in January 2021.

Harley's story has inspired many people, and he has become a symbol of hope for other children fighting cancer. He has been featured in the media, and he has even met the Prime Minister. He is an inspiration to us all, and we wish him all the best in his future.

Neuroblastoma is a cancer of specialised nerve cells, which are involved in the development of the nervous system. It is the second most common solid tumour in childhood, and it makes up 8 per cent of the total number of children's cancers. Neuroblastoma commonly occurs in either one of the two adrenal glands in a child's tummy or in nerve tissue that runs alongside the spinal cord, in the neck, chest, abdomen or pelvis. The cancer can spread to tissues beyond the original site, including bone marrow, bone, lymph nodes, liver and skin.

The cause of neuroblastoma is unknown. The symptoms vary depending on where a child's tumour is. The first signs can be vague, and include tiredness, a loss of appetite and pain in the bones. If the tumour is in a child's tummy, it may be swollen and the child may complain of constipation or have difficulty passing urine. Where a tumour is growing in a child's chest, they may be breathless and have difficulty swallowing. Tumours growing in the neck can be visible as a lump, and a child is likely to complain of breathing and swallowing problems. In cases where a tumour is pressing on the spinal cord, children can experience a weakness in the legs and walk unsteadily.

A variety of tests and investigations may be needed to diagnose neuroblastoma. Treatment depends on the age of the child, as well as the size and position of the tumour and whether the disease has spread. Children can have surgery, chemotherapy, as well as antibody treatment and radiotherapy.

The outlook for children with neuroblastoma varies depending on the stage of the disease at diagnosis. The majority of children with low-risk neuroblastoma are cured with surgery and chemotherapy. However, children with high-risk neuroblastoma have a poorer prognosis, and many will not survive the disease.

There is currently no cure for neuroblastoma, but research is ongoing to find new and better treatments.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide in the deaths of a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. He was sentenced to 12 to 24 years in prison.

Dellinger was driving his pickup truck on a highway in New Hampshire when he crossed the median and crashed into an oncoming SUV. The crash killed 24-year-old Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiance, 29-year-old Jason Timmons.

Dellinger's attorneys claimed that he was suffering from a number of medical conditions, including multiple sclerosis, at the time of the crash. They said that he was not suicidal and that the crash was an accident.

However, prosecutors argued that Dellinger was trying to kill himself when he crashed into the SUV. They said that he had been arguing with his wife about his medications on the morning of the crash and that he was driving around "depressed and loopy" when he saw the median and decided to turn into it.

Dellinger's sentencing was delayed several times as he underwent psychiatric evaluations. He was finally sentenced in February 2015.

The crash was a tragedy that claimed the lives of three young people. Dellinger's actions were reckless and irresponsible, and he will now have to pay the price for his crime.

Bella Crooke lost her phone at a friend's birthday party on Saturday night. She called her number the next morning, but it was answered by a security guard who said he would leave it at the police station. Bella didn't get to the police station until 1 pm, and by then, the police had already posted a series of bizarre photos on her Facebook page in a bid to track her down.

The photos included selfies of police officers, photos of the phone in various locations around the police station, and puns about the phone being "in custody" or "on the loose." Bella said she was "shocked" and "flattered" by the police's efforts, and she thanked them for their sense of humor.

The police even took to replying to text messages sent by Bella's friends asking if she had her phone back. One friend asked if Bella had been arrested, and the police replied, "No, but she is being held in a holding cell until she posts bail."

Bella said she was "so grateful" to the police for returning her phone, and she said she would definitely be more careful about keeping it safe in the future.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in the video for Ricky Martin's hit song "La Vida Loca," has denied claims that she tried to take her own life. She says she was instead treated in hospital after she collapsed due to low blood pressure.

Italian media reported that Moric tried to take her own life and was found by her mother in the luxury apartment she shares with her boyfriend in Milan. However, Moric told her fans that she was well and had no intention to end her own life. She said her boyfriend was in Naples at the time of the accident. She explained: "Saturday night I was taken to the hospital due to a domestic accident. I fell banging my head and I hurt everywhere because of low blood pressure."

Moric told her fans that she was "shocked" by the suicide claims. She added: "Luckily I'm fine now nothing serious I need only a bit of rest. But now I made a fine breakfast."

Italian media claimed Moric had tried to take her own life in 2009 after taking an overdose. She was once married to famous paparazzi snapper Fabrizio Corona, who ended up in jail and the pair have a son together, Carlos Maria, who was born in 2002.

Corona, the "king" of Italy's paparazzi, was jailed for blackmailing celebs with compromising photographs. Corona's scoops helped fuel the celebrity tv culture driven by former prime minister Silvio Berlusconi's channels and publications. He claimed he never blackmailed celebrities he snapped, merely offering them first option to buy the photos at the rate he would have sold them to publications. But police tapping his phone during an investigation heard him tell his then wife Nina: "Yes, it's true, I ruin lives, I am a piece of s*** and I don't even feel guilty any more."

In 1988, the body of a baby boy was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag floating on a village pond in Norfolk, England. The baby was never identified and was buried in an unmarked grave.

In 2015, the case was reopened and the baby's body was exhumed. DNA samples were taken and compared to the national DNA database. A match was found for a possible relative of one of the parents. Detectives examined that person's family tree and identified the woman who admitted being the boy's mother.

The woman told police that she had concealed her pregnancy from her family and friends and delivered the baby by herself. She said that the baby was stillborn and that she placed him in the pond.

Police said they have ruled out any foul play and the woman remains on bail while the Crown Prosecution Service decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

The baby has been reburied at Weasenham St Peter Church in Norfolk. A headstone has been erected with the name "Peter".

This is a tragic story of a baby who was never given a chance to live. It is also a story of hope, as the baby has finally been given a name and a place to rest.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple, built a two-bedroom, wood and steel home on the back of a flatbed truck. The home is solar-powered and nearly self-sufficient, with water coming from a nearby spring and most of the electricity coming from solar panels. The couple spent about $25,000 on the project and plans to build another one like it one day.

The couple wanted a home that was cozy and all their own, but could not afford to buy a full-sized lot. They started building the home on the back of the truck after returning to New Zealand from the UK in 2009. The project took about a year and a half to complete.

The home is surrounded by nature, with aromatic cypress wood inside and majestic trees and a babbling brook outside. The couple has a wood-fired stove to keep out the cold, stained glass windows and other creature comforts.

Alex said their first power bill was just $25. The stove and hot water are gas-powered and water comes from a nearby spring.

"I didn't want to live inside a plastic box," Alex said. "Not because I'm a hippie but because it feels nicer and is just a nicer place to be."

The couple is very happy with their home and plans to build another one like it one day.

Star Reader, a newborn baby, was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition. After undergoing an operation to have her bile ducts unblocked, her parents were told she would need a liver transplant in order to survive. Neither parent was a suitable match, but her maternal aunt, Shanelle Reader, offered part of her liver. The transplant was successful, and Star has since made a good recovery.

Biliary atresia is a rare condition that affects about 1 in 16,000 babies at birth. In this condition, the bile ducts, which carry bile from the liver to the small intestine, are either blocked or absent. Bile is a fluid that helps the body digest fats. If it is not able to drain properly, it can build up in the liver and cause damage.

The most common treatment for biliary atresia is the Kasai procedure, which involves removing the blocked bile ducts and creating a new pathway for bile to drain. However, this procedure is not always successful, and some babies will eventually need a liver transplant.

Liver transplants are major surgery, but they can be life-saving. The most common type of liver transplant is a partial liver transplant, in which a healthy liver is donated from a living donor. The donor's liver is then divided into two parts, and one part is transplanted into the recipient.

Liver transplants are very successful, and most people who receive them go on to live long and healthy lives. However, there are some risks associated with the surgery, including infection, bleeding, and rejection of the transplanted liver.

Star Reader is one of the lucky ones. She received a liver transplant from her aunt, and she is now doing well. She is still young, but she is already enjoying life and making memories with her family.

Todd Phillips, a pit crew member for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by the car of Francesco Dracone during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday. Robert Kushner, a witness in a police corruption trial in Philadelphia, lost his job as a varsity basketball coach at a private academy after testifying about his years selling marijuana. Kushner, 32, is one of more than a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government about allegations of police wrongdoing. He told jurors Tuesday that some of the undercover officers on trial had stolen $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. That history came as news to officials at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy in suburban Bryn Mawr. Kushner had passed a background check when he was hired to coach basketball in 2010, head of school Sharon Levin told the Philadelphia Inquirer. Kushner testified that the 2007 charges were expunged as part of a probationary sentence. On cross-examination, he acknowledged that he was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation. He also pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. Kushner told the newspaper that he never meant to deceive the school, where he worked as a seasonal employee. And he believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges. "All of the stuff that happened in 2007, that was eight years ago and was a bad phase of my life that I've moved past and never really looked back," Kushner said Wednesday. "I'm very sorry, and I want the best for the kids." He also coaches in a Narberth summer league, where director Dan Kazanicka described him as an excellent coach who is good with kids. Lawyers for the six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering have said the government case is based on 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after she allegedly broke into a home on Martha's Vineyard, lived there for at least a week, and sold items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. She is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property.

Blue fluorescent algae have lit up Australia's east coast, with stunning images captured in Jervis Bay. Tibetan mastiffs were once highly sought-after status symbols in China, with some puppies selling for up to £1.2 million. These dogs are intelligent, loyal, and affectionate, and they deserve to be treated with respect and compassion. New tests can pinpoint genetic markers in breast cancer tumors to determine their aggressiveness. This information can help doctors decide whether or not to give patients chemotherapy. For some women, the test can accurately tell if the risk of cancer recurrence is as low as 5%, which is as good as if not better than the odds for those who have chemotherapy.

The majority of women who have breast cancer are routinely given chemotherapy following removal of the tumor to prevent recurrence. Although the medication kills off cancer cells, the side effects can be difficult to live with. For some women, the prospect of chemotherapy is more daunting than the surgery itself.

But experts have long-believed that the risk of cancer recurrence for certain women is a lot less than for others, and that for some, chemotherapy may not be necessary. If the newest of the tests, called Endopredict, shows a low score, patients can opt not to have chemotherapy.

Most of the tests are available only privately and cost about £2,500, although breast specialists hope they may soon become properly available on the NHS. Surgeon Hemant Singhal said: "I think there is a good case for the NHS to use this test on the basis that the cost is balanced out by savings in not giving chemotherapy."

Professor Kefah Mokbel, consultant breast surgeon at St George's Hospital, London, said: "With this test we can help patients make an informed choice, whereas in the past we have just given chemotherapy to almost everyone."

Becca Cornford, a 49-year-old mother of three aged 11, six and four, was recovering from being diagnosed and treated for breast cancer last year only to then discover that she had cancer in her other breast.

She said: "I dreaded chemo more than another mastectomy. I was worried it would interfere with me being able to look after my children."

Professor Mokbel operated on Becca in December at the Princess Grace Hospital, London, and afterwards a sample of her tumour was sent away and tested using the Endopredict. A low score meant her chances of recurrence within ten years were just 5% and she was told chemotherapy could not offer much better odds.

"I could have gone through chemo and the cancer could still return," she says. "There is no treatment that places your chances at zero. But if you have regular monitoring, there is every chance that any cancer that might come back would be nipped in the bud early."

Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois, is facing criticism from some quarters. In a recent article in National Geographic, historian Adam Goodheart described the tomb as "a disappointment" and "reconstructed in incongruous art deco style." He also said that it is "strange to think that there is a place where Lincoln still physically exists in the world, let alone that it's a place like this."

The tomb was designed by Vermont sculptor Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874. It is a circular structure topped with an obelisk, and its interior is sheathed in alternating black and tan marble and trimmed with bronze. Hallways stretch on either side of a rotunda to the family burial chamber, where Lincoln lies below an inscription that reads "Now he belongs to the ages."

The article discusses the benefits of oophorectomy for women who carry the BRCA1 gene mutation. BRCA1 is a gene that helps repair damaged DNA. When it is mutated, it increases the risk of developing breast and ovarian cancer. Women who carry the BRCA1 mutation have a 50 to 80% chance of developing breast cancer and a 15 to 40% chance of developing ovarian cancer in their lifetime.

Oophorectomy is the surgical removal of the ovaries. It can be used to prevent breast and ovarian cancer in women who carry the BRCA1 mutation. Studies have shown that oophorectomy can reduce the risk of breast cancer by up to 60% and the risk of ovarian cancer by up to 90%.

Oophorectomy is a major surgery with risks and side effects. These include hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and osteoporosis. Women who have oophorectomy may need to take hormone replacement therapy to manage these side effects.

The decision of whether or not to have oophorectomy is a personal one. Women who carry the BRCA1 mutation should talk to their doctor about the risks and benefits of the procedure. They should also consider their family history, their age, and their overall health.

Here are some additional details about the article:

* The study was conducted by researchers at the Women's College Research Institute in Toronto, Canada.
* The study included 676 women with breast cancer who had one of the mutated genes BRCA1 or BRCA2.
* The women were followed for an average of 20 years.
* The study found that women who had an oophorectomy had a 62% lower risk of dying from breast cancer than women who did not have an oophorectomy.
* The study also found that women who had an oophorectomy had a 65% lower risk of dying from all causes than women who did not have an oophorectomy.
* The study's authors concluded that oophorectomy is a safe and effective way to reduce the risk of death from breast cancer in women who carry the BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that doctors are putting the health of women and their babies at risk by performing caesarean sections too readily. The WHO says that the procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary, as it can lead to infections and even death.

The rate of caesarean sections in England has more than doubled since the early 1990s, and now stands at just over a quarter of all births. This includes a growing number of women opting to have planned caesareans because they are very anxious about giving birth naturally.

However, the WHO says that this figure should ideally be between just 10 per cent and 15 per cent, due to the dangers and costs involved. In a statement, they said: "Although it can save lives, caesarean section is often performed without medical need, putting women and their babies at risk of short- and long-term health problems."

They added that the procedure can lead to "significant complications, disability or death" and diverts precious money away from the needs of other patients. A planned caesarean costs the NHS an average of £2,369, compared to a natural birth at £1,665.

The WHO statement sharply contradicts current NHS guidelines, which say the procedure should be offered to women even when there is no medical justification. The watchdog NICE issued revised recommendations in 2011 allowing women to have the operation if they were very anxious about childbirth, a condition known as tokophobia.

Women are also advised to have planned caesareans if they have had a previous complicated birth, are over 40 or have a medical condition such as asthma, diabetes or depression.

But the WHO said that doctors were carrying them out too often, and underestimating the risks. Previous research has found that as many as one in ten caesareans cause infections.

The WHO's warning comes at a time when the number of caesarean sections being performed around the world is on the rise. In 2015, an estimated 21 million caesarean sections were performed globally, up from 16 million in 2000.

The increase in caesarean sections is partly due to the fact that they are now seen as a safe and effective way to deliver a baby. However, there is also evidence that some doctors are performing caesarean sections unnecessarily, in order to avoid litigation or to meet targets set by hospitals.

The WHO's warning is a timely reminder that caesarean sections should only be performed when medically necessary. Women who are considering having a caesarean section should discuss the risks and benefits with their doctor.

The 10 most expensive airports for private jet landing fees are:

1. Haneda Airport, Tokyo, Japan: £4,559 ($6,850)
2. Narita International Airport, Tokyo, Japan: £3,728 ($5,600)
3. Kansai International Airport, Osaka, Japan: £3,594 ($5,400)
4. Toronto Pearson International Airport, Toronto, Canada: £3,461 ($5,200)
5. Darwin International Airport, Darwin, Australia: £3,059 ($4,600)
6. Bristol Airport, Bristol, England: £2,929 ($4,400)
7. Chūbu Centrair International Airport, Nagoya, Japan: £2,863 ($4,300)
8. Dublin Airport, Dublin, Ireland: £2,729 ($4,100)
9. LaGuardia Airport, New York, United States: £2,630 ($3,950)
10. Salzburg Airport, Salzburg, Austria: £2,530 ($3,800)

These fees are based on the 767-400 aircraft, which can hold up to 50 passengers but is often customized for private use.

The high landing fees at these airports are due to a number of factors, including the cost of maintaining and operating the airport, the demand for landing slots, and the competition from other airports.

The cost of maintaining and operating an airport is high, as it requires a significant investment in infrastructure, such as runways, taxiways, and terminals. In addition, airports must also pay for security, air traffic control, and other services.

The demand for landing slots is also high, as many airports are operating at or near capacity. This means that airports can charge high fees for landing slots, as they know that airlines will be willing to pay to ensure that their flights can depart and arrive on time.

Finally, airports also face competition from other airports, both within their own country and in other countries. This competition can drive down landing fees, as airports are forced to offer competitive rates in order to attract airlines.

However, the high landing fees at some airports can be a barrier to entry for private jet operators, as they can make it more expensive to operate a private jet. This can lead to a concentration of private jet ownership among the wealthy, as only those who can afford the high fees will be able to own a private jet.

The art of washing your own car appears to be dying out in Britain. A third of men have never washed their own car, and three-quarters of women never do. The survey also reveals that drivers are more likely to take their car to a car wash on a local forecourt.

Factors behind the decline include shops now opening on a Sunday and more live football on TV, meaning more people put off the chore at the weekend. Other reasons given for not washing cars include the rise of hand car washes and the fact that 4x4 and off-road vehicles are too large to clean.

Brits are more likely to wash their own car during the holidays, as the recent Easter break saw an estimated 15 million cars cleaned by their owners. However, one in four said they only did it as an excuse to get out of the house.

Cars are most likely to be washed by their owners every week in Birmingham, Chelmsford and Sheffield, and least likely in Oxford, Bath and Edinburgh. Audis, Toyotas and BMWs are most likely to be washed by their owners, and Range Rovers, Peugeots and Mercedes least often.

OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley said: "A lot of us remember seeing our streets full of men cleaning their cars every Sunday. It was a national tradition.

"But let's face it, we don't have as much time any more, the cars are bigger and even the kids don't seem to want to earn a bit of extra money doing it for us either.

"On top of that, there is now plenty of choice out there if you want to put the car through an automated machine or get a gang of enthusiastic guys to do it for you fairly cheaply."

On Friday, January 28, 2022, Starbucks experienced a nationwide computer outage that affected registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada. But for some fans of the popular coffeehouse chain, the joy proved short-lived. According to reports from around the country, many Starbucks locations in places like Florida, Tennessee and Arizona closed their doors so as not to give away free products during the shutdown.

The potentially costly tech snafu comes just one day after the Seattle-based global coffeehouse chain, which had 21,366 locations in 65 countries last year, posted record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion. Starbucks announced late Friday night that the computer outage had now been resolved. The global coffeehouse chain said in an update on its site that stores are expected to open for "business as usual" Saturday.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has said he is dreaming of beating rivals Manchester City in Sunday's derby at Old Trafford, but will have to do so without Robin van Persie. Van Persie said he was fit to feature in the game against City on Sunday after ankle trouble but Van Gaal has ruled him out.

With City rocking after defeat at Crystal Palace on Monday, Van Gaal and his players have an opportunity to finish as high as second or third and avoid a Champions League qualifying fixture later in the summer. The United boss wants his side to move towards that target by taking all three points against City.

Van Gaal said: "I dream of it. Every player should dream of the victory. Of course I want to win because it's a big step up the table also. If we win then third place is available. A few months ago, nobody would have thought about that, apart from me. If we win then the position in the table is good as we would then almost certainly be qualified for the top four. And if we are third it's better than the goal we set in pre-season."

Van Gaal acknowledged that City will provide a stern challenge to his team and played down the idea he will be motivated by revenge, after losing the away fixture earlier in the campaign. "We have lost 1-0, that is my history, the last game," Van Gaal said. "I say always in such games, always, you have to control your aggression. We did not do that at that time. So I hope we have learned from that moment. I can not say because we lost that game that we have to win this game. In my opinion, you can lose to Man City two times. That is possible."

The United boss also ruled out a potential return for Luke Shaw. Like Van Persie, Van Gaal does not yet consider him fit enough to feature. "I don’t think Shaw is fit enough to play," Van Gaal said. "But I can not say they are not fit, but in my opinion they are not fit to play. That is a different question."

Van Gaal admitted he is looking forward to sampling the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford, as he takes on City with home advantage for the first time since arriving at the club. "When I see the fans of Man Utd, they are supporting us in a marvellous way, I think," Van Gaal said. "After matches, I give our fans a big compliment, not because I have to, because then I wouldn’t say it. I say it because I feel it."

Mike Lane, a huntsman, was assaulted by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes. The attack took place on January 24, 2023, near Amesbury, England. Lane was chasing an artificial scent, rather than a fox, at the time of the attack. He was knocked to the ground and kicked in the head, suffering concussion and broken teeth. His face was also swollen. He has since suffered memory loss.

The face of the main suspect was captured on video. Following the attack, Wiltshire Police issued the suspect's photograph, although he has not been identified.

In an exclusive interview with the Mail on Sunday, Lane said: "I've been told by police they are shelving their inquiries due to insufficient evidence. It's angered us because we gave them evidence. I'm beginning to lose my trust in the police."

Wiltshire Police confirmed they had stopped the investigation pending further information, but their failure to identify, charge or prosecute anyone involved has dismayed hunt supporters across the country.

On the day of the attack, about 15 protesters sprayed hounds with the perfumed chemical citronella to distract them from the scent. Lane said: "I noticed they parked about 250 yards away. Then five came towards us. They were looking for trouble -- it was a hardcore element we'd not seen before.

"They were abusive and then one spat at me and then punched me in the face. A scuffle broke out and I slipped and one started kicking me in the head, stamped on me and the heel of his steel toe-capped trainer stuck in my mouth. I was knocked out for a few minutes. Then the chap started swinging a rope with an iron bar."

Lane, who has paid £500 for dental treatment since the attack, added: "I feel let down and think the police could have done more."

Karen Fieldsend, 42, who made the call to police, is furious that the case has been dropped. "It's disgraceful," she said. "If you had people assaulted in a city centre, something would be done, but in the countryside people forget about it."

James Cameron, 53, vice-chairman of the Tedworth Hunt, added: "Their decision is disappointing, but this highlights how difficult it is for police to do their job when saboteurs turn up wearing face coverings."

The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing a face covering so criminals can be brought to justice.

Last night a spokesman for Wiltshire Police said: "We have been unable to move the inquiry further forward. At this stage the case has been recorded as undetected, however should other evidence come to light then it will be re-opened."

Raheem Sterling was told by Liverpool fans that they expect him to remain at the club this summer on the day he was parading the club's new home kit at Anfield. The new gingham design, presented to supporters at Anfield on Friday, is the first offering from US sports brand New Balance, who struck a record-breaking £300million four-year kit deal to replace sister company Warrior as Liverpool's suppliers. New South Wales residents are being warned to brace for more floods and damage, with another storm predicted to hit later this week.

Meteorologists say early indicators show that an east coast low could hit the region, with heavy rain possible from Thursday.

The State Emergency Service was deluged with calls for assistance last week and has more than 4,000 jobs from the 24,196 requests still to be completed.

SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills says the organisation is concerned that more storms will hamper clean-up efforts.

"Any weather that strikes up north is of concern to us, especially considering the devastation from the storm that hit last week," Ms Wills told Daily Mail Australia.

"Any water is going to hit that saturated ground and raise flood levels again, and any wind is going to knock over the trees that are uprooted."

Ms Wills said the SES was particularly worried about the effect more wild weather would have on the Hunter region, which suffered through flooding and high winds in the last storm.

"That's our focus - the Hunter region - because they've been smashed," she said.

"We really are quite concerned about that particular area.

"We are urging the community to prepare themselves, prepare their homes and prepare their families to prevent further loss and devastation."

Weatherzone meteorologist Kim Westcott said a trough of low pressure was forming along the coast, and would hit heaviest in the far northern parts of the state.

"It looks like we could get an east coast low later on this week, but it is certainly a different kettle of fish than we've seen last week," Ms Westcott said.

"The difference is that it is a little bit further away from the coast and it is in a different area - so the heavy rain is probably not going to be over Sydney."

Ms Westcott said the weather system appeared to be moving quickly.

"We might get two days of rain but it's not likely to be the same three days of wind and rain we saw last week," she said.

The Bureau of Meteorology's NSW regional director Barry Hanstrum said: "Early indications suggest the main impacts of intense rainfall and strong winds will be on coastal areas in the state's north east including the Northern Rivers and Mid North Coasts, with heavy falls also likely for southeast Queensland.

"Current guidance suggests that rain will increase this week, and peak between Thursday and Saturday.

"Further rainfall is likely for catchments that have already experienced flooding during last week's severe weather event."

The Bureau of Meteorology said it was too early to tell how severe the weather system would be.

Ms Wills said the SES would spend the next few days trying to complete as many jobs as possible, as well as warning people to prepare their homes should another severe storm hit.

"Obviously we're trying to get through as many as we can before next system hits," she said.

Ms Wills said there were over 1000 personnel in the field across NSW, including 200 from other states such as Queensland, Victoria, the ACT and South Australia.

**Terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit.**

**Locations in Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire are also being used to radicalise Muslims.**

**Detective Constable Gareth Jones said those involved in such activities "take part in seemingly ordinary activities" in the community but "have an ulterior motive".**

**Speaking to Ceredigion Council, DC Jones stressed that issues surrounding terrorism were not confined to large cities.**

**Incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales can be traced back to 1998, when it is claimed hate preacher Abu Hamza sent a group of 10 extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons, in Powys.**

**The area is one of several locations used by the British military for training. Its rugged terrain helps prepare soldiers, including elite forces personnel like the SAS, physically and mentally for warfare.**

**In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers, Mohammad Sidique Khan and Shehzad Tanweer, were photographed white water rafting at the National Whitewater Centre in Bala, North Wales.**

**Five years later, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff were arrested as part of an al-Qaeda inspired gang who plotted a "Mumbai-style" series of terror attacks on Britain.**

**And Michael Adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, is understood to have studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences at Highmead, near Llanybydder.**

**The centre is understood to have been set up by Iraqi clerics.**

**Speaking to councillors, DC Jones said: "This chap attended the Institute for Human Sciences for quite some time. It's fair to say that is a connection to a horrendous terrorist attack in the UK.**

**'Ceredigion, Pembrokeshire and Powys have been used for radicalisation training. These people do turn up and take part in seemingly ordinary activities, but they do have an ulterior motive. This does happen in Ceredigion.'**

**DC Jones added that community intelligence was important to authorities. He said: 'It really is vital that if any intelligence comes from the community that we look at it.'**

Lacey Spears, a mother from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears. Spears was found guilty of poisoning her son with salt while he was hospitalized in a suburban New York hospital.

Spears' ex-husband, Chris Hill, lashed out on Facebook after the sentencing, writing that he hoped she would die in prison. He also called her a "crazy a** woman" and said she needed to be "beat to death."

The New York judge who sentenced Spears said she suffers from a mental illness, but that the crime was still "unfathomable in its cruelty." Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old British boy, died in a tragic accident while skiing in the French Alps. He was skiing with his family when he became separated from them and headed into dense woodland. He fell over a 164ft drop and died.

Carwyn was described as a "daring, outgoing and determined" youngster whose "handsome smile lit up any room". He was a "very competent skier and snowboarder" who had started skiing at the age of three.

The family said they had spent "the most happy ski holiday together" in the resort of Flaine in the days before the tragedy. They were enjoying their last run of the day when Carwyn's sister Antonia, nine, lost her ski on a jump and Carwyn pressed on ahead. His mother stopped to help her daughter and continued to the bottom of the piste. But Carwyn, who modelled himself on the TV adventurer Bear Grylls, was nowhere to be seen.

Mrs Scott-Howell returned to their hotel believing her son had made his own way back, but returned to the mountain when she found he wasn't there. Pierre-Yves Michau, the judge heading the investigation, said yesterday: "She asked everyone if they had seen him."

It is believed Carwyn left the piste and entered woodland because he had spotted the resort through the trees. Taking off his skis, he continued on foot as he hurried to get there. Police chief Michel Ollagnon confirmed that officers had been led to the boy's body by footprints in the snow. He said the final steps were broken up by "sliding marks" where Carwyn had tackled the sharper inclines on his backside.

Mr Ollagnon said: "We think he was attracted by the ski station that he could see below. We think he was heading for the resort."

Police last night said Carwyn's body is ready to be repatriated but his family remained in the Alps. Back in Wales, his friends have written in a condolence book on display at Brecon Cathedral: "Miss you in class. We will miss you always." Alongside the book is a picture of Carwyn dressed in his karate kit.

At the youngster's school in Brecon, head teacher Emyr Jones said pupils were devastated, adding: "We are all grieving." He described Carwyn as a "lively, likeable pupil who will be greatly missed" at Ysgol y Bannau school.

County councillor Liam Fitzpatrick said the community would rally behind the Scott-Howells, who are well known for their award-winning farm shop. He added: "It's horrendous. A tragic, tragic accident."

Carwyn lived with his parents at their farmhouse in the village near the Brecon Beacons. He is said to have loved the mountains and helping on the farm where he had grown up. The family often attended food fairs across the country and David Cameron was pictured buying a scotch egg from the family's stand last year.

The family has released a statement saying: "Carwyn was a loving, caring and happy boy who brought joy to everyone who knew him. He was a talented skier and snowboarder and loved the outdoors. He will be deeply missed by all who knew him."

The largest single high-definition map of mysterious dark matter has been produced by the Dark Energy Survey (DES). The map shows clumps of dark matter across 0.4 per cent of the sky, and is the first in a series of maps that will eventually allow a 3D view of dark matter across one eighth of the night sky. The map should allow astronomers to study how galaxies formed in the universe.

The DES is a five-year survey using the 4-metre Victor M. Blanco Telescope at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile. The survey is led by Fermilab in the US, and is funded by the National Science Foundation.

The map was created using data captured by the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device that is the primary instrument for the DES. The camera is designed to measure the shapes of galaxies, which can be used to map the distribution of dark matter.

The map shows that dark matter is not evenly distributed throughout the universe. Instead, it is concentrated in clumps and filaments, with large voids in between. This is similar to the distribution of visible matter, such as stars and galaxies.

The map will help astronomers to understand how galaxies formed and evolved. It will also help them to study the nature of dark matter, which is one of the most mysterious substances in the universe.

Dark matter is a type of matter that does not interact with light or other forms of electromagnetic radiation. This makes it very difficult to study directly. However, astronomers can study the effects of dark matter on visible matter. For example, dark matter can bend the light from distant galaxies, which can be used to map its distribution.

The DES is one of the largest and most ambitious surveys of the night sky ever undertaken. It is expected to produce a wealth of data that will help astronomers to understand the universe in unprecedented detail.

The US body that regulates internet addresses is looking to crack down on a Canadian company using the new '.sucks' domain name to extract exorbitant sums from celebrities such as Kevin Spacey and companies looking to protect their reputations.

So far, purchased names include YouTube.sucks, Bing.sucks, Visa.sucks, BankofAmerica.sucks, Yahoo.sucks, Telusmobility.sucks and other major brand names. Kevin Spacey has reportedly paid to have his '.sucks' domain taken down.

The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) sent a letter on Thursday to the US Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to see if the actions of company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. were illegal.

ICANN initially approved of the so-called top-level domain name, among nearly 600 it has added recently to expand beyond common names such as '.com', '.org' and '.net'. But it is backtracking after an advisory panel made up of industry groups and companies like Microsoft, Verizon and eBay complained last month.

Vox Populi began accepting registrations using '.sucks' on March 30 from trademark holders and celebrities before it is released to public applicants. It has recommended charging $2,499 a year for the privilege, and according to Vox Populi CEO John Berard, most of the names have been sold by resellers for around $2,000 a year.

Berard has said the domain name is meant to create destinations for companies to interact with their critics and called his company's business "well within the lines of ICANN rules and the law."

Two weeks ago, the advisory body called the Intellectual Property Constituency representing major companies and industry groups asked ICANN in a letter to halt the rollout of '.sucks', calling it a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory."

Companies like GoDaddy.com register some domain names for just $1 a year, and Vox Populi will offer consumers the right to secure a '.sucks' address for just $10 a year starting in September. The advisory body says that the threat of opening a '.sucks' site to the average consumer later is "an essential element of Vox Populi's coercive scheme."

ICANN said in its letter that if Canadian or US regulators find Vox Populi's actions are illegal, it could declare the company in breach of its contract and seek to change the registry's behavior. It said it is also seeking other remedies within its agreement with the company.

The advisory body says that the threat of opening a '.sucks' site to the average consumer later is "an essential element of Vox Populi's coercive scheme."

A five-day-old hippopotamus was killed after being caught up in a fight between two adult hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf's mother watched in horror as the baby was thrown into the air and dragged along the surface of the water before dying of its injuries.

The two male hippos had been fighting for some time, and the mother of the calf stayed with her herd, possibly believing it safer to stay out of harm's way herself. However, her decision proved fatal for the baby when one of the brawling adults grabbed the calf between its jaws.

Stacey Farrell, a 30-year-old tour operator for Shoreline Hippo and Safari, looked on with horror as the calf was caught up in the deadly fray. She said: "For hours she chased away the sub-adults and younger hippos from her little baby as I believe she knew they would be too rough.

"Sadly, as she closed her eye one of the sub-adult hippos grabbed the young calf. Whether intending to kill it or a bit of play or possibly jealousy gone wrong we'll never know.

"The mother tried to get the baby back but with the young calf in the sub-adult's mouth there wasn't much she could do. She attacked the hippo on the neck which forced the sub-adult to bite down harder and then suddenly flicked the baby in the air."

The hippopotamus died of its injuries hours later.

A light general aviation aircraft touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear and skidded along the runway on its belly. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale after the incident and landed safely. The FAA is investigating the incident.

The most common cause of a gear-up landing is human error, when the pilot simply forgets to deploy the landing gear before touchdown. Another cause is mechanical fault, when an electric motor or a hydraulic actuator fails.

In this case, it is likely that the pilot forgot to deploy the landing gear. This is a common mistake, and it is important for pilots to be aware of the potential consequences. In the case of the aircraft that touched down in Fort Pierce, Florida, the pilot was able to fly the aircraft to Fort Lauderdale and land safely. A drone carrying traces of a radioactive material was found on the roof of the Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo on Wednesday. The discovery came on the same day that a Japanese court approved a government plan to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push to restart the reactors is unpopular among many Japanese, who view nuclear energy as too dangerous.

A staff member spotted the drone on the roof of Abe's residence on Wednesday morning. Dozens of police investigators were dispatched to the roof to investigate the origin of the drone, which had four propellers and was 50 centimeters (20 inches) wide. Police say the drone was equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small traces of a radioactive material believed to be cesium, a common byproduct of nuclear reactors. Cesium was also discovered in areas around the failed Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant after its 2011 meltdown. Investigators suspect the cesium was placed in the bottle. The amount inside is not immediately harmful to humans.

Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga said the discovery is raising concerns about terrorism. "There might be terrorism attempts in the future at the Olympics and G7 summit using drones," Suga said. "So we need to examine and review continuously the way small unmanned vehicles like drones should be operated and how to cope with the threat of terrorism from drones. The government will do all that we can to prevent terrorism."

Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports to prevent problems with aircraft, but there are no flight restrictions for most of Tokyo, including the Prime Minister's residence and local and federal government buildings. Abe was not in his office at the time. He is in Indonesia, attending the Asian-African conference.

The discovery of the drone is the latest in a series of incidents that have raised concerns about the potential for terrorism involving drones. In December 2015, a drone carrying explosives crashed outside the Saudi Arabian embassy in Washington, D.C. In January 2016, a drone carrying a small explosive device crashed near the Pentagon. And in March 2016, a drone carrying a small explosive device crashed near the White House.

The use of drones for terrorist attacks is a relatively new phenomenon, but it is one that is likely to become more common in the future. Drones are relatively inexpensive and easy to obtain, and they can be used to carry a variety of weapons, including explosives, chemical agents, and biological agents. Drones can also be used to carry out surveillance and reconnaissance missions, which can help terrorists to plan and execute attacks.

The threat of terrorism involving drones is a serious one, and it is one that governments around the world are taking seriously. In the United States, the Department of Homeland Security has developed a number of initiatives to counter the threat of drone-based terrorism. These initiatives include developing new technologies to detect and track drones, working with law enforcement to develop new procedures for responding to drone-based threats, and educating the public about the dangers of drones.

The threat of terrorism involving drones is a complex one, and there is no easy solution. However, by working together, governments and law enforcement agencies can take steps to mitigate the threat and protect the public.

Tony Abbott, the Australian Prime Minister, was cheered on by a crowd of about 50 as he skolled a schooner of beer. However, he has come under fire from anti-drinking campaigners who claim he is glorifying binge drinking and associating being a man with drinking booze.

Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor at the University of Technology Sydney, said it was "problematic" that the Prime Minister, who she believes should be advocating against binge drinking, thought it acceptable to "showcase his masculinity" by skolling a beer.

"It sets up a culture that drinking isn't about socialising with friends, it's about how quickly and how much you can drink," she said.

Dr Robert warned people can forget their limits when they are wrapped up in the act of demonstrating how much, or how quickly, they can drink.

"It is the whole performance and the display and showing off which is the problematic part," she told Daily Mail Australia.

However, she said it was not just Mr Abbott's skol that was concerning, it was also the way media and other government officials have reacted to the event.

In an interview on Sunday, opposition leader Bill Shorten quipped that he was "just pleased that Tony Abbott's learning to drink beer without adding lemonade to it".

Mr Abbott was labelled "un-Australian" for ordering a light beer during his 2010 campaign.

Dr Robert said while drinking was a part of the Australian tradition, it was dangerous to make comments that would only glorify irresponsible drinking practices and perpetuate the stereotype that drinking heavily makes you a true blue Aussie bloke.

Critics said he should be setting an example that you don't have to drink heavily to be a "true blue Aussie bloke".

It appeared to take the Prime Minister about six seconds to down the schooner, as players cheered and chanted "skoll" and "Tony".

Health Minister Sussan Ley was quick to jump to Mr Abbott's defence saying there was "nothing wrong" with the Prime Minister's antics.

“If more people got up at 4.30 in the morning and went running and cycling and worked as hard as our prime minister to keep fit and demonstrate that there are many ways that you can do this, I think we’d have a healthier country as a result,” Ms Ley said.

During his night out, Mr Abbott gave a speech to the players, according to Australian Women's Weekly.

"He grabs the microphone and gives a speech, which went along the lines of: 'Well isn't this a real treat, I've been a rugby man all my life but now I finally get to hang out with some real footballers' to which of course the crowd went crazy," coach Carradous said.

"Then he proceeds to reach down and grab a schooner and he drank from head-to-toe the entire schooner, dribbling little bits on his shirt ... he was proud as punch."

While Mr Abbott is not the first Australian Prime Minister to show off his skolling skills, with former Labor Prime Minister Bob Hawke a notable example, Dr Roberts said he should have taken into consideration recent shifts in attitudes over heavy drinking.

"I don’t necessarily think it’s a partisan thing but I do think the climate has changed and we didn’t [used to] have the concern over binge drinking that we do now," she said.

Mr Abbott was asked to have a drink by University of Technology Sydney Bats coach Simon Carradous, and the Prime Minister happily obliged.

"He drank the entire schooner, dribbling bits on his shirt ... he was proud as punch," a witness said.

Robert Hardy, an 89-year-old actor known for his roles in All Creatures Great and Small and as Winston Churchill, is selling his collection of antiques in a £100,000 auction. The sale includes a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow made from yew with a mother-of-pearl handle, and a portrait of Hardy holding the bow. The actor is also selling paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and a fine collection of crystal chandeliers. The auction will take place on Saturday, February 25, 2023, at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire.

Hardy, who lives in the Cotswolds, said that he was sad to sell his collection. "Downsizing and losing a great part of a treasured library makes for sadness," he said. "Entrusting it all to Dominic Winter and Co has taken away much of the pain, and through them I wish anyone who comes to possess anything that was mine as much joy and pleasure as it has given me through the years."

Hardy has built up the haul of antiques thanks to his interest in classic literature and military history. He was taught by Tolkien and C.S. Lewis when he studied English at Magdalen College, Oxford, and he has published two books on the history of the longbow. He was also consulted as an expert during the raising of the Tudor shipwreck the Mary Rose.

Hardy, a close friend of Richard Burton, worked with top actors including Laurence Olivier, John Gielgud, and Judi Dench during his early days as a Shakespearean specialist. He found national fame playing vet Siegfried Farnon in All Creatures Great and Small, the hit BBC drama which aired between 1978 and 1990 and also starred Lynda Bellingham.

The actor is well known for portraying Winston Churchill in a number of television performances, and has also played Churchill's fellow Second World War leader Franklin D. Roosevelt. More recently, he introduced himself to a younger generation of viewers with an appearance in the Harry Potter films, where he played Cornelius Fudge, the Minister for Magic.

Hardy was forced to retire from stage acting two years ago, when he suffered a fall while playing Churchill again in The Audience, a West End play about the Queen which starred Helen Mirren. However, he has insisted that he will continue to do television work despite his advanced age.
